title: Simple, with the necessities.
text:
A bit of background of my reasons for purchasing this product: I recently gained weight while recovering from surgery. In addition, I work from home, so I've developed a sedentary lifestyle recently. The Fitbit was a method of keeping myself accountable for my actions, movements, and goals. Did I walk today? How am I sleeping? Am I moving enough to raise my heart levels? How is my stress? Was I active this week?

The Fitbit charger does a great job of answering these questions while also telling the time. It can track my movements without the constant ping of my phone continuously going off. It doesn't have all the bells and whistles as other smartwatches, so its main focus is primarily exercise.

A few things I like:
1. The app is great, I love seeing my sleep score, fitness level, and using it for overall progress
2. The watch is so lightweight, sometimes I barely notice it's there.
3. The battery life is great, I usually charge it whenever I shower so I haven't seen it drain (although I shower daily)
4. There's an Alarm on the watch! It does a better job of waking me up than my phone.
5. The tracking is very accurate. I sometimes panic when I don't feel the watch on my wrist because I want to make sure I moved any given day.

A few things I dislike:
1. Pairing this device with the mobile app is a pain. I had Fitbits in the past, and it pains me to see that pairing has not changed since then.
2. The classifications of activities seem off. Since I'm using VR for some fitness activity, the mobile app incorrectly identifies one activity as swimming, and the app will not allow users to change the exercise classification. In addition, it does not identify boxing, so it sees it as a general Sports category.
3. The wristband should be renamed to waste band because it's awful. I had to look for a 3rd party wrist strap to replace the current one. Would not recommend the default band for comfort absolutely feel the Fitbit team should be ashamed for putting a product out there with a strap that comfortable.
date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on June 3, 2023

title: Extremely Disappointed: Do Not Buy the Fitbit Charge 5 on Amazon!
text:
I am utterly disappointed with my purchase of the Fitbit Charge 5 from Amazon. After just 9 months of use, this so-called "premium" fitness tracker has turned into a complete nightmare. The device is plagued with multiple issues that render it practically useless.

Firstly, the display of my Fitbit Charge 5 started exhibiting random horizontal lines, making it difficult to read any information on the screen. This defect significantly impairs the functionality of the device and makes it frustrating to use on a daily basis.

To add insult to injury, the battery life of the Fitbit Charge 5 has taken a nosedive. Instead of lasting for the promised week, the battery drains completely in a mere 12 hours. This means that I have to charge it constantly, interrupting my tracking and defeating the purpose of having a fitness tracker in the first place.

When I reached out to Fitbit support in hopes of finding a solution, they acknowledged the device's malfunctioning but astonishingly refused to replace it because I had purchased it through Amazon. This blatant disregard for customer satisfaction is unacceptable, especially considering the premium price I paid for this device.

Thinking that Amazon, renowned for its customer service, would come to my rescue, I contacted their support next. Unfortunately, I encountered a similar response. Amazon not only washed their hands of the problem but also pointed me back to Fitbit for any resolution. It's disheartening to see both companies shifting blame instead of taking responsibility for selling a faulty product.

I implore anyone considering purchasing the Fitbit Charge 5 to steer clear of Amazon as their purchase platform. It's evident that both Fitbit and Amazon are unwilling to stand behind their products or provide any form of satisfactory customer support. Save yourself the frustration and potential loss of hard-earned money by purchasing this device directly from a trusted retailer or exploring alternative options.

In conclusion, the Fitbit Charge 5 has proven to be an unreliable and poorly supported device. Its faulty display and abysmal battery life, coupled with the lack of assistance from Fitbit and Amazon, have left me feeling cheated and utterly dissatisfied with my purchase. Avoid the Fitbit Charge 5 on Amazon at all costs.

title: Limited functionality; inconsistent
text:
I found the fitbit less useful than advertised. The only okay feature is the GPS tracking of running, with distance and pace. Sometimes it measures the distance well, sometimes it's off (compared with car-measured and google maps--it reported 6.4 miles where the other two give 5.4, quite a gap). The notifications that pop up during the run are annoying, kindergarten-style nice job, well done, "you are in cardio zone", and they are difficult to read on the small screen in bright daylight. I did not find a way to get rid of them.

The other features are not impressive. Sleep tracking is spotty at best, and you have to wear the tracker on your wrist while sleeping, which I found awkward. So to measure sleep quality, you have to give up on it from the start!

To get inactivity/exercise reminders, you have to wear the tracker all the time, which after a while also becomes a bother.

The payment feature is redundant because it requires entering the phone pin code using virtual rolling wheels (difficult when at the register) AND the phone nearby. However, if the phone is nearby, I can pay with the phone. Alarms and timers? -- As though there aren't enough of them around already.
The tracker can receive notifications from the phone when close to it--but who needs them when the phone is nearby! Luckily, they can be disabled.

title: Love my FitBit, but GET DIFFERENT BANDS!
text:
I (21F) have been using my Charge 5 for a few months, I love the device itself and the app's features for the price. I mainly track daily steps and sleep. The app shows you what stages of sleep you're in throughout the night, and keeps track of how long you slept (including picking up on naps). My mom (50F) also uses a Charge 5, although a bit more intensively than I do, as it's been helpful with her weight loss journey.

HOWEVER — if you buy it, spare yourself some pain and buy different wristbands. I've switched to a fabric one and it works much better. I only take my FitBit off to charge or when I'm showering, so when I went to take it off the other day I noticed a patch of REALLY irritated, red, and almost blister-y skin RIGHT where the end buckle sits against my wrist. I don't wear my device tightly at all, I keep it comfortably secure as per the instructions to get a good reading. I would likely pass it off as a "me thing" had my mom not come to me this morning to show me HER near-blistered wrist (unknowing that I had the same problem)!

So yeah, LOVE my FitBit and have no qualms with the device itself! But beware of the bands, especially if you have sensitive skin. Better to just get a replacement off Amazon.

title: Useful but less capable than advertised
text:
An excellent pedometer that measures pulse well and sports a colorful display. Beyond that, the company seems to have paid more attention to the marketing material than the capabilities of the watch.

The good:
- Excellent battery life. A daily charge during my morning shower is enough to keep the watch topped up.
Comfortable, with a wide variety of bands available.
- Easy to read display.
- Pedometer appears to be accurate and consistent.
- Mobile app works well and provides interesting insights.
- Numerous display options available to download.

Not yet tested:
- GPS capability that tracks time, distance, and pace seems like a useful feature. I haven't used that feature yet, but it is a standard capability of many similar devices and I expect it works well on this watch.

Needs work:
- Device must be double tapped to illuminate. Although the company claims the display will illuminate with a turn of the wrist, in my experience no amount of turning, twisting, twitching, flailing, or flapping will reliably cause illumination. Fortunately, double tapping works reliably (though it is bad form in meetings).
- Automatic exercise recognition works well for walking but doesn't discriminate between a stroll along a level path and a challenging climb through the hills. Lawn mowing is recognized as "Outdoor Biking". Yard work sometimes is recognized as "Sport". Occasionally weight training is recognized as "sport" as well, but generally it is ignored. That isn't surprising, since the unit of measure for "Weights" is "laps" and I don't do laps while weight training. Kayaking logs in as "Sport" as well, which is as good as anything.
- Sleep measurements are fascinating and generally seem to capture my sleep patterns, but at least once a week are off by several hours. Did I really sleep only three hours those nights?

Bottom line: Measurement of exercise and sleep are inconsistent at best. However, this is not a device designed to provide medical-grade assessment of metabolism or health. Even with its inconsistent data capture, it will highlight trends that could be useful guides to behavior modification. Keep your expectations low, and you will be happy with this device.

title: Fairly feature-rich device, with low-quality construction and infuriating misses in recorded data
text:
I like the idea as well as *most* of the execution of the Fitbit. I personally find the sleep tracker great. From a workout perspective, having the GPS built in as well as heart rate and step metrics is fantastic. From there, I have found some unfortunately infuriating aspects to the Fitbit experience:

1. Construction quality

For some initial backstory, I had a Charge 4 and really liked it. It stopped working within the warranty period and they sent me a replacement. Then the wristband broke. They sent me a replacement for that. Then the BODY of the Charge 4 itself disintegrated and there was no longer a way to attach the wristband and so the device was useless. I was out of warranty by this time, so my hope was that if I upgraded to the Charge 5 just this once, then I might be into calmer waters.

So I buy the Charge 5. Here I am 7 months later, and while the wristband actually seems to be holding up, the device itself just stopped working. Looking at the back I can see that moisture has seeped into the sensor area. Again, they are sending me a replacement.

3. Workout details

Running - I would be extremely surprised if there's a single runner on the Fitbit design or product management teams. I've had multiple Timex Ironman watches over the years. They all report times down to the millisecond, provide splits as you see fit, etc. Fitbit does a reasonable enough job tracking your times while you're actually running, but when you go to look at the details later in the app, you don't get the full overall time. At best, you get hours and minutes. This may seem like splitting hairs to some, but runners (and swimmers) are a generally fastidious bunch and we want our seconds and milliseconds. In addition, there doesn't appear to be a way to see a breakdown of your splits across dimensions other than a mile. It's using GPS - unleash our data for us so that we can get down in the statistical weeds like an MLB announcer.

Day of Week - This is a bit of a nit, but the workout history only shows the day of month, not the day of week. I'm not a calendar over here. Show me the calendar day AND the DOW so I can quickly compare performance week-over-week at a glance.

Compare workouts over time - I used Endomondo for years and absolutely loved that app until it was finally retired a year or 2 ago. You could very efficiently compare week over week workout stats and details in the app. You could even filter on specific activities and get a roll-up weekly and monthly summary of things like total time and mileage. You'd even get notifications and reports about things like personal records for things like distances, times, and overall duration. Fitbit has none of this. It's like scrolling through a never ending Instagram feed - no purposeful direction other than the thing currently staring back at you. I see that there may be some way to link this up with Strava, but I'd really like an integrated and seamless experience that doesn't require special import/export hacks. Let me start a workout on my watch, and be off!

4. Zone notifications

I made this a special section because it's so utterly intrusive. It's like when you accidentally click on one of those click-baity websites, start scrolling, and little ads start popping up over top of what you're trying to read on the top, bottom, left and right. So, I'm in the middle of a run or workout and want to check my time, heart rate, or any other stat for that matter, and up pops "You're in Cardio! Keep it up!" Good, great, now get out of my way! Tap, double tap, swipe, flick my wrist, intimidation - NONE of these things gets rid of the notification! It's just there, in your way, for a solid 10 seconds or more. This makes normal training annoying. It makes interval/fartlek training damn near impossible. Your heart rate in those cases is ALL over the place. Last but not least, sometimes I go to stop my workout and the screen suddenly becomes non-responsive. Then BAM, that darn notification pops up in the way and I can't stop my run time until it decides to go away.

5. Support

Support is OK. At least they will replace devices without too much effort. It probably depends on the type of problem you're having, but with my Charge 4 they refused to send me a replacement until they shipped me a return envelope and I returned the broken device. It was weeks before I had a working watch again. With the Charge 5, they seemed to have scrapped this process and now ship out replacements immediately. Much appreciated!

6. Fitbit Community Feedback Utility

I don't use the community much, but I had hoped that I could get some product manager to take a look at some improvements for running experience for the watch and app. A month or more went by when someone finally responded. All they had to say was "put your request over here instead." Funny enough, I had put my request in this specific area because I saw someone else make the same thread in a different area and the Fitbit team told them to put the thread where I had put mine.

Conclusion

Overall, I'm OK with the fitbit for now, but I still find it lacking for anyone other than extremely casual athletes. I think a good portion of the problems are simply lack of investment in development resources for the app itself. The remainder are due to major remaining issues with quality. I'm hoping better app and firmware updates on the horizon, but until then I'll be seriously looking for a better replacement. Something like a cross between a Timex Ironman, Fitbit, and Strava or Endomondo.

Return to "settings" on your phone and disconnect the charge 5. State that you are unpairing it. Wait a bit and then go to the fitbit app where you will be asked if you want to connect your Charge 5 with the application. Say yes, then wait. Stare at the long slow line which says "App is taking a while to sync; hang tight". Wait some more. If you don't stare at the phone the app will disappear. Reopen the app. It will ask you if you want to link your Charge 5. Say yes.
Then read your results. Getting them takes a full 10 to 15 minutes from start to finish.

Yesterday--24 hours ago-- my Charge 5 had a 19% battery charge; so I recharged it as I do every day. This morning after going through the hassle of getting my readings, the battery was down to 12%. It was as close as possible to 99% before I went to bed.

I am watching my oxygen saturation or I would have returned this within a week.
It's like being in a terrible marriage to a partner who does not show up for you without a long struggle.

title: Just the new version of my favorite fitness tracker, with some flaws
text:
Through the years I owned every version of the Fitbit Charge Tracker and it still remains my choice, the best option given features, size, comfort, price and durability (usually a Fitbit lasts me until I cannot longer buy replacement bands).
I have tiny wrists and although I would love to try the smartwatches from Fitbit, they are incredibly bulky and uncomfortable. Truth be told, even the Charge is a little too big on me, but it's the smallest Fitbit product with Heart Rate monitor and sleep tracker.

What I dislike about the Charge 5 is that they removed stair tracking and that they track `Active Minutes` based on heart rate zones, not just being active. I do lots of walking and hiking, so I might end up with a 5-6 hours hike but no `Active Minutes` because my heart rate was 90-110 during the hike.
I also dislike the wastefulness of getting both the S & L bands, there should be an option to only get one. I'll never use the L bands, even on the tightest loop the tracker would fell off my hand.

Otherwise the tracker is pretty decent at tracking sleep, although 1-2 times a month it won't track a night of sleep at all, although I clearly had a good and restful one.
It picks up runs, HIIT workouts and the elliptical fairly easily without me starting the activity.
It's fairly accurate with step tracker, but as most fitness tracker you can easily trick it to add steps by punching the air or moving your hand vigorously.

The Daily Readiness Score is an useless feature to me. I had awful days with a good score and awful days with a fair score; I see zero correlation between that score and my stress level. But I didn't purchase it for this feature.

The skin temperature variation and heart rate monitor are from my perspective spot on. It always amazes me how I can use the Fitbit data to know 2-3 days in advance if I get a cold or infection.

GPS is fairly accurate, maybe a few feet off during my runs, but usually it shows me on the right streets / trails.

From my perspective the Fitbit Charge is very comfortable. I only take it off while I shower (and take this time to charge it) and it never caused my irritation, even on hot sweaty workouts. Since I charge it each time I shower, I don't think I ever saw the battery under 80%, so I can't state how long it lasts on it's own.

title: Shoddy Product, Shoddier Company, WARRANTY SCAMMERS
text:
This was my second Fitbit device owned. After my Charge 2 screen eventually dimmed and died, I upgraded to the Charge 5. Things seemed to be going fairly well for the next few months... until I made the fatal mistake of getting it wet.

Now mind you, the Charge 5 is rated to be water resistant up to 50m, but apparently it couldn't handle the little 1.5m hotel pool I swam in because the screen went dead afterwards. I did a quick search and tried several of the suggested fixes that I found online; nothing worked. I finally contacted Fitbit directly and spoke with a representative. For the next 2 hours the rep goaded me into performing one diagnostic chore after another. She even went so far as to request that I record a video of me doing a hard reset of the device (that I then had to compress so that I could upload it for her to see). It was all a monumental waste of time, but I jumped through every hoop she threw up because I sensed that they were doing everything they could to wiggle out of honoring their warranty and I didn't want to give them any excuses.

Well, finally even the faithful Fitbit rep had to admit that the device must really, truly be defective. Then came the final insult. She asked me to upload a copy of my Amazon invoice. I did so. A few seconds later the rep declares that she's sorry, but they can't replace my device because I didn't buy it "from an authorized reseller." At this point I'm out of patience and ask her what she's talking about since I just showed her my Amazon invoice. Ahh, but that's the problem: the device wasn't sold directly by Amazon itself, but rather a 3rd-party reseller using Amazon's marketplace!

So there's the "gotcha." Doesn't matter that I bought a brand-new factory-sealed Fitbit device on Amazon that I've been successfully using to connect to their services for the past 5 months; because it wasn't sold directly by Amazon, they refused to fix/replace their shoddy product. Mind you, nowhere on their product page does it say anything about a warranty only being honored if sold by authorized resellers. I don't doubt for one second that that omission is by design.

People, this world is full of incompetent and/or unscrupulous businesses that screw things up then duck accountability like a disease, making all our lives harder than they have to be. What should have been a simple diagnose-and-replace warranty operation turned out to be a 2-hour ordeal that ended with a silly fine-print technicality that you won't find unless you stumble upon the right link on their web page. Those are the kinds of two-bit, penny-pinching, money-grubbing shenanigans I'd expect from some off-brand upstart competitor, not from a company with the brand recognition of Fitbit.

I am not a reactionary person, but I can comfortably say that I will never buy a product from nor use the services of Fitbit ever again. And if you're a consumer who values integrity and accountability when dealing with businesses, I'd advise that you avoid them as well.

title: never-ending swiping/band rash
text:
The Samsung Fit Pro 2 spoiled me. It cost a fraction of a Fitbit and was superior in almost every way.
The FitBit Charge 5 was my first FitBit and it is a huge disappointment, especially coming from a company that specializes in wearables. The UI is very poorly designed and without a button, the user is banished to a world of endless swiping. An action as simple as setting up a countdown timer takes 5 swipes to one side, tap, swipe down, tap, tap through two more times, then go. If you mess up, start over.
When I'm at the gym, I use the countdown timer between every set. Very often, the face resets to the home screen with the clock face. I have to swipe through the entire UI again to get back to the timer, including the process of setting the timer before I can get the watch to start counting down. But I'll look at the watch hours after leaving the gym and it will still be on the countdown timer screen.
It also does not provide any notifications from a Samsung A53 phone.
The app is about the same as most other fitness apps with minor improvements to nutrition tracking.
The Samsung Fit Pro 2 came out in 2016. The only thing FitBit has been able to improve since then is the battery life.
The rash from the band is just the cherry on top. Of all the smartwatches and regular watches I've worn, the band that comes with the FitBit is the only one to cause my skin to break down.

I purchased the Fitbit Charge 5 primarily to track data from my workouts on an Echelon bike. Seeing that this product has the ability to connect and sync with fitness apps like Echelon and Strada, it was a good choice over more expensive smart watches with extra features I didn't really need.

However, I discovered within the first two weeks that the functionality I was looking for seldom works. My exercises from Echelon Fit stopped appearing after 1-2 sessions. When I looked for a support solution their answer was plainly simple to "remove the authorized app and then re-add it", which then allows the sync to function one or two more times before it fails again.

So realizing that I wasn't going to be able to reliably use that feature, I was expecting the Fitbit Charge 5 to use the SmartTrack feature that would automatically record activity, but of course, that was not working either. So I went back to Fitbit support and discovered dozens of posts with the same problem, and supports "solution" was to simply restart the device. I tried this twice and it would stop working after 1-2 activities.

So the primary reason I purchased this device has sporadic, buggy functionality, and "support" had very limited ideas for a resolution. I re-boxed the device and will be returning it to Amazon and ordering a different brand product.

title: Buyer Beware!
text:
I have had my Fitbit Charge 5 for about 6 months now. It died on me while on vacation so I lost my step count streak. Bummer. The screen wouldn't turn on and would occasionally show a red circle with a white X in the middle. Unfortunately this is not the first Fitbit that I have had that has died a premature death. The older models certainly seemed to be more robust.

I surfed the Fitbit forums for help, but none of the suggestions fixed my problem. I then contacted Fitbit support. Even though this device supposedly has a 1 year manufacturer's warranty, Fitbit support attempted no troubleshooting and instead refused to help as I had not purchased it through Fitbit or an authorized reseller.

Wait a minute, isn't Amazon an authorized reseller? Looking at my order, I unknowingly purchased this item from a 3rd party, Electronics Club, who is not an authorized reseller: https://www.amazon.com/sp?ie=UTF8&seller=A3NZWXSNTH0Z2Q

I then contacted Amazon for support. Amazon says that Electronics Club would fulfill the warranty and gave me the link to contact them. Electronics Club attempted no troubleshooting and simply refused to fulfill the warranty and said I needed to talk to Amazon. And the cycle continues.

So here I am, with a broken Fitbit, a 1 year warranty that nobody is going to fulfill. So please be careful that you do not end up like me. If you buy from Amazon, make sure it actually is being sold by Amazon.

title: It's good but here's the full scoop.
text:
Pros:
Very comfy and can comfortably be worn with bike and ski gloves, and doesn't interfere with push-ups, biking, or anything else where your wrist is involved. I recommend getting a strap with some holes if you sweat a lot.

Week-long battery life with super-fast charging. Takes a considerable hit if you set the GPS to use only the watch versus phone or "dynamic" mode.

The HIT mode is great. You set the durations and number of intervals and it vibrates to cue you through your workout.

Pretty good app, but it loves to remind you to get the subscription. There's some oddities like the selection of activity choice, when set by the app, is always, run, walk, and hike, no matter what you can set from your device (which varies by the exact fitbit).

Bright, consistently turns on the screen when lifting it up.

Accurate GPS and heart rate. Heart rate will always be better on a chest monitor but this is pretty darn good.

Some decent watch faces and matching always-on options to choose from.

Looks good.

Has NFC payment support.

Cons:
If used with Android, you can control music and other audio by setting Spotify, Audible and whatever other app to show notifications. It then offers music controls and thumbs up, etc... in the form of replies, like if you were hitting a smiley face to a text message. A DEDICATED MUSIC CONTROL APP WOULD BE MUCH BETTER. This works alright unless you are trying to use this in the middle of exercise. Then it takes a tone of needless steps and is such a pain you're better off doing this on your phone.

Using this in the snow with wet hands isn't the worst, but tap recognition is definitely inconsistent. Given this has an accelerometer and not just a touch screen, a software update could help it considerably, and even have a glove mode. Not as bad with just sweaty hands but you'll run into similar issues. The lack of buttons makes this comfy, durable, and helps keep it clean, but an update that makes better use of he accelerometer is needed to truly make this work all the time.

There's an option to vibrate upon hitting heart rate zones. This is a highly-sought after feature by anyone looking to stay in a dedicated zone. Unfortunately, it only seems to vibrate upon going up a zone, not down. Hugely missed opportunity here. Should be one buzz for up, two for down. So close but no cigar.

No pacer function, like if you want to compete against a previous run/ride and know where you are relative to that run or some average.

Getting more nitpicky:
No app to start and stop a gopro or similar.

No camera control from the watch.

You can't type or dictate text replies.

No third-party app support.
_________________________________________________________________________________
Pretty good, but you'll know what you traded for the admittedly comfy and good looking slim form factor of a bracelet shaped tracker versus a watch.

title: Upgraded review and rating from previous issues.
text:
4-24-2023

Been using it for awhile. I find it helpful to motivate me to exercise, but the website and the app are kind of clunky and looks dated and acts more like a storefront to steer you toward other google devices. There are some useful things that you can track besides your food consumption, but I'm guessing that either the calories from the food producers are off, the number of calories the app says I'm burning per day is off or both are wrong, because even though I've lost weight it isn't coming off like it should. Recently I read a summary of a study that said most fitness devices and apps over-estimate calories burned by as much as 20% so I'm guessing that may be it.

That said, I can't believe that the app or website doesn't displays the sugars you've consumed in a day. It has all the macros and lists sodium but no sugars. The app forums say that Google removed it. Most everyone on the forums want it back. The 'workaround' is to sync your device with MyFitnessPal which still tracks sugars. Not much of workaround if I need to purchase the premium version of the Google app (to get the tracking features) as well as MyFitnessPal. $180/yr for both? Don't think so.

02-13-2023

Update and rating increase. Device is working fine now. Apparently there was a server issue judging by the comments made by users on the Fitbit forums. I'm happy with the device now. The app was a little confusing at first, but I think I have that figured out now. The only thing that still concerns me, and this probably isn't a Fitbit food database issue, is that many of the items I log for my meals during that day have incorrect nutrition facts from the label. A couple of times drastically so. If you submit a food that wasn't included that app has you snap pictures of the label for submission. Much better than MyFitnessPal which last time I used it asked users to type in the data for submission. That said, either that labels have changed or someone foobar'd the data input. Because what I'm seeing isn't matching the current labels. Also, you are able to scan the bar code as you can with MyFitnessPal which is nice for searching for a new meal item.

02-09-2023

Brand new device. Worked well for all of one day and then started having sync issues. Wish I would have gone to the Fitbit community forums first. This seems to have been an issues for quite some time, with many users complaining about the same issue.

I'm using an android phone. Its running version 10. The app has been updated and the device updated. All of the required permissions are allowed. I cleared the cache and force stopped the app. I restarted the app and my phone. I still get sync issues when I manually run one from the app. I am also having issues with the sleep tracking. Out of 4 nights it has only worked well for 1 night. And the setup for your sleep times and when it tracks is a little confusing.

Most of my sync issues are happening when I first get up in the morning. So maybe Fitbit is having backend issues with their servers?

That said, I do like the features on the device and hope that Fitbit gets the sync issues fixed.

title: Exceeded my expectations!
text:
I admit I was hesitant to part with my Charge 3 which I really liked, minus the fact that the screens are known to go dim. But once I started using the Charge 5 I will never go back.

My pros & cons are below, after using this watch for a little over a month.

First the Pros:
- Brilliant display that is so easy to read in any lighting conditions. Huge improvement over the Charge 3!
- Excellent new health metrics. I love the zone minutes, and these are the most important goal that I use. It's what really matters for fitness! Also has new overnight metrics that are nice though I do not find as useful as the zone minutes. EKG & EDM features I do not use, although some may find value in these apps.
- Very user friendly menus and displays. Much improved!
- Smoother lines and nice feel. The Charge 5 is more comfortable and less boxy than the Charge 3.
- Battery life for me is about 5 ish days. Not bad, however, my Charge 3 was 7-8 days for me. Probably because the display was so dim on the Charge 3.
- Love the built in GPS that is only used if you select Run or other exercise tracking. Auto detect tracking does not appear to activate the GPS that I am aware of.

Cons:
- Clock faces are not the best in my opinion. Wild art that is either crooked, loud, upside down, etc and really not that useful. Many have very small numbers for tracking heart rates or other metrics. I did find one called Target that is nice. I probably would not have purchased the watch initially without a decent clock face, and was considering Garmin because I did not like the clock faces at the time.
- Like the Charge 3, this watch struggles to capture accurate heart rates for me when I am on the elliptical. Maybe it's just me, but nothing I do helps except except if I move the watch up my arm. This then captures much of my session, however, half the session shows a heart rate half of what it actually is.
- I cannot get calendar notifications to work, even though I have that selected. It only notifies me of text messages. I would like it to have calendar notifications so I don't miss meetings or appointments.

The band is now more like the Apple watch band. Not sure of the benefit of this or if it is better or not vs the Charge 3, so I am impartial to that.

Overall a great health tracker, long battery life, easy to read with some smart watch features like viewing text messages and weather warnings. I recommend without any hesitations!!

title: Stopped charging after 10 months of ownership
text:
The good:

- Generally comfortable to wear
- Time between charges holds up to expectations, typically 5-7 days between charging sessions

The acceptable:

- The sleep tracking is a nice reference, but I have no way to understand or know if its classifications (REM, light, deep) are at all trustworthy

The bad:

- Since unboxing, the experience of charging my device has been absolutely miserable. The charger requires an extremely precise orientation and the magnet is not enough to properly seat the watch
- After 10 months of ownership, my device will no longer charge. I have verified voltage across the charger's terminals and measure nothing across the pads of the watch. I have left the charger installed to the watch for multiple days, and the watch is completely powered off.

This is my first Fitbit product, and I was willing to pay the premium that the brand comes with, but I am sorely disappointed that the product hasn't even lasted a year with normal use and no visible damages.

title: Broke twice in 12 months ... but now I'm out of warranty :/
text:
I had two of these. The first died entirely (battery issue) after 4 months. The second died after 6 months of use. And there was about a 2 month gap between the first one dying and the second one arriving. Totaling 12 months and putting a 3rd replacement right out of the warranty period.

I wore it a lot ... like everyday. I usually did not wear it to bed. But when I did, it was interesting to see the sleep analytics.

I mostly wore this to track my milage and pace during running. I think generally it does an okay job with that, but here is where it really fell short (this is with both trackers) ... so this should mitigate getting a dud.

What I liked:

1/ Though I didn't buy the fitbit for this reason, I appreciated the sleep analysis. I don't like wearing watches to bed, so I only did this about once a week. But every time I appreciated the analytics. Are there better tools for that? Probably, but I never used or had access to a product that did this. Do I need it? Not really. I have very little issues with sleep.

2/ Seeing pacing and heart rate while running and doing workouts was pretty cool. I liked the heartrate features.

3/ Hitting goal milestones grants you a little vibrate on the wrist and celebration graphic. I enjoyed these. (Zone minutes / steps / etc.)

4/ Incoming texts without having to check phone. This was nice, but got annoying sometimes because you might have already cleared out all your phone texts ... and your watch texts are still there. So essentially you have to clear them in two places.

What I didn't like:

1/ Standalone GPS drains the battery very fast AND it shuts off after about a mile and says "GPS not found". This sort of screws up tracking.

2/ I never actually saw any maps of my runs. I found this to be frustrating, but I understand why fitbit might not want to do that with the GPS being funky.

3/ I got into swimming a lot after having the fitbit for a month. The fitbit does not track laps :( despite it having a swim setting

4/ It tracks bumpy slow car rides (and motorcycle rides) as massive running steps ... Though I only had a few of those days, I didn't find that to be as much a problem as some of the other issues listed.

There were a few other features like credit card payments via watch, reminders to move if the watch notices you are in a sedentary position too long ... but I never really used these features.

If I had to do it all over again, I would not get one. I paid almost $200 last year for this (price is now down by $50), but I'm just like ... wow. What was I thinking. I recall after it first broke, I went on a camping trip and strapped on my old regular digital watch. I didn't miss the fitbit one bit on that camping trip.

I was super sad when it broke because it was just a few weeks before my first marathon and I thought I was going to be disadvantaged somehow by not having it ... a phone was all I needed to track pace. As a runner, you sort of know how hard to push yourself.

Support is sticking to the 1 year warranty even though the last replacement was only 6 months old. I don't think this is sticking true to the spirit of the piece of products' quality. They offered me a 35% discount on my next fitbit. I won't use it. Just not really worth the money for me.

title: The band will eventually fail catastrophically, releasing the Fitbit.
text:
I've owned two and the band failed on both. The failure point for me was the attach point to the Fitbit device body. When this happens the device will fall off your wrist and, unless you notice it at that exact moment, it will result in you losing the device.

It's a tragic design flaw that makes this device a 1 star when it could have been 5 star. If you get one anyway, pay attention to how the band mounts for the first time, following the instructions provided with the device exactly. If your band is able to be pulled loose with medium pressure, on your new device, send it back, because it will fail quickly.

If your band is solidly attached when the device is new, you're still likely to lose the device later, perhaps in a few months, after you've started to think that yours might be secure. The more active your lifestyle, the more likely it will pop free. If you spend a lot of time swimming, biking, hiking, plan on it coming lose when you least expect it.

title: Beware: Please buy from an authorized Fitbit seller or you could end up with a dud!
text:
This is the third Fitbit smartwatch I have purchased. I bought it on August 29th 2022 from Emily's Store on Amazon. However, by December 20th 2022, the battery began to fail. It started running out of charge in 6 hours. I contacted Amazon and was told that the return window was over. Then I contacted Fitbit and was told that the purchase was from an unauthorized retailer so they could not replace it and that I should contact the retailer. When I contacted Emily's Store, I was told that since it was beyond the warranty period, it could not be returned. I paid over $120 for this, and expected that it would last at least 1 year.

Some pointers for other customers:
1) Before purchasing, please check that the retailer is authorized to sell the product on Amazon. Amazon will not check this for you, so a retailer could sell you a defective product and you will not be able to get your money back if the product fails after the return window. Or, spend some extra money and buy a warranty on Amazon.

2) If you do buy a smartwatch on Amazon, please retain the box in which it came since the box has a unique serial number that nobody will tell you after the purchase- not even Fitbit. I got rid of the box and the retailer asked for the serial number and there was no way of getting the number.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2023

title: Not Perfect - But Pretty Good
text:
I got into weightlifting the beginning of November and decided to get myself a Charge 5. I mostly wanted it for the steps, heart rate, calories, and sleep tracking, so I will start my review based on these features. The steps and heart rate tracking seems to be incredibly accurate. Absolutely no complaints from me here. Calories on the other hand… there’s no question the Fitbit drastically over estimates calories burned from steps. I have a sort of hybrid office job where I’m in the office a lot, but I also have a lot to do around the building as well. The other day, I walked 13,000 steps just from work and it was a rest day so I didn’t work out. My Fitbit tried to claim that between my maintenance calories and steps, I had burned 4000 calories that day. That’s a bit ridiculous. Possibly 3000 but 4000 is most definitely an over estimate and it frequently makes drastic overestimates like this. I will also note that several years ago I lost 60 pounds so I’m pretty familiar with what typical calories out look like for me. I also think it’s important to mention that all fitness trackers have this issue of drastically overestimating calories from steps. It’s just a limitation in the technology currently available. The other thing to mention is the sleep tracking. Overall, it’s great. Recognizes when I fall asleep and seems very accurate. Where it falls short is when I wake up. Let me just give an example of this morning. I woke up to my alarm at 6:30. I got up, put the Fitbit on the charger, and hopped in the shower. I then put my Fitbit back on and proceeded with my morning routine. The Fitbit thought I was still trying to sleep up until 7:20am and counted this in my sleep score as “time awake” at night. It does this nearly every morning. This effects your sleep score by increasing your % of time awake, effectively making your sleep score useless because it’s skyrocketing the minutes spent awake during the night… even though I am very clearly awake for the day and it’s not night any more. Fortunately, I don’t care too much about the score, and I’m more just checking to make sure I got adequate deep sleep for my muscles to recover. But if you are planning on using this to overall grade your sleep and keep track of that, then this is something that would likely be very obnoxious for you.

Otherwise, the watch looks sleek and the band it comes with is comfortable enough where I don’t even notice it most of the time. However, just make sure not to wear the watch too tight or the band definitely can irritate the skin a little.

The last thing I will talk about is some of the watches more “premium” features. Most of these features are locked behind a monthly subscription. Kind of scummy from Fitbit imo to not be clear about that so I thought I would mention it. If you are getting the Fitbit for any of the reasons I did though, the more basic features mentioned above, then this won’t be an issue as these don’t require a subscription. You do get 6 months of this subscription free with the purchase. Can totally understand the subscription for things like the workouts, meal recommendations, community, ect but putting advertised features of the watch in the subscription is a quick way to lose the trust of your customers.

Overall, the watch is great for everything I need and I’m happy with my purchase despite focusing on a lot of the negatives in this review. I just feel I should point them out for others.

title: Band is very difficult to get attached.
text:
It seems Fitbit can’t get a decent design since the Charge 2. I started with a Charge2 and never had any trouble with it, but I broke the crystal and needed a replacement.

Enter the Charge 3. The face was faint but readable. As time went on, the face became more difficult to read. I researched the issue on the Internet and it seems the lack of brightness is a big issue with many. I adjusted the settings to Normal as the article suggested (choice of dark, auto and normal). At its brightest, it still was dim at best. Often I would have to go into settings and choose Normal again and I’d get a more readable display…for awhile. However, one thing was excellent about the Fitbit 3 and that was the ability to easily change bands to a dressier one I purchased. So, enter Charge 5. Readout is big and bright! Looks like they got their problem solved, but this time the band is very hard to attach. I had to research attaching a band on a Charge 5 on the Internet and finally got it to stay on, although they seem slightly loose. Yes, I listened for the little click of the little almost impossible to find button as the article said. Again, this issue is wide spread judging by the questions and complaints. But I went ahead and ordered a dressier version band, received it and cannot get one side to “click” at all, so am returning that and I’ll be stuck with the rubber band it came with, which I was lucky I got to stay on. At least until the poorly designed buttons break off. If they had of just kept the band replacement ease of the Charge 3, then they would have a good product.

I would not recommend the Charge 5. I was generous and gave it 3 stars for the bright display. I wouldn’t recommend the Charge 3 either, if it is still available. This will be my last purchase of a fitbit and will switch to Apple.

title: Really dissapointing
text:
I bought this fitbit mainly to track my steps. My phone step counter is excellent but when I'm doing chores and other things I'm usually not holding my phone so I really wanted a fitbit so it can tell me the calories I'm burning just by doing household to motivate myself to walk more.

I put on the fitbit and set it up and realized that it wasn't counting about 70% of my steps. Where my phone would count 45 steps, the fitbit wouldn't pick up any of them. Where my phone would count 60 steps, the fitbit would pick up 21.

Which this might work for some, I work remotely and find it really hard to get my steps so I need something accurate. If I'm constantly going on these long walks feeling proud of my accomplishment and then I get home and realize I actually didn't hit my goals (or at least I think I didn't because the fitbit doesn't track them) I'd get discouraged and stop actively walking which is why I need something accurate.

The heartbeat feature was spot on. I took my resting heart rate to compare and it was accurate but that's not a good enough product on its own for me.

The premium membership is a bit weird. The stats are all laid out on the app which is great but the perks that you get with the membership are a bit half assed. For example, they give you 1 minute quick video recipes but don't tell you how much of each ingredient to put into the recipe lolll.

I wouldn't get this if I were you. If you want to measure your heart rate just get an oxymeter which is only 15-30 bucks and use your phone for the step counting for the most part.

text:
I used a Charge HR previously and decided to upgrade.
I bought this a few days ago and it came in yesterday. I opened it up, and stuck it on the charger on my PC before trying to pair it with my Samsung Galaxy S10+

1st problem - Had to attempt pairing like 4-5 times before it would actually pair. (see problems 2-4)

2nd problem - App said there was a new software patch for the device (not uncommon) so I went ahead and started the upgrade download. And it kept disconnecting. And now, a day later, it is still dropping the bluetooth signal before it has a chance to fully install the new software.

3rd problem - each time it falters on the install, it then tries to do everything over again from scratch. Meaning that while it says it CAN take 40 minutes to install the new software, I have gotten as far as fully downloading the patch and then going to the install step.... but when it hangs up, locks, or drops signal, I then have to download from step one the next time I attempt the upgrade.

4th problem - The device keeps freezing and locks up completely. I am assuming this is something that the newest patch would fix, but I cannot seem to get the patch downloaded and installed to fix it.

Whose bright idea was it to remove the ability to do a hard manual restart on the device? Sure, you can do it from the charging port, IF you are near it. But I am now at work and have been trying to install this patch on my downtime between classes I teach. So for the last 5 hours it has been stuck and frozen on the progress bar with no ability to restart it.

I cannot recommend this product. I do not know why Fitbit all of a sudden has all these technical issues. But from what I have gathered (and I wish I knew this before I bought it) mine is not out of the ordinary. I am going to try and get this newest patch tonight, but if unable to do so, I will have to return it to amazon and no longer buy fitbit brand trackers.

title: The smell is what ended it for me.
text:
The tracker itself works decently. It counts your steps relatively accurately, as well as your heart rate. Those are the 2 features I relied on the most. The auto workout detection is 50/50, and not so accurate. I stopped caring whether or not the watch detected a workout because it was too much of a hassle to fix it. I just cared that when I did work out my heart rate would get into the cardio zone. Battery life is good, although I recharged my Fitbit every night. I didn't wear when I slept because it was simply too uncomfortable. Watch also worked decently during swims. The touch screen is glitchy when exposed to water, but once it dries off it's back to normal.

The absolute worst part, and what broke the deal for me was the bacteria build-up on the tracker itself (not the silicone band). This, in my opinion, is something Fitbit really needs to work on because it is impossible to disinfect all the tiny crevices surrounding the sensors without dunking it in a bleach solution. If I swim regularly, it's not so bad -- it's when I go several days without swimming and switch to running/jogging that the bacteria gets awful. Even after 2 or 3 days the smell is horrendous. And no, you can't clean it manually. Using a toothbrush and soap isn't enough. Wiping down with alcohol isn't enough. The entire unit needs to sit in disinfectant for several minutes for the smell to go away -- hopefully.

Apparently, this is a problem specific to Fitbit and it doesn't happen with other fitness trackers. We'll see, as I've switched to another brand.

title: Wonderful product, even better customer service
text:
I have to be honest: I was split between Apple watch and Fit-bit Charge 5. There were pros and cons to both products:

1. Apple watch is more holistic product. It's a small cell phone on its own with apps and bells and whistles to it. For example, Apple watch was critical for me because I did not have to carry my phone during running and could just download the songs. It also has call reception and message monitoring features. Fitbit is a no frill device meant to do one thing. Track your health. I already have another analogue watch and actually won't mind not receiving messages and calls while I am exercising so that was a fit-bit plus.

2. Fit-bit is unobtrusive. I can wear it along with my analogue watch without looking like a douche bag (which I would if I kept a health monitor on top of a digital watch. So I like the sleek and minimalistic look of it.

3. The heart rate sensor is a bit on the lower side. I had few measurements with my doctor and it seems the detector shows a bit of lesser values. But that's just my impressions.

4. The footsteps are pretty accurate. Also the app shows very good monitoring of daily active minutes, mileage and other thing.

Finally the best part was when my Fit-bit broke, despite being out of warranty, I got a new replacement. Excellent customer service. So I am keeping it

title: Deal breaker GPS Sync Issues
text:
The Fitbit charge 5 has a lot of strengths. Found the battery life to be more than adequate, the display was easy to read in a variety of conditions, and I felt like it accurately tracked heart rate.

However, there were some unacceptable issues with hardware failures and in particular, the design of synchronization with social fitness apps like Strava.

The Fitbit would occasionally not just drop its own connection to GPS, but getting the GPS information from the phone it was hooked up too. In the middle of high stress workout there was no way to notice this was happening. Even if you did, there was no way to resync the watch on the phone. Each GPS mode produced failures, wiping out 20 or 30 mi bike rides that I've been preparing for and trying to track.

When I realized I couldn't trust the GPS, I was still interested in keeping the Fitbit. I would use the sleep tracking and heart rate tracking, but trust the GPS from Strava to track my workouts. Workouts. Unfortunately, Fitbit has removed the ability to treat the charge as a simple heart rate monitor for other applications. So now I was maintaining and charging another device, which would only track 9 out of 10 workouts reliably, that I was willing to use the secondary features for, but it would refuse to send that information anywhere else.

Forums and customer service posts boiled down to "pound sand".

There's other problems too. The user interface during a workout isn't particularly helpful. I don't mind some contextual notifications about what zone I'm in, those are actually helpful. Defaulting to something with time is really unforgivable when it comes to something that should really start as a watch.

All in all, if you're a big Strava user or biker I really wouldn't suggest this heart rate tracker.

title: No battery notifications and not Apple compatible
text:
Charge 5 seems to be a step up in many ways. The display is actually visible which is a big change over the Charge 4, however, the battery just dies with no warnings and that is super annoying. Went for a walk today and realized after I started that my Fitbit was completely dead. Apple Watch would have been a much better purchase but I thought I'd give Fitbit a try again since I like the smaller footprint. Step count and exercise tracking isn't much better than the Charge 4 was and often fails to recognize exercise or has the wrong durations if it does track it. Mobile app still has lots of trouble syncing data and generally takes at least a couple of tries.

Also, if you are an Apple user I would avoid Fitbit as they are not very compatible. The instructions from Fitbit are to leave the app running all of the time, which is NOT something that Apple devices allow. You can leave it open in standby mode but it won't actually be running and will restart every time you open it either way. Also, apps that are left open in iOS will be closed by the system if you don't do it manually. The system design actually pushes users to close apps regularly so unless you want to spend quite a bit of effort fighting against the device design I'd look at Apple Watch, which is obviously designed to be used with Apple devices.

I finally gave up on Fitbit altogether because not only of the issues noted above but also because the device has a lot of random useless "apps" built in and the device quite often gets stuck on a screen for payments or notifications and there doesn't appear to be any way to get out of it (swiping is disabled on these screens apparently). I'll eventually buy an Apple Watch, I just didn't want to spend the extra money but Fitbit is pretty unreliable if you are using it with an iPhone.

title: Overall, a good watch but it does have two serious flaws
text:
I've been a Fitbit user for years and I really do like it. Before I got one, I was one of those sporadic exercisers who would start up and then quit a few months later. Fitbit gives me the incentive to exercise 5 or 6 days a week. I started out several years ago when I switched over from a very active patient care job to a computer job. I like the work but it's totally sedentary. I knew I needed to incorporate more walking into my daily routine if I was going to remain slender and healthy.

Once I started working from home during the pandemic, I needed to ramp up my walking routine. I really don't move much during the workday. I'm 62 and my formerly slender figure was becoming doughy from being immobile behind the computer. So, I decided to get even more serious about walking regularly. I bought a treadmill to keep at home and I get on it every morning before work. I try and take a walk after dinner as well to make up for the lack movement during my workday.

I upgraded to the Charge 5 a few months ago because my previous Charge 3 was getting old. It was really hard to see the screen when I was outdoors in the sunlight. The Charge 5 has a bright, colored screen that is easier for my old eyes to see.

One of my favorite features of the Charge is their notification feature-
I usually have my cell phone stashed away in my purse and I don't always hear it. I like that the Fitbit alerts me when I get a call or text. I also use it to track my sleep hours and quality. You'd think at my age I'd know enough to go to bed on time, but I get engrossed in other things. The sleep feature helps me to stay on track.

The two biggest disappointments I've had with the Charge 5 are:
My old charge 3 had a very strong notification buzzer (it had two settings so users could select a stronger or weaker buzz). I liked it on the stronger one. This one doesn't have that option. Oddly enough, the default on the Charge 5 started out strong like my old Fitbit so I was happy but once I updated it, the notification is now weaker buzz. Nothing I can't live with, but I wish they'd give us the choice again.

The more serious flaw is this:
I love that I only have to charge the battery once a week on the Chart 5 and it's easier to attach than their old clip. However, several times I've had the battery totally discharge way before it was due to be low. I had to go to their website to try and troubleshoot. Nobody really knew why so I ended up disabling a few features that I don't use often. I'm hoping that solves the issue. If it keeps happening, I'm going to end up buying a different product so I'm hoping Fitbit gets this resolved soon.

title: Great device carrying bloatware
text:
The Charge 5 is a really wonderful device. The form factor and user interface are great. I have been using it for 6 months on a daily basis in heat, cold and wet environments and it has held up wonderfully.
The touch screen is good - I would like the touch sensitivity to be a little smoother and consistent. Sometimes touches render feedback and then no feedback 5 minutes later. Also the automatic screen on is inconsistent.
The device interface is poor. The navigation is not intuitive and, while it has some really wonderful functionality and options, finding and utilizing them is a real struggle (forget trying to interact with the device while you're working out). Fitbit has also included a minimally functional payment app that has a limited number of financial institutions it supports. If the user's bank is not supported or the user simply wants to delete the app, it is not an option and you will constantly have to scroll through a useless app to use the watch.
The mobile app is fair. The navigation is not super intuitive and there are options, functions and features what can get lost to the user unless you invest allot of time figuring out the app. They could definitely do better here. The Premium features are very interesting and do provide some interesting trend analysis regarding trends in measurements of things like SPO2 and resting heart rate. There are also workouts, stretching and meditation programs which are good.
Overall the device would get 4-5 stars if not for the bloatware.

title: Overall good fitness tracker with major caveats- see below
text:
It has most major features you'd expect and can read about in other reviews. The ECG function is surprisingly good (it produces an interpretable 1-lead ECG), but has little day-to-day value barring having an arrhythmia. The important caveats are as follows:
1. There is no altimeter. For those used to tracking stairs/elevation change while hiking with Fitbits, that is impossible. I had read somewhere that it would estimate stairs based on GPS elevation data - this is NOT true - it will not attempt any kind of stair tracking at all.
2. If you don't want to give Fitbit your card/bank info for Fitbit Wallet, you'll have the distinct pleasure of getting a vibrating reminder that they want you to add a card every time you open the app to sync. To date, there is no way to disable this reminder.

Other than that, it's good at what it does, nothing mind-blowing but tracks what I want it to. If you're upgrading from another Fitbit device, it's fairly intuitive, though the screen interaction is a little different and takes some getting used to.

title: Not accurate for sleep
text:
This is my second fitbit and definitely less buggy than the previous one, particularly when it comes to synching, but still far from perfect. If it was accurate it would be probably my favorite device in the whole world, but unfortunately it's not.

Pros:
- good for keeping you accountable, showing number of workouts, their length and intensity
- can give you a very very rough idea of time to fall asleep and potentially number of awakenings, although that's very approximate and the elaborate charts and detailed analysis of sleep phases are quite misleading because the data is wrong.

Cons:
- unfortunately sleep tracking is not accurate at all. For example it routinely shows that I am asleep when I am watching TV - this alone says something about it's ability to go deeper and show different sleep phases, etc. That's pure fantasy. It can't tell the REM and light sleep from just laying awake and tossing or even getting up. I brought it up in a conversation with my sleep doctor and he told me that Fitbit same as other consumer sleep trackers just don't have the right sensors to do detect sleep phases, so shouldn't pay any attention to what it's showing there. From my own observation I tend to trust the 'deep sleep' reading a little bit more, meaning when it shows that I was in 'deep sleep' I read this 'most likely asleep' or at least not moving much.
- app is pretty buggy, which is frustrating considering that it's been around for a while. Often needs to be restarted to get the charts to update, also gets out of whack if Bluetooth gets turned off and on again. Little things but quite annoying.

title: Startlingly Inaccurate Tracking
text:
I'll try to keep this brief and I'll start with a disclaimer: there's a chance the Fitbit Charge 5 I received was just a dud. I returned it to Amazon but I'm not planning on buying another based on my experience, even if I did just have a defective unit.

The heart rate tracking just isn't good enough for the kind of exercise I do on a daily basis. I imagine more casual users who do steady-state cardio occasionally will be served just fine by the Charge 5, but that just isn't me. My favorite types of workouts involve HIIT and Interval runs, Peloton's Walk+Run classes, and strength training. For those types of workouts, the Charge 5 was simply an unreliable disaster.

The first time I did a HIIT run wearing the Charge, I was just confused and frustrated because every time I looked down to check my heart rate (already knowing it had to be peaking because of how I felt) it would be nowhere close to the number I expected. To confirm my suspicion, I started doing workouts wearing the Charge 5 with either the Peloton heart rate monitor or my Apple Watch series 7. After doing some strength classes, and more interval work, I confirmed with data what I had suspected: the Charge 5 can not accurately measure heart rates that change quickly.

The reading on the Fitbit was always a couple minutes behind where I actually was, or it was just far off from my true heart rate (usually reading much lower--at times around 40 bpm off). I tried changing wrists, adjusting the fit, and even a hard reset. On dog walks the tracking seemed to be much more accurate, but as someone who wants to track actual exercise and not just casual, everyday walks, this doesn't win the Charge 5 any points. If it can't reliably track my heart rate while I do the exercises I love to do, the tracker is useless to me. That means that it's not accurately calculating calories burned, and the data will be useless to me over time to track trends. I like to repeat certain HIIT runs or strength classes to see how I'm improving over time. I can't do that with data from the Charge 5 because the data was reliably incorrect.

I also have a bone to pick with the daily readiness score Fitbit provides. I've been wearing an Oura ring gen 3 for 10 months every day. It knows me well, and I trust its own readiness scores when it comes to accuracy and reliability. For the week plus change that I tested the Charge 5, I had the Fitbit app tell me multiple days in a row that my readiness score was at a 1. Out of 100. Essentially advocating that I stay bedridden to recover. On those same days, my Oura readiness score was in the high 80s, which accurately reflected how I felt and how I trained on those days. The Fitbit was telling me I was exhausted beyond movement, and the Oura was telling me to go ahead full-steam. I listened to the Oura and was absolutely fine. I don't know if the Fitbit daily scores get better over time, but I just don't see how my readiness score could have been so close to the absolute lowest score possible when in reality I felt great. Baffling, and useless considering that eventually it becomes a paid feature.

Overall I'm just so disappointed. I don't understand how these things have a cult-like following. They just aren't accurate trackers. The data is wrong and often. How are you supposed to know how you're improving if you can't look at a workout and trust the data it collected? For me it defeats the entire purpose of a fitness tracker. So I sent it back assuming it was a lemon. But the whole experience was so sour that I won't be coming back for more.

title: Terrible Customer Support, frequently won't connect, inaccurate heart rate
text:
I owned every Fitbit Charge model since they first came out, but the Charge 5 will be my last. I have three major complaints:

Terrible Customer Support: The screen on my Charge 5 died. Fitbit Customer Service said I needed to send them a video of the Charge 5 showing the dead screen. Then after I created a video and emailed it, I got no response from Fitbit. I called back and was told that they couldn't view the video I sent because it was too big to be sent as an attachment and was sent as a link to a file on Google. Apparently, Fitbit restricts reps from accessing Google stored files. I was told that the case would be escalated but several days later after hearing nothing from Fitbit, I called back. I was told that I had to send in a video as an email attachment before Fitbit would consider the claim. I was quite upset at that point as I explained the problem. The Fitbit rep threatened to hang up on me because she said I was shouting, even though my language was civil. Still the bottom line with the rep was that I had to send in a video as an attachment before my warranty request would be considered. I made another video, this time only 20 seconds long but the file size still exceeded the 25 MB limit required to be sent as an email attachment. So I downloaded a video editing program, learned how to use it, and was able to reduce the resolution of the 20 second video file so that it was within the 25 MB that could be sent as an email attachment. After all of that trouble, I got an email that my replacement request had been approved and I later received my warranty replacement. One of the worst customer experiences I've ever had with a company.

Frequently the Charge 5 stops connecting to the app. It has gone several days without connecting. The last time after a week of not connecting, I did everything I could think of to get it to reconnect, but it would not connect. I turned Bluetooth off/on, removed/added the device to the app, and tried connecting with my tablet instead of my phone. Nothing worked. It finally reconnected after I uninstalled/reinstalled the app. Right now, as I'm writing this review, I again can't get the Charge 5 to connect to any of my devices, which prompted me to write this review.

Finally, there is the problem with the heart rate accuracy. Sometimes, it is accurate, as I have compared the HR measured by the Charge 5 to a chest strap monitor, but it is frequently much lower than the chest strap monitor. I've found that both Garmin and Polar have more accurate wrist HR monitors than the Charge 5. HR accuracy has always been a problem with the Charge models, and I expected it to improve with the Charge 5 but it has not.

I'm not sure what my next fitness tracker will be but it will certainly not be a Fitbit.

title: I Wish I Could Give This Less Than One Star; USELESS!
text:
I purchased this device and am returning it one day later. The Charge 5 is an absolute P.O.S. To start with, it took 13 attempts to get paired to my phone (no exageration). After that, it took over 3 hours for it to update (and no, the problem is not with my internet). I had hopes for it at first after I finally got it running. However, it continually dropped the connection with my phone, and I had to re-pair them. I tried it on a second phone, and the same problem persisted.

I figured I would give it a legitimate try, but the problems continued. I had it set to battery saving as much as I could; internal GPS and whatnot were all turned off. Fitbit claims it lasts "up to 7 days." I barely got one day out of a full charge. I had the Always On display turned off, set to auto so that I came on briefly when I turned my wrist to look at it. This worked sporadically at best, and that is being generous. I found that I had to shake my wrist to get the thing to turn on. So, that aspect did not work either. I also found that I had to jab my finger at the screen multiple times to get it to wake up. No, it was not it Sleep Mode for this.

I used the Sleep Mode overnight. This seems to have worked pretty well as what it showed me on the app lined up with what I experienced overnight. This is the only good thing I can say about the device.

The heart rate monitor was completely off. From what it was showing me, I was on the verge of death. I compared it with a Polar chest strap that I trust. The data from the two devices were far apart.

Step counts...... It was counting around ten steps--give or take--for each step I took. I put it on the charger the next morning with around 1500 steps on it. When I came back to it, the device has magically gained another 500 steps while it was sitting idle. It was counting steps while I was on the toilet also.

The Charge 5 is complete junk. Add all of these problems to Fitbit hiding all the features most people really buy it for behind a paywall. Yes, it's good that you get six months of Premium free, but what after that? If you are not going to have access to and use everything it does, then why pay the $80 per year? It is inaccurate for use even as a very basic step step counter. Don't waste your money on this. I should have heeded the reviews, and now I have to deal with trying to return it. It lasted one day before I set up the return.

text:
I bought this Fitbit Charge 5 based on positive experiences with earlier models. Though the earlier ones worked great, I’m fairly active and “tore them up” within a year or two. Consequently, I purchased the extended warranty.

DON’T PURCHASE THIS PLAN! Several months after purchasing the extended warranty, I received an email indicating my plan had been transferred to the new device owner. After calling Allstate’s number, I was told someone in my household likely sold it, and the new owner had indeed filed a claim. I explained I lived alone, still used the device, and had not authorized a transfer of the warranty to another person. Thereafter, Allstate’s representative explained she’d transferred the warranty back into my name and cancelled the claim.

In response, I explained I had not cancelled the warranty or received a refund. Additionally I asked for proof of payment. Thereafter, the representative placed me on hold, then came and indicated they would send me a check for the purchase price.

title: I just really like it
text:
What I like most about the Fitbit Charge 5 is how easily it integrated into my life. I'm pretty active between young kids, 3x/week Ice Hockey, and regular strength and conditioning work. I'm also what is known as an, "aging tryhard." At 42, I've had to consider things for the first time like sleep quality and rest days. This device gives me insights on what my metrics are telling me in an, "explain it to me like I'm 5", way that allows me to react and plan in about 5 minutes every day. I wear it during my games and, after starting to wear wrist bands to stop my goalie gloves from stopping the workouts, have never had an issue with it. It's gone in pools, lakes, and oceans with me and nary a problem has popped up.

The only downsides would be it's a bit lame that the features I like the most are behind a premium pay wall. I'll pay for it when my trial membership expires, but I'm envious the my wife doesn't have that issue with her Garmin. It also no longer has connectivity with Spotify which is annoying, but that's me just being petty.

If you're on the fences and don't want to drop $300 on an Apple Watch I say go for it. It does what it says and a bit more. Also, it's not my money. Buy a fancy Apple Watch if you want, but think of all the apple fritters you could've bought with that money instead...

title: The sleep-tracking is great. If only the whole product were as good as this.
text:
So I am looking at this product through a specific lens: as a possible Apple Watch replacement. I lost my Apple Watch, and thought maybe I could replace it with a device that offered me a longer battery life in exchange for many features I would not miss (I really don’t need the weather forecast on my wrist).
So, here is the great:
The battery lasts at least 5 days (I never let it run down all the way, so I do not know the full battery life). This is great. Unlike with my Apple Watch, which needed a charge by the end of every day, I can wear the Fitbit to sleep, and get sleep tracking data. Great. Huge. Very helpful. And this is worth the price of admission.
The good:
It’s a Fitbit, so naturally it does a great job hunting steps, reminding me to move, etc. As a GPS for recording bike rides, it does an adequate job, although it doesn’t seem quite as accurate as the Apple Watch’s. But whatever.
The disappointing:
Unlike my Apple Watch, it does not have the low-power always-on screen mode, so if I need to tell the time, it needs to sense me wrist twist. It successfully senses the wrist twist about 25% of the time. So, as a conventional time-telling watch, it’s pretty poor. Here’s a small one: like the Apple Watch, if I need to locate my phone, it has the feature to “find” the phone by making it sound. But unlike the Apple Watch’s version, which just works, the Fitbit’s works about a third of the time. Usually it reports that the watch is not nearby, even though it then turns out to be within arms’ length.
The annoying: As a matter of policy, it will not send to Strava workouts that do not include GPS data. So, if I workout on the treadmill and with weights, etc, the Fitbit records a workout with heart rate data that I can view as a workout in the Fitbit app, but since there is no GPS data, it will not upload it to Strava. People post indoor workouts, stationary bike rides, etc to Strava all the time. But not with a Fotbit apparently.
The confounding:
As I understand it, if the Fitbit loses connectivity with my phone during a workout, it will stop logging GPS data for the entire workout?So for example, if I want to run laps and I start the workout near my bag, which has my phone in it, and then during the course of running, unexpectedly go out of range of my bag (who could possibly see that coming?), the Fitbit records the workout without GPS data. This, you guessed it, makes it unwilling to upload this workout to Strava, of course. Sure, makes sense. I guess?
The deal-breaker:
Playing soccer
Road biking
Showering
Sleeping
Reaching for something in a pants pocket
Crossing my arms
Looking at the time
What do all of these activities have in common? All of them have caused the Fitbit to fall off of my wrist. The mechanism that connects the Fitbit to the wrist strap is not ready for public consumption. It is flimsy at best. I am told by my Fitbit-loving friend that this is an anomaly and I should send it back. I will.

The verdict: This feels like a product that has successfully completed beta testing, but not much more that that.This does not feel like a product mature enough to have a 5 as part of its name.
I am returning this device and will most likely get a new Apple Watch, and look for a small, unobtrusive companion device for sleep tracking. Blech.
