title: At Best, Accuracy In The Ball Park
text:
As a former endurance athlete, now in my early seventies, a few issues have arisen, and after testing, upon consultation with my physician, he said it would be of benefit to get my heart rate up on a consistent basis.
Living fairly remote in the Northwoods, it was pretty easy to strap on snowshoes and cross country skis, and recently I have dragged out my old mountain bike. OK, so what’s my heart rate? Am I in target zones? Am I approaching my max? I really don’t need to keep track of my steps, as I know I’m covering a lot of ground each day when I’m out with the hounds, and I certainly don’t need to know any of the other functions on the FitBit such as sleep or my hearts electrical activity, in particular as the heart rate function is pretty general.

Let’s just say that the heart rate function hits the broad side of the barn. The interface with my phone and pad work well, and it’s easy to retrieve data from the FitBit app, but there have been times either during more strenuous activity such as long climbs on a mountain bike, or causally walking (everything is up and down here with rarely a level foot placement), where I know the accuracy is off just by taking my pulse, but the FitBit does well when showing general trends. The graphics via the FitBit app are more than adequate.

Bottom line, if you want to keep track of your steps and mileage, this product is adequate. For accuracy of one’s heart rate it may keep you in the ballpark. However, if the user wants much more exact data in particular in regard to heart rate, the apparatus falls short.

My bike computer is a smart GPS computer so I don't use the GPS on the Fitbit to track rides (I want to save battery not using on running GPS chip).... but.... it seems to count most pedal revolutions as steps, so the first long ride I did I got a reward badge for walking 13 miles... huh... It counted revolutions as steps and guessed at how far I walked based on steps or time, hence the 13 mile walk badge... double huh... Other rides are similar.. I get step credit, even when entering a cycling mode on the tracker, for riding. It's pretty easy to get 30.000 steps credit for a long bike ride. When I select weight lifting mode for a workout, it tracks calories but I don't have any sense of how accurate that is vs just monitoring heart rate. title: Poor out of box experience, Spo2 issues
text:
I occasionally try Fitbit devices, even after past frustrating issues with their software ecosystem. In this case, I was looking for a device to replace my iWatch, in particular the health metric functionality. What I was looking for is a device with good battery life, without all the constant alerts and other funk the iWatch inflicts on its users.

The Charge 5 looked to fit the bill: inexpensive, provides the health data collection I wanted, had an App to present the data. One downside is the apparent need to sign up for an expensive membership, but I figured I'd give it a year and let the Fitbit ecosystem prove its value.

The trouble started almost immediately when I unboxed the device and went through the initial setup. Total PTSD, from previous attempts to use Fitbit hardware & software. Here, the device kept failing to perform the initial software update. When I hit the support boards, it was clear that many others had been bitten by this, Fitbit support saying (for 6 months plus) that their team is working the issue, and the usual voodoo medicine Rx from other users about reboot iPhone, reboot Fitbit, delete Bluetooth association, Rekki massage, crystal therapy, accupuncture, and so so. I tried various folk remedies, and after about 1.5 hours of effort got the software update on the device. The morning after, I noticed that the device wasn't presenting Spo2. Cripes! So again, off to support, and the same-old, same-old non remedies. Supposedly Spo2 won't display in some countries (go try to find out which ones), advice about getting timezone, region set properly (the devices does this automatically, so why present that as a problem resolution, Fitbit??). Here again, after some tinkering and praying to the almighty god of tech, Spo2 shows up. Who knows, but if we click out to 30k feet, I ask myself what Fitbit Product Owner, and Product Manager allows a flawed software stack and/or device like this one to ship in the first place. I was this >< close to shipping the thing back to Big Jeff at Amazon, and foreswearing Fitbit for another 5 years.

So he's the elevator pitch on this device: if you're cool with spending time debugging the stuff the software team *should* have in their test cases, by all means, go for it. The device may work eventually, just sort out the issue before the return window closes. If you expect a more "Apple" experience, literally run away from the Fitbit ecosystem, or less dramatically, the Charge 5. I should have done my more thorough diligence before I hit the purchase button, but Amazon has us so spoiled with returns, I regularly seem to shoot my toes off buying things that aren't ready for primetime (like Charge 5) and returning them. I hope Amazon keeps track of this sort of return and brings some pressure to bear on Fitbit.

Update: I did end up returning the Charge 5. The Charge 5 wouldn't sync to my iPhone, even when the iPhone was inches away from the Charge 5 on my wrist. I give up. I'll stick with my Apple watch. I hope this was just a bad device, but again looking at the support forums, I see many reports of sync issues. I'd rather be exercising than debugging this thing. Sorry, Fitbit, a big miss here.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2022

title: Love my Fitbit!
text:
Let me preface by saying that I’ve owned just about every Fitbit the company has made, dating back to at least 2013–maybe earlier—but I can’t recall.

Anyway, the Charge 5 is perfect for me. I was actually talked into buying an Apple Watch, and for about 2 weeks, my C5 stayed on my nightstand. Then I wore both for several months. Now I’m back to the C5 only. This is mainly about battery life. I can go almost a whole week without charging it, and when I do, I can plug it in while in the car and get a lot of battery in a short period of time.

This alleviates the need to remove the watch EVERY NIGHT, like the Apple Watch, and leave it on a charger at night and forget it at home when you leave in the morning. Can you tell this has happened to me—multiple times?? And if you’re like me, it’s a serious addiction to keep these fitness trackers on. So forgetting it causes a lot of anxiety.

Also, I’m not super tech savvy, so I don’t need all the bells and whistles of the Versa, the other high end FB, or the Apple Watch. I can screen my calls, read my texts, and set alarms/reminders. It’s all I need. And I wear it in the shower. I wear it in the pool. It’s been banged up too and it is still going strong. If I decide to use more features, they are there if I need them, which is nice.

Now, only time will tell because I’ve had issues in the past with quality and had to use the warranty with multiple devices. I’ve had the C5 for 6 months maybe. Maybe a year? I can’t remember. But I love that the charger is magnetic and not a clip as almost all the previous FBs are.

Overall, you won’t be disappointed, I promise!

The text feature is slow, it might take hours to show a text received after I'd already read it on my phone, and hasn't worked at all in probably 6 months.
Recently the watch will pair to my phone's bluetooth but won't connect to the app long enough to transfer data. Fitbit has apparently been aware of this issue since shortly after release and still haven't found a solution. They give a variety of "possible fixes" but most just involve restarting phone/watch/app and are of no real help. title: So much potential
text:
Tl;dr The Charge 5 could be great, but fitbit won't allow it and the measurements are very suspect for me.

The Charge 5 has a lot of potential, however, Fitbit has crippled the device, and the application. For starters, the sensors. The Charge 5 has both an SpO2 sensor and a body temperature sensor. However, the device doesn't make full use of them. You cannot take a real-time SpO2 reading or temperature reading. You can't even access the information in the app or online account. SpO2 is given as high and low averages which isn't helpful at all. You don't have a reference percentage so the averages really don't provide useful information. The same goes for the temp readings. The application only tells you fluctuations in your average temperature, but not what the actual reading is. To top it off, the measurements are only taken when you're asleep which is useless for fitness tracking. The ability to still actual data, and take real-time on-demand measurements would vastly improve the usefulness of the device.

Sleep tracking isn't accurate for me. It consistently records time awake as either light sleep or rem sleep. There were a few nights where I was in bed awake, TAKING AN ECG READING OR USING THE FITBIT APP and the following morning the device registered that time as being in either light sleep or deep sleep. If the device can't differentiate between being actively used and the user being asleep it makes a lot of the other sleep readings suspect. There are also times during the night when I've awoken, gotten out of bed for awhile and returned and they're not logged as time being awake. I've tried to adjust the sleep sensitivity and it makes no difference. If I am in bed reading before going to sleep the device will track the inactive period between getting into bed and falling asleep as actually being asleep. To its credit it does show it as being restless sleep, but still inaccurately recorded as being asleep.

The EDA sensor feature requires the user to pinch the sides of the Charge 5 for 3 minutes in order to take a reading. That's a really long time when you're trying to pinch something that small and hold still. By the end of every scan my fingers and/or wrist were cramped. The device must be worn while scanning so holding it comfortably in your hand isn't an option.

The mobile application is confusing to navigate. It shows metrics on a dashboard, which may be helpful for some users, but in order to find detailed information you have to dig around for it. The settings are not intuitive and there are an extremely limited amount of options for clock faces, about 24 of them. There is no real app support for the device, only the handful of fitbit branded apps that are available through the app. The fitbit SDK doesn't support the Charge series so creating your own apps or clock faces isn't an option.

There are a few 3rd party mobile applications (for Android at least, not sure about iPhone) that allow you to collect and analyze your data in much more meaningful ways, but still are not very helpful. To their credit Fitbit does allow users to download their raw data from their account, but in doing so I've noticed that a lot of data is missing. Sleep data is hit or miss, as is heart rate data. This is doing a complete archive export and viewing the json files, so the data should be there, but isn't. I can see it on the app, and in my account dashboard so it exists, but just isn't being provided.

Activity tracking isn't very accurate. I bike to work every day and most days those commutes are not tracked unless I manually tell the device that I'm about to start a biking workout. The minimum length of time that can be set for auto-tracking activities is 10 minutes with the default being 15. If I am pedaling fast, or not slowed down by traffic, my bike commute can be less than 10 minutes. But even when going for a ride in the evening that lasts an hour or more the device doesn't always track that I'm biking. When activities are not tracked it affects the daily readiness score, which looks are previous activities, combined with sleep, to calculate how ready for the day you are. Lacking actual data on activities, and suspect sleep tracking data, the readiness score is rather meaningless.

This may be an accurate device for some people, but for me it just isn't. The fact that fitbit intentionally cripples devices and makes analyzing your own data incredibly difficult suggests that maybe this isn't the best company to buy a product from if you want to be in control of what you see. That may be fine for some users. I'll be returning the Charge 5 because it doesn't meet my needs and isn't very well supported. Perhaps I'll try the Versa 3 or Sense since they are better supported, but the lack of data analyses tools is a big impediment to taking the devices seriously.

title: Finally a daylight readable display!
text:
This is the third Fitbit I've owned. I started with a Fitbit Charge 2, then Charge 3, and now the Charge 5.

PROS: The best thing about the Fitbit Charge 5 is its display. It's the first Fitbit I've owned where the display can be read in even the brightest daylight. I don't care whatsoever that it's a color display. I'm simply happy to be able to use my watch to tell time again outdoors.

The next best thing about it (and all of the Fitbits) is the mobile app and website. I find these both to be well-designed and intuitive.

While other reviewers seem to disagree, I've found most of the basic measurements (steps, heart rate, sleep tracking, and minutes of exercise) seem to be accurate and consistent with other devices I own.

The ECG seems accurate as well. Though, here I have no other device with which to compare it.

I get about 8 days of battery life. However, this is with GPS disabled (out of privacy concerns).

All of the above reasons (and mostly the display) are why I've given it four stars.

CONS: First, the four-star rating is based on what matters most to me. A rating that includes things that matter less would drop this device to a three-star or even two-star rating.

The worst thing about this device is the lack of a physical button (or even a capacitive button) on the side of the watch. Because of this, you are limited to wrist rotation that works most of the time, swipes that often work, and taps that are often unreliable.

Allegedly, the watch is supposed to return to your chosen clock face with two rapid taps. In my experience, this works infrequently. I've literally sat there tapping the watch dozens of times without it doing so. This is far and away the most irritating thing about this watch.

Notifications on this watch are hit or (mostly) miss. About 25% of the time I get a phone call or text the watch correctly notifies me. The other 75% of the time these notifications are lost in the ether :)

The watch band that it comes with is horrible. Regrettably, the selection of replacement bands is only slightly better. I found one I can live with, but don't like. Also, the latching mechanism for the bands is far less secure than on previous versions of the Fitbit Charge. Even with the factory original band, I have some degree of difficulty getting it to latch. With at least one third-party band, it would not latch AT ALL.

When I first received this watch, the ECG feature would not work. It kept requesting I (Bluetooth) pair my device with my phone (which was already done). After an annoying call with Fitbit customer service, I was informed that I needed to wait 72 hours before the ECG would work. I don't mind the 72-hour wait. I do mind that this is not documented anywhere and that the error message says nothing about waiting.

The EDA scan gives me a number. The number may be accurate. It may not. Since there is no quantitative description of what numbers are good or bad, it seems somewhat useless to me.

The few clock faces (24) that are available are mostly terrible. They waste the limited real estate available on the face of the watch and distract with ill-chosen, poorly matching colors. Unlike the crisp, clean presentation of the website and mobile app, these clock faces seem designed by a three-year-old, with a short attention span, and a poor sense of color.

If you've come to rely on the stair counting from previous Fitbit Charge devices, this is gone. With the Charge 2, I previously like this feature. It gave a somewhat accurate count of stairs. With Charge 3, the number was so inaccurate, that it would sometimes register stairs as I walked across a flat room. I'm guessing rather than fix this bug, they decided to simply jettison the feature,

FINAL THOUGHTS: Overall, I'm comparatively happy with this watch. I desperately wish they would bring back the button on the side (or make the ECG/EDA sensors serve double duty as a capacitive button). Failing that, I hope that a future firmware update fixes the double-tapping gesture so that it actually works. I really hope that Fitbit hires a competent graphics designer for future clock faces. The current crop of faces (with one or two exceptions) is laughably bad. That, and it might be nice if they better documented the newer features (ECG/EDA) instead of leaving their users guessing.

title: Many fitness apps in one!
text:
This app eliminates the need for the Apple Health app, for fitness apps, and for diet/food logging apps. It’s exercise videos are actually good. HIIT, spinning, cardio, cardio dance, weight training, yoga, and more. Pretty much anything you can follow along to in a video for exercise, Fitbit has it, so no more searching YouTube for videos, and the Fitbit is smart and measures all your vitals while you workout from a video in the app.

One of the coolest feature is the auto-recognition of various different types of exercises and the many graphs that it provides both during workouts and for day-long periods on various health data. I’ve been using it for nearly a month and the more data it has, the better and better it gets at calculating things like your metabolism, calories burned, exercise readiness, and other things.

The sleep feature is really interesting. I don’t know how it works, but every night it generates data and graphs on your sleep, breaking it up into total hours asleep vs awake, light sleep, deep sleep, and REM sleep. Really interesting!

In the Premium version there are a lot of pre-made health programs you can shows to participate in that each target a different health behavior. Some are only a week long while others can be many weeks long. They help you form new healthy habits through educational material and prompting.

Overall this is the most useful AI that I’ve ever had. Very much worth the cost!

There are occassional errors. Examples:

title: Accurate at times; laughably erroneous at others. How to tell the difference?
text:
The Fitbit Charge5 offers a host of body measurements to help you keep healthy, but many are experimental or poorly measured, leaving considerable doubt about their utility. In some ways this “watch” is a step backward, as my 20-year-old Casio shows me the time (date and elevation) continuously (no need to tap the Casio to see the display), is easily read in bright sunlight (good luck with the Fitbit), is waterproof, and it never needs charging.
What the Fitbit adds is motion detection (it counts the swinging of your arms as you walk and calls them “steps”) and heartbeat rate (measured optically from the periodic widening of your arteries). Walking is really good for you, especially as you age, as it maintains bone density and promotes blood flow and healing. Couch potatoes impair their health, especially over the long run; the Fitbit might motivate you to keep moving to keep healthy. The main flaw in this device is that it treats almost any arm motion as equivalent to walking. I get hundreds or even thousands of “steps” from arm motions when I’m not walking; for example, grating cheese, or varnishing boards. Driving on some dirt roads are often credited as “steps”. In aggregate, my Charge5 has awarded me 15,000 “steps” in a single day for activities that I did without shaking a leg.
But what really sticks in my craw is the Fitbit’s misreading of heartbeats. How do I know that it is a misreading? After all, I can easily see the number of steps I take in a day, but heartbeats are not so readily counted. I set the Charge5’s screen to one of the choices that allows me to see the heartbeat rate anytime I turn the screen on; then over many weeks I repeatedly bicycled two 5+ mile rides, one on pavement and the other a gravel road. Both include 10% grades, uphill and down, and I took note of the reported heartbeat rate. Much of the time the graphs shown in the Fitbit app corresponded to what I observed throughout the ride, but occasionally the graphs were wildly in error. I reported the problem to Fitbit and they unhesitating gave me a new watch, but the new watch makes the same mistakes. I conclude that their sensors are just not up to the task.
Fitbit groups heartbeat rates into four classes, which correspond closely with my physical exertions: 1) resting, 2) active but not breathing hard (e.g. walking on the flats: Fitbit calls this “fat burning”), 3) breathing vigorously (pedaling steeply uphill; Fitbit calls it the “cardio” zone), and 4) gasping for breath (working harder than my body can sustain: “peak”). “Fat-burning” is mildly beneficial for cardiac conditioning and therefore Fitbit awards 1 “zone-minute” for each actual minute spent with a heartbeat that is 40-59% of the way from one’s personal minimum (measured from your resting rate) to one’s personal maximum (calculated from your age). “Cardio” is the zone above that, 60-84% of the way from your personal minimum to your personal maximum, and peak is the zone above 84%. The Charge5 awards you 2 “zone-minutes” for each minute you spend above 60%, but it notes that time spent above 84% can be damaging to your body and therefore should be entered only occasionally. For example, from hundreds of measurements of my heartrate I know that at the top of 10% grades on my bicycle, I sometimes enter the “peak” (=>84%) zone, but as the incline eases off I rapidly return to the unequivocally beneficial “cardio” zone. The core function of the Charge5 is the game of accumulating zone-minutes through vigorous activity. The watch has innumerable cheery messages that it sends you whenever you are accumulating zone-minutes, and it gently chides you every hour that you fail to do so.
Here are some examples of how badly the Charge5 measures heartrate. I was driving through a calm residential neighborhood to go bicycling, parked, strapped on my Charge5, and stepped out of the car, when the Fitbit congratulated me on earning cardio zone-minutes (in reality, I would not have yet even entered fat-burning). On my daily 30 minute ride on gravel, my Fitbit once calculated that I averaged 150 beats per minute (BPM) over the entire 30 minutes, when experience with that exact ride shows that I only occasionally exceed 120 bpm for a minute or two. For my age, 150 bpm is considered the maximum heartrate I can achieve; to sustain that for 30 minutes would presumably kill me. I have personally never seen a credible instantaneous measurement of >135 bpm. I could push that hard, but I would be gasping for air, and I’m too old for that for any length of time. To average >150 bpm for 30 min is simply unimaginable. Almost every night, one of the two bpm graphs (the zone-minutes graph) shows me reaching cardio (and sometimes peak) when I am sound asleep.
I mentioned before that the Fitbit misreads arm motions as steps, but it also misreads arm motions as heartbeats. My Charge5 has repeatedly attributed cheese grating or painting as zone-minutes in the cardio or even “peak” ranges, when in reality I did not have even mildly elevated breathing.
One infuriating example of misreading heart beats is to be found in the discrepancies between the two heartbeat graphs found in the Fitbit app. One is located under the zone-minutes sub-screen; the other under the heartbeat sub-screen. Both purport to show your heartbeat rate throughout the day, and the curves are mostly similar, but the numbers do not agree. I frequently see one graph (the zone-minutes one) that is 40 bpm higher than the other. Unfortunately, the errors are not consistent; I think it depends on the frequency of the arm jiggling that seems to produce the errors. Sometimes the bumps on a washboard gravel road is just the right frequency and the heartbeat rate is error-free; at other times the reported heartbeat is up to double the actual elevation above resting bpm.
Note that all of the errors inflate the number of zone-minutes earned by a particular activity. Perhaps Fitbit finds these errors tolerable because users enjoy the flattery.
Based on my experience, I have the following recommendations to avoid erroneous heartrate measurements. If you are doing an activity regularly, exercise while observing the instantaneous heartbeat rate, and note the typical value for each part of the activity, and then ignore the daily graphs that are wildly different. Do not use the GPS tracking feature unless you really need it; use of the GPS precludes you from seeing instantaneous measurements, and every time I use the GPS I get some huge errors. Be skeptical of any measurements taken from a gravel or rough road; four-wheeling produces a lot of bogus steps and heartbeats. Wear a long-sleeved shirt over your Charge5, as it will dampen jiggles that produce bogus heartbeats. Wear your Charge5 only on your non-dominant hand (left for right-handers). If there is a discrepancy between the two graphs in the Fitbit app, defer to the lower values (usually on heartrate sub-screen).
With those caveats, the Charge5 has some useful measurements: the sleeping temperature feature is purported to be diagnostic for detecting long-covid, for example (though you need a long string of measurements prior to and after getting covid). And it you cherish a dog that loves you because you feed it, you may find solace in the Charge5’s regular messages of encouragement for each time you earn a zone-minute. If you care about the accuracy of those zone-minute measurements, you might want to consider another choice.

title: Great design, Really Under-delivers on Native Device Features
text:
I love Fitbit - I worked there for years and have used all there products up to the Versa. Stopped using them after I left the company, but recently decided I wanted to have an alarm other than my phone, and my wife doesn’t like alarm clocks…so voila, I returned to the old stomping ground!

Pros
- sleep tracking is great
- HR data is solid
- sleek design and pretty good screen resolution for price
- easy band swap out
- great battery life

Cons
- incredibly buggy pairing process (c’mon ppl!)
- no breathing app on device WTF!!! I was furious as this was one of the features I was most excited about, and the last thing I want for stress mgmt is staring at my phone
- band that it comes with causes moisture build up, not breathable
- ECG usage is underwhelming, also requires phone and doesn’t work half the time - also what value am I really getting from this??
- auto-display turn on from me pulling my wrist up, a great feature, is horrible now - I have to snap my wrist with a lot of force for it to work
- the navigation on device is…tedious…doesn’t feel intuitive and swiping is tough with such a small screen, and cannot even see where I am as my finger is covering the screen. would prefer analog button to cycle through
- vibrating alarm does not stop when I dismiss, continues for another second or two - this is weirdly infuriating, I find myself thinking GET THIS THING OFF MY WRIST if I am in the middle of something and it goes off.

Overall I’m a bit disappointed - great tech jammed into a great design, but poor user experience and lack of expected features bummed me out.

Just to say it one more time for emphasis - WTF bring back breathing app!!!! Horrible trade off to make a strategic partner happy I’m guessing - and the messaging is very misleading around this feature being on device or not.

title: Can’t hold a Charge 5
text:
FINAL UPDATE May 30, 2023 - Well today the screen went dark on my Charge 5. Again followed all the trouble shooting steps. It collects data and syncs with the app, but the screen doesn’t display (faintly shows fitbit logo on re-boot) so it’s useless without pulling out my phone and launching the app. Meanwhile, a family member has had a similar Garmin tracker since 2016 and it has always worked and holds the same charge since purchase.

Time to move on from this junk bit.

UPDATE 3-Sept-22 After multiple follow up emails with no response I again used the chat feature in the app. They went through all the same questions as they have each time to see if I did all the potential resolutions (which are all listed on their site too). I answered every question and FINALLY…FINALLY they agreed to send me a new FitBit. None of the below has changed but the company FINALLY did right by the customer.
Update 23-Aug-22 the recent “update” has not resolved the issue. The device will show 1% when plugged in but then turns off. It’s impossible to run the update when the device won’t turn on nor charge.

After years of being a Fitbit customer I can no longer recommend them due to random failures, lengthy wait times for updates, and dead devices with support that matches.

I want to like this device, but Google has destroyed FitBit. With past products the service was helpful, even sending out a replacement device at no cost.

Yet the 5 has been a lesser than experience from the start. The fitbit app has been unchanged for years. You can pay more to get more, but the value of what you get isn’t worth it to the general population.

The new style band is clever but will rub you raw. Adjusting it so it doesn’t rub makes it too loose to operate. So either wearing and deal with the sore spots and peeling skin or leave it off until you want to use it for a specific purpose. Yet that sort of defeats the purpose of being able to track your daily activity.

Finally, a month ago my Fitbit started draining from fully charged to dead in less than 12hrs. Reaching out to support got a “we’re working on it” response. I’ve followed up asking for updates, replacement device, etc and only hear back with things like, “we’re aware of the issue” “a new update is being released”.

In the meantime, I don’t bother wearing it. It drains dead in hours, is finicky about charging, and both the app and firmware say up to date even though one of their responses provides the new firmware version except you can’t get it yet.

A month of being down and terrible customer service with no proactive follow up. This fit bit isn’t worth it.

title: The Charge 4 was better
text:
My charge 4 gave out and I "upgraded" to this charge 5 because the 4 wasn't officially sold anymore. It's a letdown.

The Charge 4 I could bring in the shower and water was never an issue. This thing is super reactive and skips around as water interacts with the display touching buttons and menus like a cat on your laptop. Yes, there is a water lock button you can activate, but it shouldn't really be necessary.

What's worse is that even though the display is super sensitive to water, it's not very sensitive to the double tap feature required to use some of the menus. It's very annoying. I find myself double, quadruple, sextuple tapping all over, frustrated.

The "improved" color display is tacky as hell. Just ugly. All of the themes look like they're designed by a high school intern. Tacky 70s themes. Not a single classy, simple theme with just black and white and information.

Why is it so hard to show me the time, the date (and day), and a FEW statistics (steps, distance, calories, etc.). There is plenty of screen real estate to display information, but they opt for ugly colors, bad layouts, and frustrating UX where I have to repeatedly click to get the info I want.

The worst part is the band. The Charge 4 band was comfortable and easy to take on and off. This thing is a hot sweaty, itchy mess which doesn't even fit well. The small band is too small and the large band is too large. The Charge 4 I had a couple settings with the large band which were both comfortable, one a little tighter and one a little looser. This one, loose or tight, all uncomfortable. I could sleep all night in my charge 4 for years. This thing is just painful sometimes and it's better to take it off at night. Purchased a couple after market bands, and if they aren't better, this thing is getting returned.

title: visual interface on the unit itself is bad
text:

There is a gallery with different skins to choose from, but there aren't many choices and they are universally awful. See my included image to get an idea. They are all overly "designery," with things like cut-off letters and the hour above or even to the right of the minute. And most of the layouts don't show much data at once either, forcing you to tap the device to cycle through your steps, active minutes, etc. Why, Fitbit, why? This should have been the easy part. People have been requesting better skins for a long time, but nothing has changed. We're stuck with these gaudy, pretentious, non-functional designs.

Similarly, you can't see much data at a time while doing workouts. Is your Fitbit currently showing distance and you'd like to check your heart rate? No problem, just tap it 10 times to cycle through everything, observe the heart rate, and then tap it another 10 times to get back to where you were. Ugh.

The bottom line is that the interface is very cumbersome. They tried to make it pretty and arguably failed even on that front, but more importantly, they forgot that we buy this for its functionality, not its looks.

The real issue is that since the initial setup on April 19th, I keep losing the alarms. I've deleted them, I've done resets/restarts/updates, but it keeps happening. Sadly, this morning was the last straw, but my window to return the device was last month. I should have gone with my gut and sent it back the first week, but I was hoping it was just my learning curve. The time is still accurate, but it is locked. You can see the "0" is cut in half. The only way to fix it is to turn it off and on.

As much as I've loved the previous Fitbit models I've had, I LOATHE this one. I actually bought a 3 year warranty for this one and I am not going to make it 3 months. title: The Charge 5 is a piece of JUNK!!!
text:

I now charge my Charge 5 battery every morning.
It goes from 100% to about 28% by the next morning.
Next the sleep score after 5.5 hours sleep is zero.
It does this approximately once a week.
It monitors my asleep for 5 and a half hours.
There just isn't a sleep score to display.
It's frozen on me twice and I've had to reboot.
This has all happened in the first month and a half.
If it lasts a year then I'll start to look for a different tracker brand.
The only thing I like about the Charge 5 is they have made changing the band a lot easier.
If you buy one I hope you have better luck then I have.
My conclusion is that the R&D department needed to show some progress in development.
So they duped their bosses into offering the crap 5 to the public.
Paul

title: Meh, over rated.
text:
I purchased this when my charge 2 died. I thought it would be a superb upgrade and I was very dissatisfied, so I called Amazon and returned it. I had no problems with the return when I explained what was happening and that I tried all the troubleshooting.
The GOOD: Nice looking, sleek design, smooth, soft band, able to see the watch face in sunlight, waterproof. The BAD: Had to beat the crap out of the screen, tried side of the screen to come on. I tried a light touch, hard touch, it just sucked. It just took so much effort. Flicking my wrist seemed to be the only way it came on every time on cue, I saw tendonitis in my future from the constant flicking. I missed pushing a button and seeing the time. I did try the manual and auto, they both sucked. I could not imagine putting a screen protector on it, as the screen just didn’t respond for me without one. I read that people with protectors said their charger didn’t work. Not sure that’s true, but I thought I’d throw that in for you to research. I also did not like any of the watch faces. They all looked so abstract and crazy. I just wanted big black and white lettering, and not an art showcase. I will say the screen in the light is way better to see then the Charge 2, that I loved. There is no way to arrange what order comes up on your screen like on the Charge 2. So, I must swipe through notifications, which I don’t use to finally get to my exercise. The treadmill did not log for me, but it would in run mode on a treadmill. Amazon rep said it doesn’t log treadmill runs. Not sure its true, but there is an exercise listed for treadmill. I also didn’t see aerobics as an option, just workout. I can’t see well without my glasses, and I don’t run in my glasses. With my Charge 2, I just started my run and at the end, held the side button to feel the vibration to let me know I ended the run. The Charge 5, you must tap the screen to start, then pause, then done and then finish. What??? Three steps to end my run when I can’t see the screen. The OEM band was nice and smooth, but I could not get the right tension. I have a small wrist and on one hole I was too tight and the other too loose, so I didn’t feel it was super comfortable. I was hoping it may stretch because the band is smooth and soft. I wish someone made that soft, smooth band material for the Charge 2 but with the buckle. I like the smooth, non-buckle band but it just didn’t fit me. Also, none of your bands, screen savers or chargers from the 2, will transition to the Charge 5. I did the 6-month free premium trial and none of the extra sleep, heart and Oxygen sensor would work. It also would not log my sleep from day one. It doesn’t count stairs anymore, but I didn’t use that much anyway, but I know people who do. In the run it buzzes you when you’re in-cardio mode and in fat burning mode, but never lets you know when your out of it. I didn’t find it useful. Plus, by the time I looked at the screen it shut off even though I had the screen display set to long time. I just felt for a brand-new tracker, it should not have had so many problems out of the gate, even trying all the troubleshooting, reading blogs from similar people who had the same problems. I looked at getting the Charge 4, most people said the Spotify was worthless. I guess if you want the 4 or the 5, it would be for the GPS and payment feature, which didn’t hit any of my needs. I have my phone on an armband and listen to music from my phone, so the GPS worked on my Charge 2 fine. I am sure there are killer features for runners on the new Fitbit. But I just wanted a simple tracker for exercise, steps, stopwatch, and time. I just think that it wasn’t that great for what my needs were. I bought a new Charge 2 on eBay. If I could not have found a new Charge 2, I still would have returned the Charge 5 and bought another brand. There were just too many annoyances for me to deal with on something I wear 24/7.

title: As a many year Fitbit member, here's my input on the Charge 5
text:

Pros
- All the same features
- ECG seems fairly accurate. I know I get flutters sometimes due to a health condition and so I've been able to track it with the ECG feature
- I can actually see this outside in the daylight!
- I like that the charger is a lot easier to get it properly attached to the terminals than on the prior models.

Cons
- I am nervous about even possibly getting this thing wet. the latch on this seems very inferior to the Charge 3 and Charge 4. It is quite touchy and easy to get it stuck. I'm not keen on exposing it to anything or even changing out bands often because of this. The Charge 3 and Charge 4 will take a bit more rugged use. Honestly, this is probably the biggest downfall for me. I'm concerned about the longevity.,
- This is more of a fitbit app issue. Finding the ECG readings is a multistep process and they were sort of difficult to find at first
- The ECG service has to be paid for, which I already knew in advance
- There is a passive Afib detector that you can agree to activate that will detect Afib outside of using the ECG app. I had an episode yesterday that I caught the tail end of it with the app. The passive Afib detector never triggered.

title: Accurate - Bad band design
text:
I've been using the Charge 5 for over a week now. 1st - The heart rate monitor appears accurate as I've compared the readings to what I get with my Garmin and an arm sensor I use for cycling. The Fitbit was within 1 or 2 beats of the Garmin, either up/down, at all times. 2nd - The sleep monitor appears to be accurate along with the associated respiration and O2 levels. While I don't have a separate monitor for these parameters, they are consistent night to night so would be a good indicator of any drastic changes either good or bad. 3rd - The distance as measured by the GPS is within the margin of error as compared to my Garmin. Even individual Garmins measure slightly different distances over the same route from one ride to the next. That's just the nature of GPS as provided for civilian use.

Now, for the band design. I will guarantee I'll lose this thing at some point in the future. The attachment of the band to the unit itself works well if the tension is perpendicular to the attachment point. However, if any sideways/parallel torque is applied, the band easily comes away from the actual unit. This torque can come from something as simple as the sleeve of my base layer catching on the band.

Except for the band issue, I would have given the Charge 5 a 5 star rating. But, the fact that I WILL lose it at some point, I can only give it 3 stars.

title: Really wanted to like it
text:
Gave this a really thorough try - and really wanted to like it. Great form factor, thin, light, great screen, comfortable band, superb online web/phone app connections points for off-loading data. What's not to like?!?

Unfortunately, the thing I couldn't get past is that the heartbeat monitor - i.e., the primary function for which I wanted a fitness tracker - was disturbingly unreliable. I tested it against other sources of reliable HB activity monitoring, including just a stopwatch and my finger on the pulse, and it was frequently far off for more than a few moments.

I tried tightening the band, didn't really address the issue (while making it less comfortable.

I noticed that while outdoors walking, if I put my other hand over my wrist (shielding the unit from the sunlight) it would work better - until I removed my shielding hand when it would go off again. Apparently the thinline design leaves very little overlapping watch surface to shield the optical HR readers from extraneous sunlight.

The problem was not as pronounced indoors as it was outdoors in the daylight. This makes me believe that the benefits of a thin watch body come at the cost of a compromised HR accuracy when outdoors.

Well, for me, that's a show stopper. If I can't rely on the HR monitor feature unless I'm indoors, I've compromised a key use case that prompts me to want to buy a fitness tracker in the first place.

YMMV. Happy hunting for a device that meets your needs. I really wanted this to meet mine but as explained above it did not do so.

title: Best sleep tracking, worrisome heart rate data
text:
I've been a big fan of Fitbit for years. I've owned the Charge, Charge 2, Versa and decided to get the Charge 5 because I wanted a durable, moderately-priced fitness tracker to tote around for activities like playing softball, swimming, camping, etc. because the battery life is just so good compared to almost all other trackers. The Charge 5 has a great battery life and built-in GPS and can still run 4+ days in my testing with GPS on the tracker itself. Impressive! It's also fairly light and while the stock band isn't as comfortable as I'd prefer, it's good.

That being said, I have a major gripe: the heart rate tracker. It's accurate but, and there's a major BUT, it's extremely laggy and doesn't engage with activities unless your fitness tracker catches an extreme jump in HR. Extreme = 40-50 BPMs higher than average HR. There's a chance that the tracker is actually grabbing the correct HR data but it's not displaying it. I own an Apple Watch series 6 44mm and the HR tracker on that thing is snappy. When I am not manually pushing the activity mode to track activity, the HR tracker can take 30-60 seconds in many cases to catch up. Eventually it locks in and is in lock-step with my Apple Watch (I've tested both on opposing wrists simultaneously) so I know the HR tracker is accurate but the lagging indicators are a concern for overall accuracy. Historically, Fitbit has also been a little exaggerated with total calories burned too but I can't determine how accurate/inaccurate this Fitbit is.

One of my favorite things between the Fitbit and Apple Watch is the total calories burned tracker versus "activity tracker" on the Apple Watch because the activity tracker doesn't do the best job catching low-intensity activity (standing, slow walking) so if I stand at my desk for 5+ hours at work I'm not really tracking the total benefit of that and it makes it hard to gauge where I'm at for the day. If Apple changes this and the Apple Watch becomes even more durable AND can run 2 days with activity tracking I'll probably stop using the Fitbit line. I had faith Google would improve the quality even more and the software would be fantastic. There's a couple small improvements but it's not really a legitimate step forward.

In all honesty, a GPS isn't all that useful to many people when they're using the device with their phone which can GPS track passively. Google should do better with the Fitbit Charge. Maybe they will but while this is a good device it's not the greatest and hard to justify the price versus just buying a less-expensive Charge 3 or 4 which is about as accurate.

- There is no way to turn off all vibration. I don't want distraction, but there are some uncontrollable alerts.
- The number of buttons you have to click to start and especially end an exercise is really annoying. Doubly so since, again, the touch screen isn't very reliable.
- There is no way to turn off things on the screen that you didn't put there: goal celebrations, 'Start run?', etc. I want to look at my watch and see the time, but sometimes I can't and I either have to wait or to exit a screen, which might not be safe while I'm biking or running. title: It's not what I thought it would be.
text:
It’s not a terrible device, but it’s more of a “gimmick” than anything. As of this review, there are hardly any apps for the Charge 5 and the ones they do have aren’t very useful. The wrist gestures are sluggish, and you might find yourself constantly having to tap the screen to get it to come on. Unfortunately, this has the side-effect of changing the home screen, so you’ll have to keep tapping to get back to whatever metric you wanted to see. This procedure gets a little old after 20 or so times.

My biggest complaint, however, is that this device DOES NOT track your oxygen levels (SpO2) in real-time. It only takes measurements while you sleep and even then, it only uses those measurements as an estimate. I believe the manufacturer knew this would be a pain point for Fitbit owners (there are LOTS of complaints in the forums) and they deliberately hid this shortcoming when they advertised the Charge 5 features on their website. It’s not until you use the device and go digging in their technical articles or forums that you realize you’ve been duped. There are some posts that say there’s a clock-face that does display the Oxygen levels in real-time, but I couldn’t find any for the Charge 5.

Their app does have some fancy charts, but to display any useful information, you'll have to purchase a subscription. Without it, you're restricted to the most basic of data. They’re just another company out to nickel-and-dime you for whatever they can get.

In my opinion, if you want a product that is ground-up designed for fitness tracking, then spend the extra money and purchase a Garmin. Yes, they are more expensive (considerably in some cases) but you’ll quickly find you do indeed get what you pay for.

Overall, I’d categorize this device as a toy, and as such, this charge 5 has found its way to the wrist of my young niece who gets a kick out of seeing how many steps she's taken in a day.

title: Flawed, missing my Charge 2!
text:
I am usually wary of 1- or 2-star reviews because people find one little thing that they complain about and it's usually user error or not that relevant, and I rarely give them myself, but I cannot tell a lie: After purchasing, then returning, then repurchasing at a deep discount a Charge 5, this former Charge 2 user is truly disappointed in the Charge 5. I'm happy if others love theirs; mine has just enough issues that make me wish I'd never bought it:
1) The available faces are overdesigned and difficult to read, and there's no simple default view combination of date, steps, heart rate; there are hundreds of complaints about this on the Fitibit website for several months now, but nothing's been done. It can't be that difficult to simplify the display code.
2) Syncing with my phone app is very slow. When I open the app on my phone it always, by default, first flashes "Couldn't sync" and it often takes three flicks of the screen to activate; that could be because the sleep score isn't visible on the Fitbit itself, long after I'm out of bed (see photo); the slowness here (often over a minute or two) is a huge complaint;
3) Truly stupid is that long after you've ended a phone call, there are "Active call" notifications displaying and you have to scroll down through them to "Clear all."
4) As with the Charge 2, the step and sleep calculations are, at best, approximations. One night the device did not register that I had fallen asleep until 4 in the morning (about three hours after I had crawled in bed). title: See my in-depth review below
text:
Some background info: I have been a triathlete for years. I have used Garmin devices half of my life and I track data most of the time such as running dynamics, cadence, and heart rate. I have prior history of using Fitbit watch for 2 years back around 2017-18. Now, I got the Charge 5 because I don’t want the bulkiness from the Sense because Charge 5 practically tracks the same thing as Sense (except a few things like the ABC so no stairs climbed will be measured). I tried Charge 5 for 3 days (including sleep and exercising) and one of the days I compared it side-by-side against a Garmin watch.

My quick summary: it is an excellent fitness tracking band but if you crave for something more than just basic tracking, look elsewhere.

Disclaimer: I tried it under free fitbit app because I wanted to see what I get from the free app since the membership price per year is outrageous (I am aware there is a 6-month free trial).

Here is my in-depth analysis:
Wear/appearance/design: I did like the charge 5 and its band. It is comfortable once you’ve adjusted to the correct area. I often forget I was wearing it most of the time. I have no problem wearing it overnight and no skin rash or anything after the 3rd day. I wear dress shirts during the day and it is slim and nicely hiding under my cuff. The display is vibrant and easy to read.

All-day continuous heart rate tracking: Their 24/7 PurePulse tech records your rate every 5 minutes. Garmin does it every 2 min. When I was wearing my garmin + charge 5 together for 24 hours, I can see a big deviation between both devices. The RHR for fitbit says 54-55 for me and for Garmin (from years of history tracking me) says 46-48 RHR. The HR graph is also friendlier to read on Garmin than fitbit. There is also more HR fluctuation throughout the day seen from fitbit than Garmin (perhaps because it measures every 5 min?). All in all, it is a bit questionable for me here.

EDA and ECG: I tried them but I don’t know if they are accurate. Even if they are not, it only tells me if I am sinus rhythm or not. I guess these are good features for individuals with heart concern or family hx of heart diseases.

SpO2, Heart Rate Variability, breathing rate, and skin temp: Yes fitbit tracks them, but you cannot interact with/open the graph to see how you did throughout the night/day. Garmin tracks respiration, pulse-ox, HR, and stress in real-time and I can track on the graph exactly when and what 24/7.

Steps tracking: For some reason, Fitbit is always ~250-300 steps more than Garmin at the end of the day. Not sure why but that is not a big difference. Charge 5 has no ABC so it doesn’t track floors climbed.

Sleep tracking: As mentioned above, RHR in fitbit is higher than my Garmin. It may be due to the type of sensor or other errors I’m not sure yet.

SmartTrack: I have done a 10k track workout and a 1.5 hr ride with some tempo zones 2-3. On the run, fitbit sensed it and the GPS is somewhat accurate (but it’s like spaghetti lines, not precise). HR tracking was fair compared to my garmin wrist HR. Then for cycling, the fitbit sensed it but started recording late. It also inaccurately track my HR to be much lower than my garmin heart rate chest strap that I have been using for years. Fitbit says my highest HR was 142 v.s. 166 on Garmin. I know garmin wins in this one for sure. Fitbit also doesn’t allow me to look at my exercising HR graph. If I go to another tab to see my overall HR tracking, the graph does not appear accurate at all. It is simply disappointing for cycling. I didn’t even want to bother trying it in the pool.
Free Fitbit app impression: I did my research on this prior purchasing. The only thing the Premium will get me is the 30 day trends, stress management, videos (which you can easily find online these days), and few other things I don’t care for. If you don’t care much for detailed graphs and numbers, free is enough for you. Premium is a rip-off.

Battery: it went from 100% to about 18% by the end of the 3rd day. I only sync with my phone twice a day (AM and PM). I left always-on display off. So 7-day battery life seems to be a long-stretch.

Overall: I’d give it a 3.5 out of 5 stars mainly because it does a good job tracking things but I don’t think it is there yet. I have also considered my possible bias towards it since I am comparing it with Garmin. But with my 2 years previous background with Fitbit, I do think Fitbit has improved a lot since 2017 but still need a bit more. I do think Charge 5 is great for a fitness-minded, non-competitive or non-data driven person.

None mentioned that it's literally USELESS during most sports, because the ONLY way to see or do anything is to tap the screen with the other hand, while also rotating the whatch's hand tawards your eyes! (for example imagine what this meens when biking). An always-on option is not available, and the built-in automatic turn-on never works properly.

Even when you do manage to see the screen, all data other than the time (e.g. heart rate... as in "fitness watch") is in TINY font, and requires multiple taps to reach - every time again. Imagine to try reading tiny font while running, and while both hands are atressed, to manage this.

One main reason I chose this, and was willing to pay over $200, is because it's supposed to have GPS - I was hoping to track and log my route while biking. Unfortunately, there is no sign of any GPS or location related functionality anywhere on the device or the app!

Now let's forget "fitness", and talk "watch". This "watch" forgets the time every time the battery is depleted!!! - as opposed to any smart device out there.

If this is not enough - you can't set the time from the "watch" itself!!!
And instead, you need to use the app on your phone, have internet connection, and connect to their server (!!!) - only to set the correct time!

I'm so sorry I got it, and wonder how reviews on appreciated tech sites fail to mention such fundamental flaws.

I have sensitive skin and was happy that the band didn't cause me to break out as many do. The display looks fantastic. I enjoy the moving prompts throughout the day including the challenge of getting 250 steps/hour. The app is easy to navigate, though it's worth noting that Fitbit charges you a ridiculous subscription price just to use most of the features that come with the device. Also, if this sort of thing matters to you, 98% of the available watch faces are garish and ugly, and there doesn't seem to be developer support for creating new ones.

The main reason I bought the Charge 5 was to track my HR during HIIT workouts. It takes forever for my HR to come down once it's elevated, so I needed to know that my HR had slowed before performing the next sprint. Well, the Fitbit HR monitor is not even close to accurate. After doing an hour intensive workout it recorded my max HR as 125bpm. I looked into it, and apparently this is a widespread problem with Fitbit's latest generation of devices. Other models seem to have the same problem.

This was a dealbreaker for me. It may not be for you. All of the other features seemed to work well.

I spent a little extra and got a Garmin Venu 2s and the features are so much more robust than what Fitbit has to offer, I don't think I will ever go back to the company. Especially because Garmin lets you use all your smartwatch features for free.

Either call for replacement bands or simply order $10 Maledan Compatible with Fitbit Charge 5 Bands
bands from Amazon.com. The reviews for the Maledan silicone bands state their rashes resolved when using the Maledan silicone bands.

title: Comfortable, accurate, misleading battery life and sluggish.
text:
The good: Very accurate HR monitor, verified readings with a pulse oximeter and they are pretty much on point, maybe +/- 1bpm. Sleep tracking appears to be accurate, but haven't cross checked it with another sleep tracker. Screen is visible under the Texas sun, great viewing angles and colors. Watch is slim and comfortable enough to wear without noticing.

The bad: TOO DAMN SLOW. Seriously, navigating through the menus is so sluggish, and I have to constantly swipe 3 or 4 times just to get it to register one swipe. If you need to tell the time it takes a solid second for the gesture to turn on the watch which is annoying, it's quicker to just double tap the screen to turn it on to see the time. We cannot download custom watch faces, they all have be the official Fitbit watch faces which all IMO look horrible. I just need the time, seconds, and my BPM but they're all minimalist rainbow vomit watch faces that barely provide ANY information (usually it's JUST the time and maybe the date if you're lucky. No seconds, and you have to tap through to see your HR, oh and the time is in tiny text because most of the watch face is composed of that rainbow vomit design). It's literally built form over function. I found one that I sort of liked and left it at that, but if you hate all 9 of the watch faces you are SOL because there are no custom faces.

Battery is rated for 7 days. Some say 5 is more realistic. I am lucky if I get 2 days of battery. Last night I was at 80%. Woke up with 70%, went to work at 7am, and the watch died at around 2pm. WHAT IS THIS BATTERY ???? I am having to charge this watch EVERY single day. I actually charge my watch more than my phone which is just ridiculous.

The ECG app worked maybe 2 times, and hasn't since. Everytime is says it's unable to get a reading, and then hours later I'll get a PDF notification on my phone as if it actually got a reading.

The ugly: This watch is good hardware, coupled with awful software. Fitbit has the audacity to charge a premium membership for some features (frankly, none of them are useful enough to warrant the price).

I really wanted to like this watch, but the software issues make it impossible. Avoid unless it's dirt cheap or they fix the issues with the watch.

To make it worse, you have to FIGHT with customer service to even have them consider a replacement under warranty. It took me 5 chat sessions and a phone call to get one under the warranty. They will blame the user for having features turned on (like Always on Display or GPS) as the cause, even if you have those features disable. They always claim 'well, our system shows you have those turned on'. It is INCREDIBLY frustrating.

I challege anyone who reads this to search the web for "Charge 5 battery draining too fast" and look for the official Fitbit Community website. It's, by far, the most popular thread.

In the end, as far as the device itself, it's perfect, as long as it's got a charge. If the battery lasted the claimed time, it's one of the best fitness trackers on the market. But, until they either fix the issue or acknowledge the issue, they deserve a 0 star rating.

title: Not an accurate fitness tracker
text:
I have used the Charge 5 now for approximately 60 days. I am fed up with it.

It cannot accurately track my heart rate while exercising. I have tried everything I could find online: I've done the 1-, 2-, and 3-finger distance from the wrist trick; I have worn it tighter and looser on my wrist; I have worn it higher and lower on my arm. The product either (a) cannot find my active heart rate or (b) continually misreads my active heart rate.

While at the gym, I find that I spend more time fidgeting with this Fitbit than focusing on my cardio workouts. If the Fitbit does not sit in just the right position on my upper-wrist/arm while exercising, the product misreads my active heart rate by (anywhere from) 30 to 60 beats per minute. If/when I can find that "just right spot" on my arm, the product tends to slip and the Fitbit loses my active heart rate again. Further, because I sweat a lot during my cardio workouts, the sweat interferes with the sensors and, again, the Fitbit cannot accurately read my active heart rate. Also, if my arm/wrist is larger than normal on a given morning, the Fitbit wristband may be too tight or too loose and, again, the Fitbit cannot accurately read my heart rate.

I am beyond frustrated and extremely disappointed with this product. I debated whether to buy a Fitbit for years. When I finally pulled the trigger, this is what I have experienced. Worse, when I researched fitness trackers online, articles pointed toward Fitbit. Nevertheless, this fitness technology is flawed.

I would not recommend this tracker to anyone.

title: Nice device. Decent battery life now
text:
December 2022 update

Maybe 2-3 months back they released a software update for the watch. That changed the battery life tremendously. I don't really pay attention, but I expect I get around 5 days on a charge, give or take.

Since that software update I've been very happy with this device. Would buy again if the device eventually fails.

### end update

2 month update: April 2022

* I like the sleep data on this watch. It's useful and appears to be relatively accurate. It's about the only thing I really like on this watch outside of its bright display.

* The band has grown on me. It's still annoying and gets in my way when typing, but it's pretty robust. I don't know if you can have it both ways: a band that doesn't get in your way and a band that is strong / sturdy.

* With great consistency battery life seems better when charging to less than 100%. Maybe it's a fluke with my unit, but more times than not, charging to 100% results in shorter use time between charges. I stopped daily monitoring my battery usage, but have had 3-4 days usage between charges as well as a little over 2 days. Be warned, however: the battery is like a vehicle's fuel tank that narrows on the bottom: once you start getting to 40-30%, battery life can go quick. At least on my device. I can't say whether rebooting has helped on an ongoing basis.

* This thing does not seem to have the capacity to be used as a realtime heartrate tracker. I think the heartrate tracking is accurate (based on checking against multiple different devices), however, the data I see on my watch seems to lag behind reality. Looking at my exported logs I see gaps of 5,10 and 15 seconds between heartrate data points, and I'm not certain the watch display updates as frequently as data is collected. Maybe it does, but you'd have to look at the source code to confirm. From my perspective, looking at my heartrate on my device is more akin to, "my heartrate was likely xx bpm within the last 30 seconds or so", not "my heartrate is xx bpm right now". I know it's accurate at rest, eventually, but I have no way of testing against other devices while I'm moving. Maybe this is something unique to me and/or my device, but it's frustrating. I think if you want a realtime heartrate monitor for exercise, I would not use this device.

I've lowered my rating to 2 stars.

### end update

I had an Inspire HR for nearly 2 years before buying this, so this will be compared to that. I bought this outside of Amazon.

TLDR; - this watch is okay. Battery life out of the box is garbage, but appears you can improve that. Band is thick, which can be noticed if you spend time on a keyboard or do other things where your wrist is in close proximity to a hard surface. Some watch / app features require premium membership, which won't be worth it to some people.

Would I buy this again? Maybe. If the price was right and there weren't potentially better options at a reasonably-higher price point.

Review and more info:

I've had this watch for about 2 weeks. The first day or two, the battery was nearly fully discharging every day. I decided to start tracking it, and that is my attached image. On day 2/3, when I started tracking, I was dropping about 3.3% battery life per hour. This is just wearing it. I don't exercise in the traditional sense and don't use watch notification things, so it's just an accessory that tracks my steps, sleep and heart rate, more or less. That's all I use it for.

I looked into it, found you could disable or offload the GPS to your phone, which I'm assuming is what made the biggest difference, unless the watch just needed a reboot after the firmware update. My first reboot took place after disabling GPS, so I can't be sure which caused the behavior change, or if it was something else entirely that improved battery life at that time.

At this point I'm getting 3-4 days between charges. Not 4 days, but possibly over 72 hours sometimes. It's acceptable.

The band, 2 weeks in, and I can't get used to it. It's a minor hindrance as I sit here and type this, or when I sit at my desk and type anything. I can probably / hopefully find a thinner band. The band itself is comfortable enough, I guess, though if you have large wrists, the band may be too small. I'm an ideal-weight person and am on the last adjustment hole. Maybe they made the band backwards: the tightest settings I don't think would fit around an average / large dog's leg, which is certainly smaller than most human wrists.

If you have the default strap too tight, it will leave impressive marks on your skin, much more so than I saw with the Inspire HR.

Possibly the EKG is useful. I think the skin temp feature is kind of gimmicky in that it only tests at night, can be affected by your arm placement and ambient temperature and really they don't seem to advertise why it's a useful metric anyway. Likewise the Sp02, only checking at night, which is really less useful and incredibly limiting compared to what I thought it'd be by reading over the sales material before purchase.

Certainly the brightness of the display is substantially improved over the Inspire HR.

I rate this a half-hearted 3.5 out of 5. It's not that I'm all that dissatisfied with it, but I'm also not impressed. The things that I like about it over my last Fitbit get washed out because of the still-unimpressive battery life for the watch to exist, the awkward band and features that don't have obvious health-interest benefits, or are so limited in implementation that they're not really worth mentioning as a selling point unless you want to disappoint people once they see how they actually work.

The watch is supposed to do way more than what I use it for, and if I intended to use my watch as a true fitness tracker and notification beacon, I would expect to have to charge this up to 1x-2x per day based on my experience thus far. If that were the case for me, I'd be buying anything else at any price point because at that point, there would be zero value in having this device.

Highly recommend this amazing technology with one exception meant without sounding condescending. title: Fun fitness tracker that you could probably replace with something cheaper. Short lifespan.
text:
I started doing health metrics during the early days of COVID, using a homemade Google form and spreadsheet. Then I adopted Google Fit to try and make use of their built in charts and metrics and stuff. About a year in, I decided to raise the bar a bit by incorporating a fitness tracker to automatically record bio metrics, and integrate the data with my existing suite of apps and stuff.

The Fitbit Charge 5 accomplishes this goal, although it wasn't really designed to be used this way. Instead, the device is bait to lure you into a paid subscription service. Without the subscription you need to use a lot of workarounds, like third party apps, to integrate the Fitbit data with whatever database you're compiling.

The heart rate monitor and sleep tracking are probably the most useful functions of the Charge 5, and you could replicate those functions with something much cheaper, in all likelihood. It has built in GPS but it can also use the GPS on your connected mobile device, in order to save battery. I use the built in GPS on runs, because I like to carry only minimum essentials. I have not used the Fitbit payments app, although I can see how that might be useful if you'd prefer not to carry around superfluous objects during your workouts.

The suggested retail price of this unit is too high, but if you can find it on sale for 25% off or more, I think its worth it. Just be aware that you'll either have to implement some workarounds, or else pay extra for a subscription to track your data long term and unlock some features.

UPDATE 3/1/2023
After about 18 months of use, the screen went black. I tried Fitbit's customer service, which suggested either rebooting the device using the charging cable button, or installing a new clock face from the smartphone app. Neither solution worked, and that was the end of Fitbit's support. So take that as you will. This was a good device for the 18 months that it lasted, but I'm not so certain I will look to replace it with another Fitbit, rather than a competing device.

title: Exercise in complete frustration
text:
I am a long-time Fitbit user. I upgraded from a Charge 4 to this (with a Christmas request). I have now gone back to the Charge 4. There is so much wrong with this device, it is hard to know where to start — but let's start with this seeming like an "alpha" release. Not even a "beta" release.

If you are used to a Fitbit battery lasting for days, get used to disappointment. This one lasts for maybe a day with the always on set to dim. The band is a Fitbit band, meaning bad and not breathable. Within days my wrist had two raw patches where water had gotten underneath and rubbed my skin raw. One "app" I use regularly is the Stopwatch to time how long I have been doing something. That "app" regularly disappeared from the Charge 5. I couldn't move off the countdown timer. I could only get the stopwatch back by resetting the device, which I never had to do before. Shutting off the vibration for the alarm, while in bed half-asleep, is an exercise in complete frustration. Almost impossible to do. Your partner won't like it either as it keeps going off. The last morning I wore it, I had to remove it in frustration and drop it off the bed. Also, I had tried to turn OFF the alarm completely the night before so it wouldn't go off at all, but despite my informed efforts, I must have missed one because it kept on going off early in the morning when I didn't want it to! Either too complicated or another software glitch.

Finally, whatever you do, don't buy through Fitbit! Buy through Amazon or other retailer. My wife bought this for me at the Black Friday sale at Fitbit, but didn't give it to me until Christmas. It took me a week or so to switch over and then I used it for a couple of weeks, giving it a good trial. When she and I tried to return it, Fitbit said that a return had to be done by January 9th! I spent an hour on the phone on January 21 trying to get this clarified, but after an hour with a representative (from India?), they still couldn't tell me anything. Amazon gives customers until Jan. 31 to return Christmas items. Is Fitbit deliberately trying to lose customers? Anyway, this product failed in numerous ways and I am sorry we ever bought it. YMMV.

title: After 3+ months of use, benefits outweigh disadvantages, but there are problems
text:
Charge 5, started using early October.

In general, I like it, and some things have gotten better since the first frustrating week in October, but there are still issues. I bought it mostly for heart rate monitoring while bicycling, and that seems to work well. But I really wanted it to seamlessly integrate with Strava app, and that is still disappointing.

I learned to be comfortable with it on my wrist. The first week was rather uncomfortable; now I hardly notice it. Except for the battery percentage, the screens are readable, and you'll learn what all the swiping left, right, up, and down, does.

Mine still has some issues:
UPDATE (2/5/22): Step counter works better if you're walking and swinging your arms normally. If you are carrying something (or looking at the watch) or gripping a handrail or walker or pushing a stroller, etc., you aren't going to get accurate steps. Syncing issues continue; GPS connectivity is still unreliable.

1) battery indicator on iphone app no longer registers correctly. Tiny greyed-out battery percentage indicator on the Charge is more accurate but is nearly invisible without a magnifying glass.

2) my device can't maintain bluetooth connection to iPhone app. This makes syncing difficult and time-consuming. Even after turning on/off bluetooth and restarting device.

3) integration with Strava for exercise (biking) is confusing and weak. Sometimes, when using "phone" setting for GPS, recording works great; other times it drops out (even over the same route where it worked the day before). So I have to activate Strava as a back-up, sometimes ending up with "duplicate" activities if Fitbit works. Just delete the Strava activity if the Fitbit one works, you say? They're not really duplicates though: Strava data is much more accurate than Fitbit, but Fitbit provides the heart rate, which is why I bought it. So I lose something if I delete either one. But if I keep both, it shows inaccurate record of my exercise activity. Grrr.

If I set my device for Built-in GPS, I'm not dependent on the phone, but the battery runs down very quickly, so it has to be fully charged before a ride of more than a couple of hours. And even then, the GPS distance measure is unreliable.

title: Highliy inaccurate - Inflated calorie burn, steps significantly off
text:
It's a neat idea but the lack of accuracy kills this product. It's only useful for identifying trends (i.e. I was more/less active today).

It calculated 200 steps for me as I stood in one spot brushing my teeth. Another 240 steps were tabulated while I was sitting on the floor petting my dog. And yet another 250 steps while I stood in one place cooking dinner. A 10 minute seated presentation at work yielded another 300 steps. I'll routinely wake up from a night's sleep with 100 steps or so already logged (after not getting up in the night at all). All these together, I'm logging around 3,000 or so "steps" per day doing mundane activities where I'm not actually moving at all.

In addition to that, the calorie tracker is absurdly off. Maybe by as much as 30-40%. The charge 5 noted that a favorite walk of mine at 3.18 miles burned 778 calories. That's CRAZY and no where near accurate. It has repeatedly done this for walking, treadmill, and weightlifting activities. It's not even close to accurate.

I had no expectations that this product would be perfectly accurate, but I also didn't expect the device to be completely inaccurate, either. I use it only to see if I'm trending towards being active for the day, or if I'm trending towards burning more calories. The only feature worthwhile that I've found on the device is the heart rate monitor.

title: Wanted to love this, but some clumsy changes from the Charge 4
text:
Love:

- New dynamic clock faces
- ECG/EDA (stress) test functions
- Exercise tracking

Like:
- Colorful screen
- Magnetic charge connector
- New band buckle (although I admit I didn't like it at first)
- Lots of different functions in the app

Dislike:
- Logging food in the App is really hit-and-miss. There are like a billion results for any search you do, and it's not smart enough to prioritize items you've recorded in the past. And frequently (probably 3-4 times a week) it just locks up when trying to enter something.

Absolutely Hate:
- No button to wake/return home, and it was replaced with the WORST TAP-TO-WAKE EVER. If the device has been awake recently, tap-to-wake works fine. But if it's been more than a minute, your odds are more like 50/50 that it will actually wake the device, and they go downhill the longer the device has been idle. One morning, I literally had to tap 27 times just to wake up the device so I could turn off the alarm. Support's response? "You can also use the auto screen wake" (i.e., where you spin your wrist to wake the device). Which doesn't work if you're using the Sleep mode. Just a horrible implementation. It's been 3 weeks, and I'm still honestly debating returning it and going back to my Charge 4.

title: I would not buy a Charge 5
text:
I have been a FitBit Charge 2 user for years, and it worked great, so when I broke the screen, I ordered a Charge 5 to upgrade. It came in one day, and kept time and counted steps, but nothing else worked because the heart rate monitor did not function (no green light on back either). Amazon replaced it within 6 hours, and the replacement was the same! No heart monitor.
I contacted FitBit customer service and after a few minutes was connected to someone with such a heavy accent that we could barely communicate, who ran through a checklist to make sure that it wasn’t something I was doing. No success, because the heart rate monitor simply does not function, and almost all of the functions run off of the heart rate monitor.
She “elevated” my situation to the next level of service, who was supposed to contact me by email. It has been a week and nothing.
I did some internet research and found that this is a common problem and that many, perhaps most, perhaps all Charge 5 watches have the same problem - probably a software update glitch they can’t fix.
Bottom line: The watches don’t work and FitBit customer service is nonexistent.
I guess I’ll return the replacement to Amazon, forget about FitBit and go find a quality fitness watch from a different company. I would suggest that you skip the hours of frustrating hassle and simply buy some other product to begin with.
(If you don’t believe me, go ahead and Google “Why doesn’t my Charge 5 heart monitor work?” yourself).
