title: Did not serve its purpose
text:
Bought this for my father thinking the he needed something simpler and less expensive than a Garmin fitness watch (I have used a Garmin watch for a decade) and because the App from Fitbit looks simple and insightful. First things first. It took me a few hours (in a span of two days) to install and upgrade the watch (with an Android phone) and get it going in my dad's wrist. The watch band by the way, it has some creativity in its design, once in place it is very confortable to wear. The big if is that my dad is not used to it and so he struggle the few times he tried himself to wear the watch. Although as I said the band is confortable I wonder why in something so important Fitbit decided to try something new. In terms of the screen and the info, if one is new to Fitbit it takes time to understand the icons and stats the watch delivers and the sweeps needed to get a full read of all the stats. One appeal for me of the reasons I chose the watch was this information. What I noticed for my dad is that he needed quite a bit of time to be able to extract the information from the watch as my dad kept sweeping the screen many times without success and so the first two days he used it he seemed frustrated. My thinking, like everything else is that this is about getting used to it, and a big positive of extracting in this way the info from the watch is the battery life one can get from the device.

My biggest couple of negatives of the device. While setting up the watch and the App (I used the watch myself to do this) , the app asked me if I wanted to hire the premium service. This I found it frustrating if you are new to the watch, when you have not had the time to see the full functionality of the watch. This is not very important, but still I remember filling somewhat frustrated by it. The second point is that in the second day of usage the screen turned unresponsive. There is a relatively quick fix for this if one googles the problem. By connecting the device to an outlet, and pushing a bottom three times, voila the watch resets. That showed me quickly that the watch was not for my dad, he would not understand why a new device would have that failure. In summary, the watch has some interesting futures, it is nice to the eye, but is is cumbersome to use and impractical. I returned the item and decided for a more expensive Garmin watch that I know much better, and specially its reliability and easiness of use.

Alarms. I need to take calls and conduct meetings all day. If I want to take a walk or do something outside, I would like to set an alarm to get me back at my desk in time for a call or meeting. The alarm function does not work at all.

I think the health readouts are questionable. If you want the novelty of 'believing' your watch, that can't handle alarms, can monitor your heart or your sleep, then this $150 toy might be for you.

I did contact support. They know the alarm function does not work. The "escalated" my issues. I got an email 4 days ago saying they are working on it. I decided this morning to toss this thing in a drawer and forget it. Fitbit is collecting more data on me that I get from this stupid, dysfunctional watch. A $20 Casio can trigger an alarm.

Not worth a cent unless you need a rubber watch to look cool.

title: Stick with the Charge 4
text:
I've been using Fitbit since the Charge 2, mostly to track my sleep and resting heart rate.

The first and biggest complaint is that the Charge 5 has no physical button. This means you have to navigate between the different applications using swipes that often do not register, with no easy way to back out of an app that you tapped on by mistake. This is especially frustrating if you want to monitor your metrics mid-exercise. Making matters worse, you can only see a single metric at a time (for running there's like 9 total). The Charge 5 has the biggest screen yet, but manages to fit very little information on screen at a time; the enormous bezel was not a good design choice in this context, but that's not nearly as bad as the fact that there's no physical button to quickly "go home" anymore.

The main reason I wanted to buy this device was the much-awaited Smart Wake feature. Sure enough the smart alarm worked for the first two days of use (though the swipe up to cancel, swipe down to snooze feature is not at all intuitive--again, a good use case for the absent button). However, by the third day I noticed that the alarm was no longer waking me. I've tried deleting my alarms, restarting my device, setting up new alarms then syncing the device. No luck. It's not because the motor is dead either, as the tracker still vibrates when I reach my daily step goal.

Finally, my computer is unable to sync with my Charge 5. I've been using the Fitbit Windows app to sync my trackers for years. The first time I tried to sync, the Windows app asked me to un-pair and re-pair my tracker, which I did, and it was able to sync. Since that first sync, my tracker has been unable to sync over Windows. I'm still able to sync over Android, but that application requires location to be enabled *at all times* (not just when the app is open) or it will refuse to let you access the dashboard. Not a good look when the device pairs over Bluetooth.

I will be returning this device and going back to my old charge 4. There's no reason, as far as I can tell, to use this tracker.

title: Abysmal Accuracy
text:
The shape is great and the build quality seems quite nice, but the nuts and bolts simply don't hold up. The sleep tracking is fun, but know that the goodies for this are only available with a premium membership on the app, which is free for six months with purchase of the band.

Outside of that, the step counter is incredibly bad. I often get my 10,000 steps notification when I'm sitting down, not even moving. From what I've seen, it seems to be up to 30% off at times, often overcounting.

The Charge 5's heart rate tracking is even worse than the step counter. I workout five times a week, and row three times a week, every time with the Polar H10, which is arguably considered the benchmark in heart rate monitors. The Charge 5 can't track the upper-end zones, which for me is 150–175. It seems the Charge 5 can't track anything above 140-ish. I work out so much, I can tell when I'm at my max, but the Charge 5 will give low, inaccurate readings. As well, it buzzes constantly during a workout if you've chosen the "workout" setting. The "weight training" setting is much less intrusive. However, regardless of the workout you've chosen, you have to tell it to stop, then finish, the scroll down and tap done to complete it and get back to the standard watch face. Seriously, Fitbit?

That brings me to the ECG feature. Considering it can't track my heart rate accurately during a workout, I can't imagine it would be able to give reliable information regarding a-fibrillation. I wish this wasn't true, as it was a buying point for me.

Another disappointment is the lack of different watch faces. I knew this before getting it, but it's worth mentioning for those who might like a wide choice or variation in this department.

Next on the list is the app. I don't allow it to use location services, which it annoyingly reminds me of every single time I open the app. It's also incredibly slow to sync with the device, often taking upwards of a minute to do. I can't imagine 24 hours of data should take that long, but it does.

All in all, this thing's an overpriced toy. I got it during the Black Friday sale, but can't imagine how torqued I'd be if I'd paid full pop. Definitely can't recommend it.

title: Legible and useful but flawed
text:
I received the Charge 5 as a birthday gift. I previously owned an Alta HR, an Inspire HR and a Charge 3. I am not a person who likes call and message notifications on his tracker, so I was accustomed to about 7 days of battery life from these. I have my phone on me all the time and with ever-worsening reading vision, I couldn't read any of the previous FitBit screens for anything other than time, anyway. The Charge 5 is different. I can tell pretty much what's going on with my steps/heart rate/calories burned on the standard watchface in any light. It's a big positive.
Two frustrations, though: First, the water lock should not be buried beyond the payment tile and whatever other tiles it's buried behind. If you shower every day, you will need the water lock every day. I did not have this problem with any other fitbit, but this one goes off to all corners of the menu if you don't water lock it in the shower. God help you if you do have payments set up. Second, if you like notifications for your workouts, beware. I went on a 4.5-hour canoe trip and this tracker burned itself out with the HR zone notifications. So I got about 3/4 of my trip tracked and arrived home with a dead tracker. I have since turned those off, but I haven't taken on another trip of that length since to see how it handles the ups and downs.
It would also be nice if paddling was one of the auto-recognized exercises, but it is not. It did, however, attempt to take my "outdoor workout" paddle and convert it into a swim. It must have recognized its error when I unchecked swimming as an auto-recognized exercise. Nothing like having a 15-mile paddle converted into yards and laps. I just shook my head.
If you're not familiar with Fitbit's culture, they have the same annoyingly useless help system as Roku: Post your question in the forums and hope someone with half a brain or a company title can help you out. That's not a "knowledge base," it's chaos and it's laughable. Hopefully you don't have any issues.
All told, it's a nice tracker, but it's got a surprising amount counter-intuitive hiccups for the 5th iteration. It was a gift or I'd probably be back to the Alta HR after watching the Charge 3 screen die mysteriously not once but twice. Hopefully this one stays alive longer.
EDIT: This thing just finds new ways to disappoint. My workouts are wildly inaccurate vs. previous Fitbits and the battery burns through the last 10 percent in about an hour. With everything turned off, I get about 5.5 days of battery life.

title: MULTIPLE UPDATES. Please READ BEFORE YOU BUY.
text:
Play Video
 I have a Charge 3 that is now 18+ months old. That’s probably the typical life expectancy for this device. Still works ok but showing signs of decline.
I set out to find a suitable replacement. The new Amazon Halo looked good so I gave that a shot but after a few days it seemed lacking in features and accuracy. Reconsidered an Apple Watch. Expensive upfront investment, and the need for daily charging was a turn off. So back to Fitbit. The new Charge 5 is a step up from my Charge 3 and priced reasonably with recent discount so I went for it. After a couple days, I’m pleased with its performance. I have not turned on the Premium features yet but may if I decide to keep it. Accuracy seems to be there judging by HR and Sleep monitoring. I will need to access the step count and activity functions. I like the ECG functionality. Nice addition. The Charge 5 feels comfortable on my wrist and the band although not my choice, seems good enough with a softer strap. I plan to update after a week or so. Right now battery life seems to be going well with 90% after 24 hours.

Update 5 days of ownership. I forgot to mention in my initial review that it did take extra effort to pair and sync with my iPhone 11. Success was achieved only after resetting Bluetooth on my phone and reinstalling the app. All seems to be working favorably. I really like the speed of sync and reliability of the Bluetooth connection compared to my Charge 3. Battery is at 62%. I have not use the gps feature yet. I think this will be a keeper. Very easy to find info on the tracker and the app is helpful compiling the data. Recommended.

Update 8 days: Battery still has 24% after 8 days. Not using gps. Still like this device very much. Great being able to track sleep, HR, steps, activity, mindfulness and readiness with App. Just placed on charger 45 minutes ago, now back to 93% charge. Excellent!

Update: 12 days, There has been a change in the rate of battery duration. Two things happened that may have impacted this. 1) I used the gps feature by selecting bicycle exercise. Normally I would not use the watch for this purpose as I have a Garmin computer on my bike but I was curious on how this might work. After a two hour bike ride more than 40% of the battery charge was consumed. It also lacks an auto pause feature like my Garmin has so it also counted a coffee stop as cycling reducing my average speed from 14 mph to only 8 mph.. Additionally, I also started the premium feature. I fully charged the watch this am at 8am (100% charge) and now at 3 pm it is at 80%. Bottom line, the less features you use the more battery time between charges. Still better than an Apple Watch.

Update 1-5-22. There are problems with rapid battery power loss. You should check out the Fitbit Community and review for the Charge 5. It maybe dependent on manufacturing location. The one I purchased here on Amazon was made in Malaysia. Others who got a Charge 5 made in China are having battery issues. Fitbit Will make suggestions to resolve these issues but for some, these approaches do not work. Beware that some are only getting 1-2 days out of a battery charge while others have documented getting up to 8 days. Fitbit is offering replacement for those who cannot resolve their battery issues but the replacement could be a remanufactured unit that is warranted for only 3 months.

title: Helping this couch potato reach some fitness goals!
text:
I’ll start by informing everyone - I don’t use all the features. The sleep tracking, water, food…. I don’t wear it at night. But I never knew just how sedentary I was until I started using it. The hourly notification if I don’t get 250 steps really helps me get away from the computer or tv or tablet and give my body, eyes and brain a break. I had no idea how many calories I was burning in my workouts and was stunned to find out that a 30 minute brisk walk only burns about 200 calories. Now that I can hone in how many calories I’m burning in a day, I can tailor my diet accordingly and I’ve finally started to lose some weight.

I love all the visual options, all the stats available in the app. My one complaint is it does VERY FAST when using GPS. I tried to use it on a long day hike, it died halfway through. So if you want to track hikes instead of runs, I’d get a garmin (my husbands garmin lasts much longer for the rugged activities). But the battery life is great if you’re just using it to track daily exercise and steps, etc. It lasts me about 5-6 days before I need to charge it and charges in about an hour if I haven’t used the GPS function. I highly recommend!

title: New color screen is great - the rest is a PoS
text:
TL/DR - loyal Fitbit used is extremely angry at the horrible quality of the new Charge 5

This is my 5th Fitbit and the upgrade from the previous Charge has some nice features. There are also some things like floor counters that are no longer included (and sadly missed), and I have to reset the watch at least once per week. Several of the apps are extremely buggy. All-in-all, the color screen and brightness controls are the only reasons I didn't return this device initially, but now I just want to throw it away - what a piece of garbage.

The biggest problem with the device is that there is no longer any button to use - the apps all depend on gestures such as swipes, taps, and double-taps. Unfortunately, the quality control for the apps is ridiculous and I have found a few errors that are merely annoying, but several others are deal-breakers.

Screen display does not come on automatically when I raise my wrist - even though that setting is enabled. I must tap the screen 3 times to find out the time.

The clock face cannot be updated - I get a bogus error that says I am not connected to the internet - yet here we are - typing a message on the internet. There is a lot of discussion on the internet as to how to get around this, but most of the suggestions involve removing ad-blockers and other security features.

The Timers app has 2 different functions: Count-down timer and stopwatch. Unfortunately, my watch is frequently stuck on the count-down timer and I have to reset the watch 2 or 3 times in order to get the timers menu to re-appear. It's currently stuck on a 15-minute timer that I set a couple of weeks ago and I cannot access the stopwatch.

The stopwatch - if the timer menu gods are allowing it to be used - is buggy. Starting the timer immediately shows the pause icon so that you can stop it, but the display doesn't change the digits from 0 for several seconds. It might show the 0 for 8 seconds and then change the display to an 8 - which then freezes for maybe 5-11 seconds and then the display is updated. Isn't a simple stopwatch something that the Fitbit engineers can code? Apparently not.

I've uploaded a video showing how buggy the Exercise app is. The video shows the app's limited range. I can scroll down to choose an exercise, or I can scroll to the right - which will either show a black screen or it will show the buggy Stopwatch app. I am trapped in this app and nothing will allow me to get back to the main screen - or anything else. If the device had a button, I could force it to reset, but no such luck. What a steaming pile of software.

If you've read this far and are still considering buying this piece of garbage, my condolences.

Fitbit really created a loser product with this one. No wonder the price has been dropped.

I hope that the Charge 6 fixes at least a few of these issues, but that's doubtful. The company has emphasized new feature and the Premium subscription service rather than building quality products.

title: Big And Bulky, But Better Than Inspire And Luxe Models
text:
I used the original Fitbit Inspire for about a year before upgrading to the Inspire 2.  I was very pleased with the upgraded model, which added some new features, improved on existing features, and improved my battery life from about 8 days to 12 days. About six months later, I upgraded again to the Luxe model. Sadly, I am left somewhat disappointed.  The Luxe is a great product overall, but there are a few things about it which seem to be downgrades from the previous model (Inspire 2).  After using the Luxe for only a couple of months, I upgraded to this Charge 5 model.

This review will compare and contrast the models I've used.

When I switched from Inspire 2 to Luxe, there were some changes that I loved. It goes without saying that the Luxe display is far superior to the Inspire 2.  The Luxe display is crisp, clear, and full color.  I also like the thinner band on the Luxe.  I didn't mind the band on the Inspire 2, but the Luxe band is definitely more feminine (although if I were a guy, I would probably prefer the Inspire 2 band).  With the Charge 5 model, the screen is even better than the Luxe; however, the band and screen are much larger. This is PERFECT for a man. I am a woman with a very small wrist and I feel like it is slightly too large for my frame. Overall, I prefer the size of the Luxe.

What changes do I not love?  The display on the Luxe and Charge 5 models is activated by touching the screen.  It is finicky.  Sometimes it turns on randomly from movement (you'll see an example of this in the video I attached).  Other times, I have to tap on it two or three times before the display activates.  This is a HUGE downgrade from the Inspire 2, which turned on by pressing the side of the band.  It worked every time and never turned on randomly when I didn't want it to light up. 

The biggest reason why I disliked the Luxe is the battery life.  It is estimated at only 6 days, which is even worse than the original Inspire.  In practice, it only lasted THREE days. The Charge seems to be an improvement, as I'm getting five to six days of battery life on this model.

The Charge 5 sells for $179. The Luxe sells for $150 - $200 depending on the band that you select.  The Inspire 2 sells for $80 and is frequently on sale for less.  I honestly don't believe the Luxe is worth the difference in price over the Inspire.  If I was in the market for a new Fitbit and didn't have unlimited funds, I would opt for the Inspire 2. If I had the funds to splurge a bit, I'd order the Charge 5.

title: Upgraded from Charge 2. Quickly returned Charge 5 to get a Charge 4.

- Floors are no longer tracked because there is no altimeter in the Charge 5. (The Charge 2, 3, and 4 all have one and can track floors.)

- The Charge 5 would constantly have problems syncing with the app and give errors when I tried to change the clock face.

- The blood-oxygen metrics are only recorded during sleep. There was nothing on the Fitbit website that indicated this at the time of purchase so I assumed incorrectly that you can do a blood-oxygen reading at any time.

- The heart ECG functionality was not available at the time of release. It really feels like Fitbit released the tracker before the software and other features were ready.

- You cannot set alarms in the app like you could with the Charge 2. The Charge 5 only lets you do so on the tracker itself. (I am not sure about the Charge 3.) This is too bad because it’s way easier to use the app to set alarms than the much smaller tracker screen. To be fair, the Charge 4 also forces you to set the alarms on the tracker.

I really wanted to love the Charge 5, but for the reasons above and more, I just had to return it.

text:
As background, I have been using Fitbit trackers for something close to 10 years, and generally have liked them a lot. I have in my possession a Charge 3 which actually works very well, but I finally decided to treat myself and step up to a Charge 5. Big mistake.

My experience is that several of the wrist alarms that I have set sometimes just mysteriously disappear. The EDA scan worked once and has never worked again; the sleep scanner is often inaccurate and the GPS is variable in its accuracy. Trying to do something as simple as put the tracker on my wrist and buckle the strap may take several minutes, because some idiot designed the strap to only be insertef under everything else next to the skin, where it does not slide well because of the pressure on it from the overlying strap. title: Good basic smart watch/fitness tracker, for a premium price, with some problems.
text:
I had a Charge 3 and decided to upgrade despite the charge 3 working fine. I had an inspire HR briefly before the Charge 3, which I miss for it's size and simplicity.

Immediately I noticed the Charge 5 has a color screen, and the built-in GPS and clock faces are a nice touch. Although, I bought my charge 3 on sale for $120, so the $180 price was hard to swallow.

PROS:
+ The band is flexible (but feels more cheap) than the previous charge 3 band.
+ The screen is 2x as bright as the charge 3, you can actually see this in daylight now.
+ Color screen
+ Easy to use apps and functionality
+ Water resistant, no problems in the shower
+ They ditched the side button from the charge in favor of all touchscreen functions. This button often went off randomly on my wrist.
+ The wrist flipping detection is MUCH better, still not perfect, but definitely better. (when you flip your wrist to look at the screen)
+ I got 4-7 days of battery life, depending if I was using GPS on my bike rides or working. (If you sit around a lot, you'll get closer to 7, if you heavily use it, you'll get less). You can extend battery life in a few ways, there's also an always on display that will severely drain battery, I kept it off.
+ Fitbit app is always easy to use.
+ Text messages work perfectly with my pixel 4a

CONS:
- The price, I think the watch is overpriced, especially compared to the competition
- Charge 5 specific charger, which is super short and annoying to use, it's magnetic but it's so short I can't put it anywhere as it hangs from my outlet. It also requires a USB charger. (I have an anker 3 port)
- Charge 5 specific bands
- GPS can be slightly inaccurate, and can outright not work if you have the watch tight on your wrist
- Weather app is gone, which is unfortunate.
- Like most fitbits, it will drain your phone's battery faster at idle, since it's constantly syncing and connecting to bluetooth
- The fitbit app has been the same for years without much change, still no dark mode and not much that's new, sometimes it's slow to sync.
- Fitbit premium is stupid, but 6 months is included with this watch. Why have a subscription with an already expensive product line?
- Fitbit watches have been known to cause allergic reactions, which I have a nickel allergy, fortunately the watch doesn't affect me.

Remember, like all technology, it can help or hurt you. Decide that with fitness trackers or watches. They are a data mine for companies, however, I use it to track my calories/diet, exercise, hit goals and targets, etc. Which helps me control my weight and improve/target my fitness. I also like having a digital watch in general, I mainly use the exercise function for bike riding which it works fine. I can not comment on other exercise functions, to which there are many.

I eventually followed a YouTube video that gave various steps to attempt to pair (i.e., restart the Fitbit Charge 5 using the little reset button on the "USB end" of wire which I had never seen before on any USB plug, restart the phone, turn off/on phone Bluetooth, turn on/off phone Airplane mode, hard close/open the Fitbit app, etc.). I have now been the owner of 2 Charge 5's. The first was dead on arrival with the black screen issue discussed extensively in other reviews and on Fitbit's forums. After far too many hours diagnosing and troubleshooting it with Fitbit I exchanged the product with Amazon. The second watch was technically functional, but suffered from severe measurement accuracy issues and general sluggishness. It was regularly up to 55 bpm (!!!!) off from other devices, including other Fitbits. I tried several positions and tightness levels without improvement. The form of the product is excellent however. It fits comfortably and the band material felt good. Perhaps with enough testing, Fitbit may be able to update the software enough to make this a functional product to fit its superb form.

This product was clearly not ready for release from my perspective, and I have no interest in acting as Fitbit's test development team.

title: A nice step up for the Charge series
text:
UPDATE May 2022: I'm still a big fan of this product and have made a few updates to my initial review(s), but the bottom line is that it's held up to initial impressions. I ended up knocking off a star just because there are a few improvements that can be made, but it's still very solid.

==============================

I purchased the Fitbit Charge 5 as an upgrade from my Charge 3. I skipped the Charge 4 since I didn't really need/want the new features of that model, but the allure of a color display with the same lengthy, weeklong battery life was enough to make me upgrade to the Charge 5. I won't cover all the features of the Charge 5 since there are plenty of other places that go into great detail, and I may update this review after I get more use out of it.

WHO SHOULD BUY A FITBIT CHARGE?
The Fitbit Charge is great if your primary use is as a lightweight fitness tracker. I prefer the Fitbit Charge over the Apple Watch and other smartwatches due to its lightweight nature, weeklong battery life, and my lack of need for fancier smartwatch functionality. If you like the extra bells & whistles of a smartwatch and don't mind a heavier watch that needs to be charged every day or three, then you may want to skip the Fitbit Charge. Also, if you're a die-hard Apple user who needs integration with the Apple Health app, then you'll also need to look elsewhere because there's no data flowing between the apps in either direction; thankfully, the Fitbit app is quite good and does integrate with a number of other apps.

IS IT WORTH UPGRADING FROM THE CHARGE 3/4?
It mainly depends on how much you value a better, color display. The MSRP on a Charge 5 is $180 (though, I'm sure the sale price will drop during the holiday season), while the MSRP on a Charge 4 is $150; though, at this point, everyone's selling the Charge 4 (and 3) well below MSRP, especially if you buy refurbished.

IMPRESSIONS:
- Initial setup was fairly smooth. I had to connect it to the charger to get it started up. Transitioning from my Charge 3 to the Charge 5 in the app was easy enough. There was a firmware update notice (the firmware enables the EDA sensor), and that update was a little buggy & required a few attempts before it succeeded (at one point, I needed to reboot my Fitbit).
- ECG monitor became available via firmware update 11/9/2021. I had some connection issues while trying to run it but got it to work eventually. I don't have any arrhythmia issues, so while it's a nifty feature, it's ultimately useless for me.
- The Daily Readiness Score also became available 11/9/2021. It's only available for Premium subscribers.
It takes 4 days before it starts functioning & a couple weeks to "tune". Overall, I'd say this is not terribly useful. If you work out on a consistent basis & get a decent amount of sleep, then it's always a great day to work out! That is, you'll remain in the Good to Excellent range (30 & above). For reference, I typically work out 4-5 days/week spending 30-40 min on cardio & 30-40 min on weights, which ends up being 110-160 Zone Minutes on those days when combined with whatever other Zone Minutes I rack up when not working out. But if you take a week off or so & return to working out, then you may dip below 30 into the Low score range where it says you should prioritize recovery. I also noticed that if you forget to wear your Fitbit to bed, it can throw off your score; it sent my score plummeting for no good reason otherwise.
Also, perhaps not surprisingly, the Readiness Score seems to be primarily reflective of your cardio workout. It will classify my "Activity" as "Light" on some days when I spend a fair amount of time on weight training that doesn't really sustain an elevated heart rate (and less on cardio).
- There's no longer a "home" button on the side of the display to "Return" or access additional menus. This took a little time to adjust to, but I'm generally okay with it, especially since the touchscreen is noticeably more responsive than the Charge 3. Now, you must swipe right to return to the prior screen, and you can also double-tap in most cases to return to the home screen; though, the double-tap can be finicky. Would I prefer to have a "home" button again? Yes. (Now, the sides of the device used for the EDA sensor & ECG monitor).
- The display is much, much better than the Charge 3/4. Brighter with much higher resolution. and of course, color.
- The display has 3 brightness settings; however, the difference between dim, normal, and max is rather subtle; they're all pretty bright, and this is unfortunate because it's a little too bright for dark rooms in my opinion. I liked the dim, auto, and normal settings on my Charge 3 much better. Hopefully, this is something that will be fixed in a future firmware update (assuming, the Charge 5 still has the sensor that allows for an "auto" setting).
- The "up to 7 days" battery life is not a lie. The battery life lasts me about a week with my brightness set to "normal", which is the same as my old Charge 3. I do not use the built-in GPS nor the always-on display (both of which are a significant drains on the battery), but I do average 6-8 hours/week of active exercise time. And, since the "dim" brightness setting is bright enough for me, I use it all the time, which translates to even better battery life. Pretty amazing considering the brighter, color display.
- The Charge 5 does a better job of automatically turning the display on at the turn of the wrist. My Charge 3 wouldn't always turn on or would require me to turn my wrist more than what felt natural. The Apple Watch is still superior with regard to automatically turning on when looking since there is a slight delay with the Charge 5 after turning your wrist (and, it still doesn't always turn on).
- The wrist band that's included is a nicer feeling silicone material instead of the plastic one that came with the Charge 3/4. The "small" strap on the Charge 5 band is also smaller than the "small" on the Charge 3/4. On the Charge 5, I use the last or next to last notch on the band (i.e. the strap is basically at its largest, most expanded size), but with the Charge 3 strap, I still had 3 or 4 empty notches to work with. Not a big deal since they include small & large bands, but something to consider if you purchase additional bands. I did end up purchasing the Sport band, which does have more notches to work with. Be sure to use Fitbit's sizing tool on their website before purchasing extra wrist bands since they do vary based on which one you get.
- The heart rate monitoring is nice & accurate like the Charge 3. I run on a treadmill with a Tickr X (1st gen) chest strap, and after the first few minutes of running when my heart rate is more stable, the readings between the Charge 5 & Tickr X are either the same or only off by a bpm or two. It's less accurate when doing sprints/HIIT since it tends to lag behind the Tickr X, but it's still in the ballpark (albeit, delayed).
- The EDA sensor seems like a waste for me. Along the lines of the guided breathing exercises in the Charge 3, it's just something that I don't care to use, and I question its accuracy/validity anyway.
- I'm not sure if this was introduced with the Charge 4, but there's a daily Stress Management Score now. The number seems fairly meaningless, since it's somewhat of a mystery as to how it's calculated. Yes, Fitbit tells you what the general parameters are (heart rate, sleep, activity) & premium members get to see how the sub-scores feed into the overall score (see below), but in the end, it just seems pretty meaningless to me.
- I think this may have changed with the Charge 4, but it no longer tracks the number of floors you've climbed (no big deal as it was wildly inaccurate), and it counts Active Zone Minutes instead of Active Minutes now. Fitbit's website has more details on Active Minutes vs Active Zone minutes.
- There's 23 clock faces to choose from. Most of them only display one stat (e.g. HR, steps, etc.) at a time (though, you can usually cycle through them all by tapping the screen), which is unfortunate. Hopefully, they'll add more data-rich clock faces, but overall, it's nice to see them making use of the colorful, higher resolution display.
- The charging cable functions a lot better since it magnetically clips to the Fitbit (like an Apple Watch does to its charger). I believe it's the same charging cable as the Fitbit Luxe.
- My Charge 5 somewhat regularly (once every day or two) has trouble syncing with the app. It has gotten better over time & usually just requires me to refresh the app (by dragging down at the top of the screen of the phone app). At worst, I'll need to restart the app, and once I had to restart my Fitbit device itself. Overall, not a big deal. Just an occasional annoyance.

FITBIT PREMIUM MEMBERSHIP:
I generally dislike paying for subscriptions since the cost of them can add up to something pretty substantial over time. The Fitbit Premium Membership isn't exactly cheap at $10/month or $80/year; though, you get 6 months for free with the purchase of your Charge 5. If you actually use many/all of its features, then it may be worthwhile, but for me, it isn't (i.e. I won't be paying for membership when my free trial runs out in a week or so). The Daily Readiness Score & Health Metrics Dashboard are the only premium features I routinely looked at, but I question their overall usefulness/practicality. Here's a rundown of what you get for your money:
- Daily Readiness Score: see comments above in IMPRESSIONS section - in short, not terribly useful.
- Health Metrics Dashboard (see attached pic): graphs/data for Breathing Rate, Heart Rate Variability (HRV), Skin Temperature, Oxygen Saturation (SpO2), Resting Heart Rate (RHR). The RHR data is already available for non-Premium users & you can view you most recent SpO2 reading on the device, but the rest of the stats appear to only be available to Premium members. The graphs are actually kinda crummy; there's two types: 1) one graph allows you to vary the time scale to view 7, 30, or 90 days, but you have to visually line up the dot with the values on the y-axis to determine the actual reading for each dot, and 2) another type of graph shows 7 days at a time with individual readings on the graph, but you can't change the time frame/scale of this graph. It would be a lot nicer if they made these graphs larger & interactive (so you could change the time scale on the fly & tap on the data points to see the reading).
- Wellness Report: You can generate a PDF wellness report to be emailed. While it provides a summary of HR, weight, activity, & sleep trends over the course of 1, 3, 6, & 12 months, it's lame that you can't just view this directly in the app.
- Stress Management Score details (see attached pic): extra details on your score including the sub-scores that feed into it: Responsiveness, Exertion Balance, & Sleep Patterns.... still not sure how meaningful any of this is.
- Sleep Score details (see attached pic): there's a different detailed view of your sleep score; you get sub-scores for Time Asleep, Deep and REM, and Restoration, but I believe all the graphs are the same for non-premium users, so I'm not sure that this offers much more insight that the non-premium view does; I suppose you get to see how much each sub-score accounts for the overall score.
- Instructional stuff: There are various workout routines, guided meditations, food programs, & sleep programs you can look up & do.
- Games & Challenges: You can participate in various fitness games/challenges, which might motivate you to work out more.

Overall, I think the Charge 5 is a nice upgrade from my beloved Charge 3, and for me, it was worth paying the extra bucks.

title: Not a must upgrade but worth it for many!
text:
So, if you are like me, you are debating whether to upgrade from the Charge 4. The color screen alone makes things tempting but it is a $180 upgrade. I had read some of the latest reviews and was pretty sure I would order this and return it. Everyone was talking about swiping overload because Fitbit ditched the button. That it was pretty much a color Charge 4. Some of this is accurate but not completely.

First, if you are active outside like me (I am a runner), just buy this now. The screen here is more than color. It is very bright and crisp. Easily visible in all light. The Charge 4 is a constant battle in the sun. I would actually have to time when I looked at the Charge 4 to coincide with my trips under trees and in general shade. I am going to guess that this will sound familiar to my fellow runners. The screen is just so much better.

Contrary to some reviews, I don't miss the button. I found the Charge 4 button to be unreliable anyway and, with the Charge 5, you now just tap the screen twice and, boom, you are back home. Easy. I am guessing some reviews were written when using a pre-release device. Further, the screen is much faster and more responsive. I would not call it a pleasure to use yet but it is when compared with the old clunky 4 screen. Further, the footprint of the 5 is much smaller and sleek feeling. Just a lot better on your wrist. You will be really happy with the physical device here.

Other than that, this pretty much is the same as a Charge 4. The battery life, waterproofing, and features are mostly the same for me. It will be getting updated with a lot of what the 5 gets here. Fitbit has given the 5 an ECG to help better measure your heart's activity but it isn't turned on yet. For me though, the vibrant more reactive screen and smaller form factor is more than enough to recommend and I do. My only caveat would be if you don't really use it outdoors. If that's you, buy the Charge 4 on sale and take the save. The rest of you should buy now.

title: Half baked, expensive, accuracy issues? UPDATE: can be RETURNED just fine
text:
UPDADE 4 (final):
Fitbit introduced the recovery score as part of the premium service (means monthly fees). It’s not as good as I’d hoped. Very generic and seems to rely on resting heart rate and HRV only. It’s a bit of a disappointment. I am keeping the 3-star rating. There are better health monitors out there, but this one is well-rounded. (and priced) enough to be a contender.

UPDATE 3: I am just going to sum things up after two weeks of use.
PROs:
*Great screen, can be easily viewed in very sunny conditions.
*Great for working out. Provides extensive metrics as you work out and seems accurate.
*Very good sleep tracking. Silent alarms (can be setup to avoid waking you up from a deep sleep).
*Decent heart rate monitor. Step tracker. Calorie count, etc. All these inherent features work well.
*Holds charge forever.

CONs:
*No recovery rate metrics, as promised by Fitbit yet.
*The screen is blinding at night. No way to tone down the brightness.
*No longer counts stairs climbed for some reason.
*Does not have actual body temperature readings.

I've learned how to estimate my recovery rate, based on resting heart rate, sleep quality and HRV. Still, wish that metrics was provided by Fitbit, as promised.

UPDATE2: Look like they made the black version FULLY RETURNABLE for whatever reason, so buy in confidence.
One more issue to report: the screen does not seem to have an ambient light sensor and the "sleep mode" does not automatically turn on. I find myself waking up in the middle of the night to a blinding screen that lights up the room. Not great!

UPDATE1: some have mentioned problems with the device being non-returnable. I followed up with Amazon on the issue. It is returnable, IF you experience performance issues or the device itself is defective or otherwise problematic. It seems like all versions but Black are fully returnable, so it must be a glitch. Talk to Amazon, if you experience an issue. They are extremely helpful.

I am now into the 4th day of testing and it looks like there is some calibration going on in the background, as readings are getting a bit more accurate. I wish the temperature sensor would provide nominal values instead of an evaluation on how much it changed from the day before. I hope Fitbit hurries up and releases the Readiness Score feature.

These are my initial impressions and I will update this review, as my experience living with Charge 5 allows me to better evaluate it. I have and regularly use Biostrap and Apple Watch. I am mostly interested in my sleep and recovery data and Apple Watch doesn’t do any of that, while Biostrap is useless for tracking workout. You cannot have it all, apparently. I was hoping that this Charge 5 can reasonably handle both tasks in one device.

To my great disappointment, Fitbit released Charge 5 without the promised Daily Readiness Score, which would basically indicate your recovery score after you wake up in the morning, telling you how your body is really doing, and whether you should go hard or easy on yourself for the rest of the day. It’s a great way to modulate your workouts and properly recover without overstressing your body. The Biostrap is excellent for that very reason (see some of my dashboard pics). That’s what I wanted out of this Fitbit and they didn’t deliver. There isn’t even a timeline for when the feature will be available.

Another missing feature is the ECG, but I am neither here or there on that one. Charge 5 also no longer shows you how many stairs you've climbed, which is disappointing, since Charge 4 did. After using it for two days, I am noticing that sleep time recognition isn't accurate. My Biostrap gets it right, down to a minute, while Charge 5 can be off by hours. Better turn it on yourself in the settings before bedtime.

Speaking of settings are adjustments...the lack of physical buttons means that you'll be scrolling up/down/left/right on a small screen all day long. It can get frustrating and menus aren't all that logically laid out. Another things that's poorly laid out is the dashboard, which is supposed to give you a snapshot of your metrics at a glance. You have to go through multiple screens (and some are not easy to find) in the app to get to various points of data. All of that should be viewable on one screen. AND you must use the phone app to view detailed info. Most of it isn't available on the web interface.

As it stand today, I would rather spend extra $20 and get an Apple Watch SE, which would be a superior tool in just about every respect until Fitbit delivers on the Daily Readiness Score. I’ll have to see how my experience with Charge 5 evolves, but I am giving it very generous 3 start for now…

title: Attention: Not suitable for counting kilometers
text:
I love hiking in my free time.
I was looking for a simple and cheap fitness smartwatch.
This watch should record my hiking route via GPS and the kilometers I have run.

However, the mileage for the route is completely off the mark.
That was originally my main reason for buying.
In some cases, there are deviations of over 25%. (17.2 km with Fitbit on a 14 km route).

After consultation with support, I also found the reason:
It is not a bug, but is software-related.
Although the watch records the GPS route, it calculates the mileage from a mixture of:
- GPS data
- And the number of steps unfortunately completely incomprehensible

to me. There is accurate GPS data.
Instead of relying on this, the number of steps is also taken into account when calculating the mileage.
There are also various forum topics about this on the Internet.

As a result, the clock went backwards — not suitable for odometer counting.

However, recording the GPS works without any problems, both via the watch's GPS and via the GPS on the mobile phone.
Both modes work reliably, even in the woods.
That's why I still give it 2 stars.

title: Ok for beginners
text:
The Fitbit Charge 5 is my second fitness tracker. My first was an Amazfit Neo. Since I really liked this one, I wanted better sensors and bought the Charge 5.
So - I was actually very happy with the Charge 5. I've had it for almost 8 months and have lost several kilos. I've gone from exercising 1-2 times a week to doing sport 5-6 times a week. I'm as fit as I've never been before. I wouldn't get them again though, as I've now reached the limits of Fitbit. I miss good Strava and bike computer support. This is significantly better for colleagues with Garmin watches.

So - what I really like:
- the Pro functions in the first 6 months are helpful and motivating
- the sensors are sufficiently accurate
- stylish design - calorie tracker in the app
- easy

- you can change the bracelet, have one made of fabric
- battery lasts a long time. On a hike in Nepal, just under 7 days without recharging
- still relatively affordable
- GPS usually accurate enough for tracking

What I don't like very much:
- First Fitbit after the first swim after 2 minutes is broken. Replacement through warranty. But avoid the new watch for swimming now
- no live tracking when swimming. The distance and number of lanes are only displayed after finishing and syncing with the app.
- App only works with the Internet. The app does not work on a plane, without reception or on a remote vacation. Connections were blocked from Fitbit in 50% of WLANs in Nepal.
- GPS less accurate than cell phones. Running speed is rather imprecise.
- Too expensive per functions
- Strava integration rather poor. Only activities using GPS are transmitted. Except interval training - that is never transmitted.
- no display of the cadence when running; the 15€ Amazfit Neo could do that better
- no way to transfer the pulse to the bike computer
- App not suitable for use on a bike
- Comparison to Garmin: no estimation of competition pace/competition fitness, no V2Max display, even if a sensor is actually available, no music function
- will probably only work soon with a connection to Google account That's a lot of criticism now.

I actually like the watch and would miss it if it breaks again. But more of a Garmin next. It has significantly better sports functions.

title: Countless Issues and Ongoing Problems - From the Very Beginning!
text:
I HIGHLY DO NOT recommend this device. From the very beginning, I have had nothing but technical issues with it. Within 2 days of activation, the battery completely drained. When I recharged the device, the screen froze, then went black. The user manual and help section of the website were useless and contained insufficient information (if any) to correct the issues. Eventually internet research and the experiences of others provided trouble-shooting suggestions. These suggestions included turning off nearly every feature that Fitbit boasts as unique to its devices. What then, is the purpose of this device? With these features turned off, the battery lasts about 5 days - which is okay, but not great. However, other technical issues persisted. Nearly every week, I needed to reset the device with the charging cable. The screen would glitch like a strobe light, freeze or blackout entirely. The device often had issues syncing and connecting to Bluetooth.

After a few months of this, I finally gave in and requested a placement through the warranty. Customer support was helpful and the replacement arrived fairly quickly. However, they sent the replacement via GLS to a pick-up location in a town 30 minutes by car from my address. The company did not even try to send it to my home (not usually an issue) or even a pick-up location nearby. This is not a reasonable process at all. Customer support also did not advise me to keep the charging cable and band. The replacement device is only the watch face. Fortunately, I had kept these. After charging and activating the device, the exact same issues began immediately. Fed up, I contacted customer support regarding a potential refund. After enduring more trouble-shooting advice and offers of another replacement or a 50% on a new Fitbit, I had to reiterate my disappointment/dissatisfaction with Fitbit and that I refuse to continue. My only option now is to contact Amazon to see if I can return it. We’ll see how that process goes…

Outside of these tech issues, the device and Fitbit service simply do meet expectations. I chose Fitbit based on its claims for sleep accuracy (I have a severe sleep disorder, sleep data is crucial) and blood pressure / oxygen saturation monitoring (chronic side-effect of the disorder). The monitoring features are not accurate at all, which makes the device only sufficient for the basics (steps, activity minutes, etc). For this, I would have purchased a much less expensive device. I also wanted the community aspect of the topic groups, group challenges and connecting with friends who have a Fitbit device. The companies recently eliminated most of the community features. And of course, most of Fitbit’s features are behind the pay-wall of the app subscription.

Personally, I am going back to Garmin. The device may be more expensive upfront, but most features are included in the device and app price. I found the tracking as accurate as its competitors and it suffers from far less technical issues.

title: Exceptionally disappointed
text:
I have been 'burned' by fitness trackers before, so was wary about buying the charge 5, but did a crazy amount of research and when it went on offer at £97 thought it was a 'sign'!

I was wrong!

It did start off well, once received, the features are rich, but quickly you will note most are either nice to have and not really needed, or just, well not needed! For example, EDA scan, seems pointless, the ECG just tells you you have normal sinus rhythm, and points out, that adverse rhythm can be very intermittent, so it is actually more beneficial to monitor heart rate and SpO2! So again, pointless, unless you have serious heart concerns, but if you do, it's very unlikely you will have a fitness tracker!

The GPS is a nice feature - except it can use your phone for this, to save battery life - so why have the GPS, unless you don't want a phone with you, which unless you are an occasional runner, is unlikely!

Anyway, it tracks well, is consistent and when comparing heart rates on cardio machines, seems accurate. This is all great, it is what I wanted it for. The sleep tracking is really informative, but to be honest, unless you are an insomniac, you are not really going to be changing much in the way of habits via a tracker!

But they are all features we like and use. The problem with charge 5 is two fold - firstly, the strap is silicone, but not breathable. This means, when you sweat, it may rub up and down your wrist, this causes rashes and they are not nice! I ended up using the charge 5 on one wrist for half the day, then the other wrist for the other half, to try and reduce this, but still it caused discomfort! It may be something skin gets used to, but after 2 weeks, it was still a problem for me, but I do have sensitive skin.

The biggest issue though, is the battery life. For the first 7 days, it was great, barely dropped 10% per day, then after this, which bizarrely coincided with signing up for fitbit premium, the battery life dramatically dropped, first to 50% per day, then as of this morning, it has dropped to 90% in one day. I don't have GPS active, all exercise apps are turned off, the screen isn't constantly on and I don't have animated screens. and apart from signing up for trial Fitbit premium, nothing has changed! I bought this because it was a good price point AND it was better battery than the Samsung watch 3/4, which has reviews about terrible battery life. I might as well have gone for the watch 3/4 because this is appallingly bad and for no reason!

In this day and age, with the sheer amount of investment in research on tech and with the investment from Google as well, quite frankly I find it awful that this is what Fitbit consider a leading product. It is no better than cheap versions of trackers and I decided, with one week of the window left, to return the item. This is incidentally why I buy from Amazon, because it is no hassle return and this is a huge factor when purchasing something like this, because as we know, no matter how good your research and the reviews, until you get it, you just wont know!

Thanks Amazon for your customer service - shame on you Google/Fitbit for your poor and shoddy product!

title: Cheap Assembly -- Screen Fell Off Whilst Sitting

However, in the process of getting to my office to get some glue, thinking I could fix it, it tore a bit and the screen no longer worked. title: Much promised, little kept
text:
Delivery was smooth, the tracker was also charged quickly and the app was set up quickly.

Bracelet
When I put it on for the first time, I immediately noticed the assembled and much too short standard bracelet. Ah, Chinese size. At least a longer one was included, but you had to Google how to change it first.
But the longer bracelet is also very tight. In addition, the closure and unclean processing lead to skin irritation within a very short period of time. Ah, you have to reorder other bracelets (that's also intentional, the things are exorbitantly expensive compared to the material value).

Touchscreen
The screen is small but sufficient for a pure tracker. Various watch sheets can be displayed via an app, but their design and readability can be disputed. The touchscreen reacts a bit sluggishly, especially when you switch to swim mode, you need several attempts to unlock the screen again.

Detection of sporting activity
The automatic recognition works quite well, compared to other products such as Withings or Apple, there are fewer sports that are recognized. However, the GPS is not switched on, but that is due to the app.

Fitbit app
The app was considered the gold standard for a long time, but it is also the weak point of the product, as it URGENTLY needs to be reworked. First of all, units on the treadmill are not correctly recognized, the same applies to an ergometer, where a workaround must be selected with a workout or elliptical trainer in order to get calorie tracking at all.
You have to set the sleep recording to “sensitive” to obtain reliable values, otherwise you can expect many interruptions. There is no progress recording of SpO2 saturation per night to identify and warn individual apnea phases, only an average value is calculated and displayed in the morning, which is also very poor and actually gives zero information.
There is also NO recording option for blood pressure and blood sugar, i.e. neither a product in the Fitbit series such as a portable cuff, the integration of a Bluetooth-enabled device nor manual entry is possible. This is precisely what would be important in order to track training efficiency.
It is also incomprehensible to specify the form of the day - I was shown an excellent form of the day even though I was exhausted from training the previous days and vice versa a bad form of the day even though I was rested and fresh and was able to train in the performance range. Quite a bit of humbug then.
The EDA function can be described as what it is: It is “Eh there” - keep your arms and hands still for three minutes and breathe quietly, that's it - the meaning and effect are questionable and can be used more for calibrating skin conductivity.
The ECG function also cannot be evaluated in the app, despite Premium. You get neither a measurement value nor a graph display. The Charge5 does measure well, but what good is it if you can't do anything with it. Even a 1-channel measurement under load would be better than nothing, especially for people with heart failure or other heart problems who want to exercise - even without approval as a medical device.
Reporting for the family doctor is missing in the app and on the dashboard, the promised export as PDF is missing (even with Premium) or is hidden in such a way that I can't find it. Overall, using the app takes some getting used to.
The motivationals, i.e. the various trophies, are very nice, but pretty pointless. There may be people who motivate themselves with it, but it quickly gets used to it and you ignore the whole thing.
It would have been desirable if there were real modules with which you can expand the app, but most of it was already activated and there were no more additions, even with the Premium.
Since most functions are not implemented correctly, all that remains is to switch to other apps and install them. When it comes to data protection, this is of course an absolute disaster, as it makes it impossible to track who can see everything in the most personal data.

Support
You are referred to a chatbot whose information is modest. In most cases, you only find out what you already know about the device and the services. The bot is also extremely slow and misinterprets the question. That was more than disappointing.

Summary/TL; DR
The product itself is good but with significant weaknesses. If you want to count your steps, this can be easier and cheaper. Sports tracking is fine for outdoor sports, but it doesn't knock anyone off their feet. The recording and evaluation of vital signs is inadequate. The stress and sleep functions are largely useless. The app and premium services are insufficient. The support is not good. The premium services are pure bag tailoring.

Conclusion
Quite nice to get started, but it doesn't come close to the products of other manufacturers. Within three months, you'll throw that thing in the corner and get something different and better.

title: Has so much potential, but I'm trading it in after six weeks.
text:
So I was looking for a comfortable fitness tracker (as opposed to a smart watch) with the primary aims of monitoring heart rate, light running and exercise, sleep tracking and general step tracking. Charge 5 seemed to suit the bill. I did read reviews of the poor built in GPS, but decided to take the risk anyway as I'd be running with a phone mostly so could use that instead (spoiler: I regret this).

Pros:
- Comfortable and unobtrusive, easy to take on and off
- Battery life excellent, multiple days no problem and charges fast
- App is really good, responsive, fast syncs etc. No complaints.

Here's where we get into the Cons:
- GPS. Awful. Awful. Awful. Built in GPS is a joke - you get an extremely jagged map of where you ran, which makes it inaccurate. Fine you might say, just use the phone GPS which I run with anyway. Well that's a mess. Constant drops where you are looking at the watch and see a red icon and "connecting" text. Is there anything more frustrating knowing you've been let down.
- Fitbit Support. Their first port of call is to "loosen the strap" to fix the issue and not having it touching your wrist bone. But that has the effect of not tracking your heart rate accurately or at all. Then they encourage you to do a factory reset. Sigh.... But that does not fix it.
- Step tracking. How does one wake up, look at their watch and see they have walked 60 steps without even getting out of bed? It massively over-estimates steps and therefore calorie burn. Super frustrating.

I don't understand how Google has not kept their high bar for customer experience through to Fitbit. It's clear there are major issues with this product. I should have read the reviews in more detail and not taken the risk sadly. Avoid this product. Maybe the higher end ones are fine but for £99 I expect better.

title: Cool tracker for sports enthusiasts
text: I've been using the Fitbit watch since Christmas to track all my sports activities (cycling, running, workouts). My original intention was to get a tracker that was as small and compact as possible, which I only wear when exercising to keep an eye on my pulse (I never really paid attention to that before). But things developed a bit differently because... I now wear the Fitbit around the clock. It is very comfortable to wear, very compact, light as a feather, looks modern and does not disturb the wrist. I now track my sleep and my pulse throughout the day, track my weight there with a Vitafit scale, log all sporting activities (some are also automatically recognized) and use the Fitbit as a.. watch. What I really like is the data that you have collected, for example, after a challenging mountain tour on an MTB or after a relaxing round on a racing bike. I particularly like the presentation of the heart zones (fat burning, cardio), which gives you a better sense of how the training carried out affects the body and allows you to optimize your training plan. The app/dashboard is absolutely great, very clear and customizable. The “dial” design can also be changed. In addition, there are a few tools such as the timer, which I regularly use when exercising. The battery lasts quite well and even after 3h sessions on an MTB in the mountains, there is still enough capacity for the rest of the day. I was skeptical when buying it for now, as the Fitbit is in the cheap range at €100. But I'm really excited so far. I can only recommend giving them a try to anyone who likes to exercise a lot and wants to pay attention to themselves a bit.

title: Better the good old Charge 4
text:
Fitbit and Xiaomi were the first two brands that shook the wearable market, making a fitness band indispensable today, but Xiaomi has been able to evolve, even if it has fragmented its brand too much into other submarines, such as Redmi, Poco, etc.
Fitbit has remained faithful to its brand, and has chosen to join Google to provide more extensive services... or at least that was the goal... not yet achieved.
With the new Versa, Sense and Charge, the famous manufacturer of fitness trackers has revolutionized the market with many beautiful to look at and very advanced sensors (on paper).
A sensor for measuring body temperature, an advanced heart rate sensor, a sensor for calculating physical activity and recovery, a chip for NFC payments and much more, but it's a pity that everything is managed by a terrible software, full of lag and that allows you to measure the temperature “only while you sleep” and not on command.
Joined Google, it could have introduced the new Wear Os on its devices, but Fitbit has only added the ability to show a pop-up when you have to install the device on your smartphone. It works almost useless and considering that there were so many other things to optimize, I would say that Fitbit has cut a hole in the water.
But given that the app is slow and redundant, with the features placed at random, difficult to find and with many functions that are useless, one could imagine that the smartwatch software was not optimized, it was that it remained slow and devoid of many features that even 30-euro smartwatches have.
But now let's talk about design. A very small display, in color yes, but which looks like something seen 4 years ago if not earlier, with an always-on display that drains the battery like a leech, when today there are bands that last even 10 days with an always-on display. A 'patented' strap closure system, which should be innovative, but which is only uncomfortable when you rest your wrist on a surface or while you sleep.
At least the NFC payment system works well, but honestly, considering that Charge 4 is 100 euros cheaper, I would say that Charge 5 is practically to be avoided.
Obviously, the same goes for the more advanced Versa and Sense smartwatches, which are nice doorstops.
Xiaomi remains at the top, supported only by Apple Watch.

Bought my partner and I the fit bit charge 5, as a way to monitor our activity and keep us active.
My first warning would be to not use the free 6 month subscription. The fit bit subscription service is a total con. It provides you with data other watches provide as standard but effectively if you keep the watch and subscribe for two years, it’s cheaper to get an Apple or Garmin Watch, which are far better devices. You’re also paying for your own data, so it just makes no sense.

However, ignoring the subscription and if you get the watch in the sales (I.e less than 100£) like we did, then it’s a great basic tracking watch. It’s step counter isn’t 100% accurate, but I’m not sure many are, it is however a good indicator for whether you’re at least close to a decent daily target of steps. The watch screen is lovely and bright, however the raise to wake function just doesn’t work, you end up having to tap it or shake your wrist 9 out of ten times to get it to wake up. This is the same on both watches.

It’s sleep tracking is also temperamental/ lacking accuracy. We have a newborn baby who needs feeding during the night, so we’d expect our sleep scores to be pretty low. We get around 70-80 scores as it doesn’t register that we were awake, when we were, or the fact that we were at points walking around the house.. if we just took the data from the watch, we had a great nights sleep, where as the reality is very different!

One of the watches has also already frozen, needing a full reset. Not a great start for longevity. The other has also disconnected twice from the phone.

Overall, it kind of sums up our experience to date with fit bit, we’ve found them to be quite hit and miss. Example: we’ve been on the same walks together and one will have a full GPS route mapped out and the other won’t, same with connecting and syncing with phones, every so often, the watch just won’t sync and this has happened to both watches.

The app itself, is a lovely and well thought out app, with easy to locate and read settings and the data it gives you is plenty to make positive health choices and get active.

As a cheap tracking watch we’re very happy with it. If you want something of better quality, better features etc. then avoid. If you just want to track steps, log dog walks and the odd bike/ride or swim and you’re not that fussed if it only tracks 80-90% of it properly, and you’ve got around £100 to spend on a ‘smart’ watch, then get the fit bit, it’s a pretty good tracker at such a low price point.

Another annoyance we have found though is around clock faces, there are no nice ones. Also when tracking an activity, you can’t get back to the clock face, so it no longer functions as a watch.. you have to end the activity to see the time again.

We’re happy with our purchase and would recommend them to those just wanting a cheap tracker, but if you’re tracking PBs, or the price is above £100 again, then maybe avoid as there are far better available.

Battery life is around three to four days but much less when tracking activities like walking. So far the shortest has been just under two days before needing a charge. There’s also no warning about low battery, and we’ve found that we have to plug the watch into the charger to find out how much battery is left, or check on the phone. Although the phone isn’t always automatically sync’s so this can be misleading.

title: Overcounts steps, bad UI
text:
1. Overcounting steps: My Xiaomi account got randomly deleted for no apparent reason about 2 months ago so I decided to "upgrade" and bought a Fitbit Charge 5 as that's supposed to be the best fitness tracker. However I almost immediately noticed that it counted considerable more steps than my old Mi Band 6. I decided to get to the bottom of it so I bought a couple of bands and currently doing a comparative test between the Fitbit Charge 5, Honor Band 5, Mi Band 6, Amazfit 5 and a random cheap one called Bingofit. I also bought a Realalt 3D pedometer and another digital pedometer. I'm also counting steps manually using a tally counter. When outdoors all the bands are pretty accurate (within 1% of each other and the pedometers) but when at home the Fitbit overcounts by about 50%, honor +20%, Mi -20%, Amazfit +10%, Bingo -30%.
2. The small selection of watch faces on the Fitbit are also pretty poor and they don't give me the step count without having to swipe.
3. When in exercise mode the watch face is not customisable and it gives me a bunch of useless data but not the basics I'd need - steps count and the time (I do a lot of walking - my main goal is to hit my steps and keep track of the time).
4. One time I was arranging clothes at home and it thought I just had a 20 min swimming session.
Readiness score also seems bogus, it told me I was in great shape to hit the gym after a night where I only got 4 hours of sleep. Whereas today it gave me a score of 1 despite sleeping well, just because I exercised yesterday. Needless to say I ignored it and smashed it in the gym this morning.
5. You can only link 6 activity types on the device and there is not a great variety to select from in the first place.

title: A lot promised, little kept
text:
First of all, the positive thing: The Fitbit Charge 5 tracker looks good, feels well made, and the display is really bright.
And now unfortunately for the less pleasant things:
1. I bought several of these trackers for my kids. Children under 16 years of age cannot set up their own account in the app, but may only have a child account in a family account. What does that mean? Well, I had to set up my own account first, even though I don't have a tracker myself at all. Then I added the kids as family members. So far, so understandable. But now the problem started: The child accounts can only be used with Fitbit Ace bracelets! Charge 5 cannot be connected to such a child account! Fitbit's support just “shrugged it off” and said “that's the way it is.” So everything back again, and the dates of birth of my children a bit backdated so that they can set up their own accounts. That worked out then too.
2. The pedometer is insanely inaccurate. Just shaking your arm makes the pedometer jump in air. Absolutely incomprehensible with a product in this price range!
3. The GPS is only used if you turn it on for a specific training period. If you want to use the daily route as a reference instead of the absolutely useless pedometer, you will unfortunately be disappointed. This is not based on GPS, but on acceleration sensors. The same sensors that supply the inaccurate pedometer. Conclusion: USELESS!
4. The support is pleasantly in German, but only provides you with ready-made answers. Individual questions are not addressed.
5. Unfortunately, the app is extremely confusing and faulty. Apart from the fact that the Fitbit app crashes again and again, I don't understand how you can even publish something like that. When I remove items from view on the app's dashboard in Edit mode, I can't add them anymore. They're gone forever and ever. The statistics also take a lot of getting used to.

CONCLUSION: The tracker is very nice and practical on the hardware side. The battery life also leaves nothing to be desired. However, the software, in particular the app, is barely usable.

title: unreliable
text:
The fitness tracker shouldn't be able to do much for me: measure heart rate counters during training, record the route via GPS when you're out and about, record workouts. None of this goes smoothly. Heart rate measurement is a matter of luck. Sometimes it records, sometimes it doesn't. When measuring, the deviation from the HF meter on the training device is sometimes up to 30 beats. This also makes zone recording useless.

I would like to have the display “always on” during sports. The setting completely ignores the part. The display is fairly easy to read - but not in motion. And especially during training, you also want to see what you do.

Whether the GPS signal is found or not is also a matter of luck. If so, the recording is relatively accurate. But not every time.

The pedometer already registers steps when you are sitting motionless at a desk. Despite the premium function, the app does not evaluate any training progress. There are far too few sports. Even when cycling indoors, the thing absolutely wants to connect to GPS, otherwise it won't record. It is a tragedy.

The whole thing is a bitter disappointment. And that even though it shouldn't be able to do much.

title: Disappointing Upgrade
text:

The built in GPS is pretty handy too as a backup, although it’s not accurate and does burn down battery fast (I’ve previously had connection stability probs with some phones). The price has also dropped to something more sensible since I purchased mine so the overall value for money is reasonable.
It also seems to have [more than I can count…] new features that I have no interest in if that’s your thing.
A major issue with this tracker - the material used in the strap can cause really nasty rashes if you wear it for more than a day or so, you may need to spend more $$$ on a fabric replacement. I found the stairs climbed/altitude logging interesting/fun for day-to-day monitoring and cycling which now seems to have been removed. The screen can still get activated by your sleeve whilst exercising in the rain and pause, or even end your workout (I thought they’d addressed this - there’s a water lock but not obvious how to for general workouts).
Overall - I’m not feeling this was much of an upgrade, Fitbit seems more concerned with fashion branding, pedling premium subscriptions and feature packing rather than focusing on solid, basic functionality; I'd likely try and alternative brand in future.

title: Returned to Fitbit from Garmin
text:
My first tracker was a Fitbit charge 2 which I regarded highly, only swapping it out for a Garmin Vivoactive as I started cycling more often. But the Garmin required near daily charging and eventually conked out - my belief is that watch tries to do too much.

I also think you’re better off with a strap type design than a watchface one, especially if you’re swinging your arms around catching barbells, dumbbells or kettlebells. Watchfaces dig into your wrist causing discomfort and pain. The strap design avoids that.

So I returned to the simplicity of the Fitbit charge 5 and I’m glad I did. I like the app better than Garmin active. The charge 5 now benefits from displaying more notifications from your phone too.

The main con is that you cannot link it up to a chest heart rate tracker device like you can the garmin, but I find the in built wrist tracker on this fitbit is adequate enough - the reason I got the chest strap in the first place was because the garmin in built wrist tracker was really poor at tracking heart rate during exercise. The fitbit is not 100pc accurate either, but it’s far closer to the chest strap readout than the garmin was.

One other note, non gps workouts (ie those that are not running, walking or cycling) don’t go to strava automatically - but you can sync them via a third party website - check that out via google.

title: Excellent but for one thing!
text: As a fitness tracker this is excellent value for money, with features included in more expensive versions. I bought it mainly for the ECG function, but also to support my fitness regime with data. That includes walking and cycling. I love the detailed summaries and insight. It is motivational and great feedback that is relevant and guides progress. But that's where the issue surfaces because you must choose either between accurate heart rate or GPS, but not both. I found a YouTube video that explains why and it is to do with the position of the GPS antenna, which is at the bottom and side. For accurate heart rate the watch needs to be firmly fitted, but, that hides the antenna, which means that the signal gets lost and tracking stops. The only solid solution is to choose the option within the watch settings which uses the mobile GPS. There is also a dynamic setting, which switches between watch and mobile, but it seems logical that if you have your mobile GPS tethered then best to use it full time. So this means that the watch needs to be tethered to a mobile for GPS tracking as for me I want accurate heart readings. For me I always have my mobile for music and calls, so I am happy to accept this flaw. Apart from that anomaly, the watch is excellent value and I'll not be returning it as the ECG and other functions really are very good for the price.

Lots of features are hidden behind a paywall with a premium subscription, given the poor performance off the app I am unlikely to continue paying when my current trial expires; in fact I may be looking for an alternative smart watch that better meets my needs. My original review gave 4 stars, after 4 months of use I am downgrading this to 2. Such a pity as the technology is great - its just that the app developers seem to have a very poor understanding of what their customers want.
