After a long time, I bought a Fitbit again because I lost my first device, an Alta HR a few years ago, from my wrist.
The Charge5 was mostly praised for its good sleep tracking, but I wanted to wear it all the way, of course. The fact that some functions are only available with a paid subscription, which comes into effect automatically after the trial period has expired, might have been another point of criticism, but unfortunately I can't really judge whether this is justified because I haven't tested the functions. Unfortunately, this will no longer happen.
After a week, I lost that too, again from my wrist.
I was able to find it again on the basis of the synchronization, but unfortunately a car has already driven over it in the paved parking lot. The display is now gone and the device is useless.

From my personal repeated experience, I therefore generally do not recommend a wearable whose clipped wristbands can be released from the case very quickly only by slipping on the wrist. I prefer to freak around forever to change a bracelet if I don't run the risk of losing a 130€ device all the time.
date: Reviewed in Germany on June 5, 2022

title: Does not work with (dark) tattoos
text:
There is a lot of talk about the functions, advantages and disadvantages of the Fitbit Charge 5 in many places, I'll spare you that. Better watch YouTube videos of tech tubers instead of Amazon reviews, where you often tend to review if you're dissatisfied: P

I find Charge 5 quite chic in itself, it's certainly state of the art, but: I'm tattooed on both arms, full sleeves, also on my wrists. There is a lot of black color on the left - that's not what the light sensor of Charge 5 does, which uses the light to check the blood composition and reads heart rate (not the same as “pulse”), oxygen saturation, etc. - sleep detection is also based on this, together with some other functions. Since black absorbs most of the light directly, the tracker unfortunately doesn't work on very dark tattoos. After I returned the first tracker (in this case unjustified) and received a new model, but it didn't work again, I was completely stumped. It was only my wife who came up with the idea that it could be due to the tattoos.

I have worn the tracker on my right arm for a while, the tattoos are brighter - the heart rate was measured correctly, the rest was still not. Steps were counted, but were set far too high. 280 steps were counted in the morning, even though I just stumbled out of bed to puss, haha:D The calories probably consumed were also completely absurd - 600 calories for 50 minutes of strength training is easy too much by a factor of 2.

Well, sent back, it doesn't help. With little hope, I bought the black Withings Steel HR Sport, it costs the same as the Charge 5, and the Withings app also connects to MyFitnessPal - and lo and behold, everything works, exactly. They probably installed a better sensor then. However, the Withings is also “earlier”, haha, it's just an analog watch with sportswatch functions. Heavier, but more chic. I am very satisfied - so maybe a solution for tattooed fitness sufferers <3
date: Reviewed in Germany on May 18, 2022

title: Great piese of engrennering with horrible User Experience
text:
UPDATE: downgrading to 1 star. On top of all the below GPS is off by 300m on 5 k run in comparison to other devices and phones (especially if you live the road and run on the footpaths), battery dries inconsistently on the same running course and can go from 25% to 0 in no time. and there are even more bugs to what's described below (for instance today I've had black screen of death just when I was going to go on a run). FitBit should be ashamed to charge £100+ for such a poor product.

Very very disappointing. Firstly, let me mention that my "high" usability standards were set by MIFit4 which I used for several years and it was like 10 times cheaper.
The good: device itself is very nice, gathers a lot of data, quite accurate when tracking activity, battery is decent and depending on how you use it will actually last longer then 5-7 days suggested in the description. For my liking default setting of vibration is too strong and there's no possibility to tune it down (only up)
The bad: User experience and testing was done by people who should be banished from software development forever. If this group of people were asked to design a WC room you'd find urinals upside down and toilets on the ceiling. And none of that would flush. Also I don't think any of them did any sports. Ever. Let me give you several examples:
1. Running app - you have a choice of setting a goal of 1,2,3,5,10,20 and 40k. I normally run between 5 and 10k. is it too much to ask to be able to select 8? or 13? How about a buzz every kilometer to inform me on my progress? again too much to ask? it’s buzzing like crazy with every heart rate change but almost ignores the distance.
2. Mobile app for this device is a separate story - it's literally USELESS! Max you can do with it is change the display view and see some stats. That's it. ok, also some fency training programs, sure. But a lot of user journeys lead you to the same place and that place does not resolve your problem. Or how about being able to set an alarm on the devise from the app? Set a running goal? being able to reinstall any program (it’s not the case for most of them). How about telling me my pace and distance via headphones while I run? It’s sooo much more convenient! Apps for waaaay cheaper devices are perfectly capable of doing that, but not this one. Maybe it would be slightly less frustrating if fitbit wasn’t that bugy!
3. Stopwatch and timer. It's funny that I even have to white about it. Both DON'T really work. Think about it, you are buying a £100+ device that has a problem with such basic things. Stopwats doesn't buzz in the end. I literally have to stop it manually and only then it decides to buzz. Time increments in 2-3 second steps, turns the screen off and then doesn't want to come back on, so if you are stretching on the floor you are screwed. You need to use your other hand to tap the screen to light it up and every other time it will stop the timer. At some point in time the timer disappeared from the device all together, I had to reboot derice 2 times for it to come back.
4. Bugs, bugs everywhere... today I was running 10k, at 8,5 mark the device said that the battery was 7% and this notification wouldn't go away. So for another 1,5k I was trying every trick in the book to get it to show me distance and pace but nope, screw me - 7% is all I've got. Naturally missed the mark and only when I've stopped it decided to show something else. Synced it with the app, it suddenly became 12%. Sometimes when swiping through the device it will get stuck in one place (like ECG or stopwatch) and refuse to move or go back to the main screen. It can last for seconds or for minutes. Same with activity reminders and other notifications or just random screens. And I could go on and on and on about these things.
The Ugly: Fitbit clearly does care more about marketing then about actual user experience. There’s a lot of hype about it but in the end you are buying yourself an endless source of frustration for £100+. I will be checking if I can still return it at this point as it was used already.

title: A great watch, an awful fitness tracker
text:
The Charge 5 has some improvements over the Charge 4:
- the bevels for connecting the strap to the body of the watch are reversed, meaning that if they break, you only need replace the strap instead of the entire watch being made redundant.
- it's more colourful.

After that, it's all negatives.
- the lack of a button makes navigation difficult, to get out of a menu you have to double tap the screen & hope you don't accidently turn off the alarm you just set for example.

The worst if the fitness tracking.

There are two main issues here:
- the screen is very sensitive to water. In the shower, you glance at your watch and the ECG monitor is open, or your alarm or your payment methods - it reads the water as being touched.
Worse yet, if you go for a run in the rain, it'll often just cut out - the screen believes it's being constantly touched and you will lose your run.

The other issue is a difficulty that Fitbit are having with Android phones (according to their Customer Support agent). A run will record the full distance (18km for example) but the map will only show the first couple of km and then stop. This is super frustrating for tracking any sort of outdoor activity.

Currently, despite having a brand new Charge 5, I'm tracking runs with my phone again or borrowing a Charge 4 to ensure I get the full run data recorded.

Overall, if your fitness tracker can't track fitness - what's the point?

Update: 3 months on, the battery has now given up and the device requires charging every 2 days. Regularly it dies during the night so Sleep Score doesn't work any more either.

I have requested a refund.

title: Absolute car crash
text:
I had a Charge 3 before this, which was reliable and functional. So, it is possible for Fitbit to make a decent device. It is all the more egregious therefore that the Charge 5 is such an absolute nightmare. I will outline why...

- The side button has been removed and so one is entirely reliant on the touchscreen to wake the device up. This would work if the touchscreen was any good, but it does not function anywhere near as well, as say, an Apple product. So to wake it up one either has to repeatedly hammer the screen, or perform a theatrical flick of the wrist. Half the time the device cannot even function as a reliable watch. In addition, because of the sensitivity of the screen to drips, it is near impossible to use it in the shower or swimming pool. This was also a problem with the 3, but the side button meant this could be partly overcome.

- The syncing. The syncing with the app is extremely unreliable. It is 0945 now, I have been up since 0530, and I still haven't been able to sync. However - and this is quite the achievement - it is possible for the device to endlessly and repeatedly display iOS calendar entries from yesterday.

- The ECG function is difficult to use and can only diagnose one abnormal rhythm. Pointless.

- The pulse oximetry function provides some sort of derived overnight average, but not a real time reading. Pointless.

- I don't know what an 'EDA' scan is but it takes three minutes to do and one has to grip the device the whole time, so no thanks.

- The colour screen is good, but is there a clock face that shows hours, minutes, second and doesn't look terrible? Nope, there is not.

- Can the watch recognise and active GPS for a long walk? Nope.

- The previous feature that counted flights of stairs climbed was good, but of course that has gone from this version.

- The device thinks it can tell you when you are stressed. This is delusional. There is no need for this kind of pseudo-scientific nonsense.

In summery, basic functionality has been overlooked in favour of bells and whistles that serve little to no purpose. A huge disappointment.

title: Great fitness tracker with minor issues
text:

So a great positive feedback about the costumer service that was very fast to solve my problem.

Anyway, to simplify I will do a little list with the positive and negative aspects of the tracker.

Positive:

-It is reasonably accurate compared to professional devices for tracking heart rate, steps, distances and sleep while compared to other fitness tracker it is excellent

-The battery life is great, I manage to do 8 days despite daily training with the GPS in dynamic modality

-There is the ECG reader

Negatives:
- The straps are horrendous. I had a pretty bad irradiation on my skin and they smell like a corpse after each training
- The ECG is a gimmick. The atrial fibrillation is usually an arrhythmia that cause a very fast and irregular heart beat but the tracker cannot do an ECG if your heart beat is more than 120 bpm. This means that it is almost useless.

In conclusion, the Fitbit Charge 5 is very good. Excellent heart rate, steps, distances and sleep tracking compared to other fitness trackers. However, the choice of the straps is questionable considering that I am not the only who suffered of skin irritation. Same thing about the ECG, what is the meaning of this feature if it is pretty much unusable to catch an atrial fibrillation when it is needed?

title: Barely coupled in the bucket
text:
The joy was great: the Fitbit Charge 5 had arrived! Of course, I immediately unpacked it, connected it to the mains and paired it with my iPhone. So far, so good, you would think - everything worked out at first. A message then came up that the firmware was not up to date. Trusting with blue eyes that this should not be a problem - after all, this is not a problem with other wearables such as Whoop or the Apple Watch - I initiated this. Something seems to have gone wrong, now I only see a white line.

“Well, let's start all over again” - I thought, decoupled the choice again and wanted to start everything from the beginning. Admittedly, I didn't pay attention here, because of course you have to enter a four-digit code when coupling - which I can't see thanks to the white line.

Ok, it wasn't the best moment of my use of wearables, but there will certainly be options for a soft or hard reset. So I read my way across the net and see that this seems to be a problem that was already there with the Fitbit Charge 3. And people everywhere claim that “pressing the charging cable button three times” would help. I can't confirm this - and I think I've tried it frequently enough to be able to say that. So it's bullshit.

So you turn to Amazon and Fitbit support. At this point, I have to praise the Amazon support, which has really taken care of my cause. Despite a detailed description of the problem, Fitbit Support sent me a general answer according to the motto “Make sure that it's plugged in”. This, as you can find confirmed in the Fitbit support forums, has quite method.

The last experiment on my part is that I let the Fitbit Charge completely empty in the hope that such a hard reset will be triggered. Fun fact on the spot: Since then, it has been vibrating every five minutes. In terms of frequency, this is about as pleasant as the high-frequency sound at the dentist. I had to bring the Fitbit Charge to the other end of the apartment at night so I could sleep - and I'm currently enjoying the regular buzz while working. If that doesn't work, I will correspond to Amazon's offer and send the wearable back. I'm going to lay the money back because after such a ridiculous experience and knowing that this is apparently not an isolated case, I can't trust the Fitbit company.

Why do I continue to give two stars for something of this kind of defect? First, because the mobile app makes an acceptable impression, I am convinced that the product would be really good if it wasn't junk. Second, in my experience, one-star reviews are taken less seriously than two-star reviews. So that I don't sink into the fever swamps of bashers, who like to write reviews with more exclamation marks than letters based on their own fanboyhood regarding other products, I give this one star to the company. Who knows, the Fitbit Charge will probably be usable with constructive reviews.

It'll tell you your heart rate was 100+, but because it's so SLOW to change to what your current heartrate is whilst exercising, it's a guess, and a bad one at that. And believe me, none of their advice fixes the rate at which data updates.

You might think it's worth a punt based on the price, but if you want any of the useful data you have to pay a subscription for it (not a cheap one either for what you get, there's absolutely no reason they should charge you the price they do), and with something this inaccurate I gotta say they really should reconsider the whole thing. title: Does not measure pulse peaks
text:
Unfortunately, batch 5 does not measure short pulse peaks, as batch 3 has done before. At the moment, I still need a certain amount of health monitoring in everyday life, and short pulse peaks, e.g. when getting up, at the beginning of an effort after rest, etc., are essential here. After a pulmonary embolism, my body is still spinning a bit, which is shown in such peaks. About 1 week after the embolism, I switched to the 5 series, and I was initially happy about the good results, but did not match my state of health. So I wore both watches at the same time, and I noticed the differences in measurement. Such spikes also occur, for example, in venous gymnastics. The 3 shows pulse 130, but the 5 only shows 90. That's why I wear both watches in parallel, even if the 3 has the well-known display damage, which is getting worse and worse. The higher readings of the 3 are correct in my opinion, because I countercheck them with a pulse oximeter in between.

However, with longer uniform pulse changes, walking, running, resting, sleeping, etc., the measured values again appear similar, even if the 5 only shows them with a delay.

This is not a Nedicine device, but I still find it essential that a successor model does its job so poorly. And it's not exactly cheap.

By the way, the Charge 3 and 5 functions are similar, respectively, without premium. So I won't buy Premium, the free basic scope is enough for me.

title: Expected better
text:
I upgraded from a trusted Charge 2 (that I bought in July 2017 and was still in good working order!) and honestly, I expected the Charge 5 to be much better than it is.

Firstly, it has no altimeter. In fact, I chose the Charge 5 over the Luxe because reviews promised an altimeter but apparently that sensor has been removed so no floors or accurate elevation tracking is available, which is a massive bummer.

The heart rate tracking seems to be off or lagging behind during excercise, I just did a 20min cardio session (one from FitBit Premium, no less) and it was still showing "fatburn zone" when I was about pass out, then jumped straight to "peak", but then the app logged it all wrong (no cardio zone minutes), even though I was really happy to see after the video that you can add it as a workout on the app with a click of a button. Also, this morning it registered a "17min swim" while I was getting ready for work, no idea why... So overall, the exercise tracking is not great compared to the Charge 2 that I was used to.

The Charge 5 also seems to count significantly more calories burnt during the day with less excercise/fewer steps than the Charge 2 would, so I'm going to have to up my daily targets to account for the difference...

I'm yet to take it on a run or bike to test the GPS but after the initial impressions (had it for over a week now), I don't have high expectations.

Some positives:
- Battery life is decent so far
- Colour display is pretty (but I can't seem to find the option to set 24-hour clock which is super annoying!)
- Active/zone minutes are counted immediately, and not only after sustaining the elevated heartrate for at least 8-9 minutes, which makes it easier to hit my daily targets (and harder to "cheat" by just moving my arm to add steps lol)
- It has some extra sensors so there are more health metrics and some cool personalosed insights (although I would swap any of them for an altimeter!)
- The readiness score is a really good feature (but only available on Premium)

If I could go back in time, I would consider buying the Luxe or even the Charge 4, because after having the Charge 2 for ages, the latest addition to the FitBit family has been a bit of a letdown...

In turn... Track length set, alway-on display on, started... let's go. The screen lock is automatically activated while swimming... And that's where my problem begins: I take a break every 500m and therefore want to pause time accordingly at the batch as well. I can't because I don't have a chance to turn off the screen lock in the water. The part says “double tap” but doesn't respond to it. Automatic pauses cannot be activated for swimming. I don't know if I could pause the training at all or start a new one if it worked... Probably the latter. But so my breaks are added to the swimming times and my time per 100m becomes 3:! 0 minutes instead of 2:02 minutes. A swolf is not determined, nor is the swim type determined. However, it counts the tracks correctly. However, the pulse values in the water are significantly too low and therefore a failure.

So the batch unfortunately has no use for me and is declining. If the product description could tell which data is being collected, I could have saved the whole thing... Garmin can do that too - why not Fitbit?

Maybe again in a few years... unfortunately here it goes back... Incidentally, I find the price-performance ratio quite good due to the quality of the sleep and pulse data (outside water) and rate it accordingly differently than others so far...

title: For those that can settle
text:
Device Looks/Comfort:
The device looks nice, it seems to be built well and the strap is fine, it didnt build up sweat, rub or make my skin feel itchy as other watches have. It is comfy to wear however with all hardware it is managed with software. my issues with this device come from software and the FitBit support teams.

Software:
-- No ECG on launch and still no released at the time of writing this.
-- FitBit studio. There is no way for developers to customise watch faces, create their own faces or make apps as FitBit refuse to add this functionality to charge series.
--Sp02 not on clock faces
-- No constant stress monitoring

Support Teams:
- After talking to support teams they had no idea about a majority of questions i had, Its like they have no been trained on anything other than to tell users to reset and repair the device upon any issues that occur.
- They didnt know about the charge 5 device in depth or know what the studio was.
- After alot of hassle i was finally able to get in contact with a "specialist team" to discuss it. However you cant live chat this "team" or talk to them on the phone. The only way to contact them is via email in which you get a reply maybe 1 once a day if you are lucky, reply instantly as an email comes in ? well you still will wait till tomorrow for a response.
-- Talking to the "specialist team" was more frustrating than the regular support team. They made the conversation go in circles requesting information and then dismissing , misunderstanding, or providing false directions whilst im being direct and clear in my questions and/or requests. eventually they referred me to the community forum, expecting them to help me instead. The community however have no involvement in this software, so cannot help, and the only part of some use in the forum is the feedback/feature suggestions. Except it really is no use at all, They reply to every suggestion with the same copy and pasted message subtituting the users name and thread issue to thank them for the suggestion, and to see how many "votes" the community give it. Then you dont hear any follow up on it.

Device Usage:
- All data collected has to go through Fitbits server. So having extra data analysis, such as your sleep score + Deep/Rem/Awake times, will require you to purchase a premium subscription.
- Always need to have it connected to your phone, As the device cant store the data for very long, so forget about long runs using built in gps while leaving phone at home.
- 23 clock faces are avaliable in the app, you must use the app to swap faces, you cant do this from the device and no extra faces are avaliable to download or be created, with no interest from FitBit to create more even though there is many community requests for this and no interest from FitBit to give studio access to create your own. The current faces in many opinions are ugly (with the styles and/or colours used) and/or dont show all the info many want at the same time. majority needing to tap threw the data to display or leave out some data points all together.
- ECG isnt avaliable, but is advertised, somewhat discretly, as coming soon and even then wont be avaliable in some countries.
- No control for music including spotify

tldr;
Pros:
+ Comfy and no noticable, even wearing 24/7
+ Battery life, Can get many days usage without worrying it will die
+ Responsive screen
+ Build quality
+ Charges fairly quickly with a magnetic charger
+ Apps on device seem to work as intended, i did not experience crashing or glitches.

Cons:
- No Sp02 reading on faces, This is done seperatly in an app, But i dont believe its live data, I think it just shows the latest data from the last nights readings, as this is recorded with the sleep data.
- Stress monitoring is done by making you hold the sides of the device for 3mins. It often will complain about this, by not detecting you are holding the sides, interrupting the 3mins and needing to resume or restart the readings. Then finishing with asking you how you feel. This seems as if it is trying to learn ? why doesnt this just give a predictive stress level constantly ? who knows why they decided to do this is anyones guess.
- No ECG app
- No Fitbit studio support, This is not a device for developers.
- Premium subscription is needed for indepth/extra data for some sensors and for more than just live data.
- Limited to stock, ugly clock faces
- No music control
- Limited storage for sensors/gps, always needs to sync with phone.
- FitBit has the Worst support teams i have ever encountered on a "premium" device

For me having this as a basic tracker was fine but i firmly believe when you buy a device then it is yours, having restrictions that limit your usage and experience is very much a dealbreaker. Having to try deal with support was a nightmare and further reinforced me having to look elsewhere.

I requested a refund on this product as a result.
